DOC.HEAD: Prescriptions, Milkshakes and Conversation at Old-Fashioned Drugstore
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report. ^LaserPhoto RM2 of Nov. 21
DOC.TEXT: There's nothing fancy and not much modern at Goolrick's Modern Pharmacy, where the druggist still delivers prescriptions and the soda fountain waitresses call everyone ``baby.'' Much of the store looks as it did 50 years ago, say employees and patrons. ``They got real wild in 1950 and changed the outside some. Why change something if it works?'' asks former owner and druggist Charlie Rector. The new owner is already looking to replace a new Pepsi machine with something that looks older because the regulars don't like it. At $2.25, an egg salad and bacon sandwich is the most expensive itemon the menu at the pharmacy's lunch counter. Behind the counter, cigarettes are stacked in wooden racks alongside tins of snuff and Goody's headache powder. ``We get lots of tourists in here who say, `Look, an old-fashioned drug store, you don't see them like that anymore.' I say, `Yeah, and you know why? Because you wouldn't patronize them,' '' Rector said. The drugstore has been in business on the same downtown corner for 121 years - through a fire, floods, desegregation and the rise of chain drug and convenience stores that put many independent pharmacies out of business. Rector bristles at the suggestion the store is an anachronism. ``This is not a curiosity. This is what a drugstore is supposed to look like.'' When Rector took over the business from his father and uncle in 1953, he had four competitors within a two-block radius. When he retired and sold Goolrick's this fall, it was the only drugstore in the business district in this city between Washington and Richmond. Like many American cities, Fredericksburg's merchant district hit hard times in the 1960s and 1970s, but shopkeepers have been able to capitalize on local Revolutionary and Civil war sites and the city's proximity to Washington. Now antique and gift shops thrive in buildings that once housed supermarkets and a five-and-dime. Tourists and antique buyers swarm the brick sidewalks on sunny weekends and fill up the stools at Goolrick's. A group composed mostly of elderly city natives gathers weekday mornings, each with an unofficial spot at the counter or at one of a half-dozen tables. ``It's not just a drugstore, it's a way of life,'' Rector said. The store was founded in 1869 and remained in the Goolrick family until Rector's father bought the business in 1933, Rector said. As a boy, Rector chipped ice, swept floors and delivered Coca-Colas and Camels to downtown beauty shops on Saturday mornings, he said. The drugstore has prepared prescriptions for generations of city residents and still delivers drugs at any hour. A few people who got their first Goolrick's prescription before World War I are still customers, Rector said. New owner Stephen May has pledged not to make any major changes, although he does plan to add a few tourist trinkets to the inventory. ``I think everyone was worried I was going to rip the fountain out, or worse yet, fire all the help,'' said May, 39, a pharmacist who plans to keep the store until retirement. Regulars are touchy about even the smallest changes. ``They don't like the new Pepsi machine I put in here, so I'm going to try to replace it with something that looks older,'' May said. ``People like it just the way it is ... I guess if you came in here as a child with your mother and now you've got kids of your own you want them to see it like you did,'' said waitress Viola Newton.

DOC.HEAD: Whole Community Sits Down Together For Thanksgiving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report. ^By JOEL WILLIAMS
DOC.TEXT: Folks in and around Vattman don't even consider eating Thanksgiving dinner at home or going off to visit relatives. For most of this century it's been a day when they all sit down together. ``The people here in this community, this is their home for that day,'' said the Rev. Sean Noone, Irish-born pastor of the small Roman Catholic church that rises out of Vattman's plowed fields. Thanksgiving has been the high point of the year in the sparsely populated farming area since 1913, when the annual feast began in a grove of mesquite trees. It was canceled only in 1943, due to food and fuel rationing in World War II. And 1943 is the only time that Idella Strubhart, 71, has ever eaten Thanksgiving dinner at home. She grew up in Riviera, an unincorporated town of 500 or so eight miles west of Vattman, in southern Texas southwest of Corpus Christi. She said a daughter in San Antonio invited her for Thaksgiving this year, ``And I told her I just couldn't do it. Everybody has a job to do here.'' Mrs. Strubhart was supposed to work in the kitchen while her husband, Fritz, 78, helped run the bingo game. They met at the 1932 Thanksgiving dance. What began as a small gathering has evolved into a major production at the parish hall of Our Lady of Consolation Church, about the only structure that identifies Vattman as a community in southern Kleberg County. The Handbook of Texas describes Vattman as ``more a community center for nearby farming families than a town.'' The all-day party merely begins with the dinner. Bingo, target shooting, ring toss and other games keep the picnic going until the dance starts at 8 p.m. This year the parish of about 60 families expects to feed 1,500 people at its Thanksgiving Day Picnic. Some former residents travel hundreds of miles. Old friends and strangers also show up. Farm and residential development began in 1908 on land the King Ranch sold after the railroad came through. Predominantly German settlers came to farm the land. Now nearly all of the residents of northern European descent seem to be related either by blood or marriage. They and their Hispanic neighbors keep a slow, rural pace and a sense of community hard to find in modern, urban America. Weddings and high school football provide about the only source of public entertainment the rest of the year. ``We grew up in sort of a naive setting here,'' said 62-year-old native Teddy Marie Wallace, one of this year's picnic organizers. Residents donate much time and effort, she said, because they know they have something worth preserving. ``I think we're kind of sinfully proud of our accomplishment,'' she said. ``I'm sorry, but we are. We do a good job.'' The Thanksgiving dinner, priced at $7 for adults and $4 for children, also is the church's only fund-raising event. The picnic attracts members of other denominations as well as people who otherwise never set foot in a church. This year's plans called for parishioners to cook 56 turkeys at home and take them to the church on Thanksgiving Day. Others prepared vegetables and desserts. Loretta Yaklin, the mashed potato maven, remembers how the now-defunct Vattman parochial school she attended used to put the students to work preparing the parish hall the week of Thanksgiving. The pastor said picnic organizers will meet about a week after Thanksgiving and start planning for next year. ``If we ever quit it, there would be a lot of people lost,'' Mrs. Yaklin said. ``What would we do?''

DOC.HEAD: Revted, n.a.-not avision Could Pinch Small Savers While Cutting Coverage for Rich
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department is considering a deposit insurance change that could pinch small depositors even though it is aimed mainly at reducing coverage for the rich. The department asked the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. for its opinion on whether to restrict each American to three federally insured bank, savings institution or credit00-per-account insurance limit. Some use brokers to divide their money among a number of institutions. Others use a combination of single, joint and trust accounts to protect more than $100,000. Under existing rules, a couple with one child, for instance, can protect up to $1.2 million at a single bank. Seidman said Treasury's idea ``has some merits and ought to be looked at,'' but a trade group, the Independent Bankers' Association of America, is vigorously fighting it. It argues that many Americans of modest means maintain more than three accounts. For instance, a depositor with six accounts - $1,000 in checking, $5,000 in savings, $2,000 in a credit union, $10,000 in an IRA retirement fund and two $1,000 certificates of deposit - would be allowed to designate only three of them as insured, even though the total - $20,000 - is far below the $100,000 limit. ``I think tens of millions of people would be adversely affected and their financial life rendered more uncertain at just the wrong time,'' said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the independent bankers' group, which represents smaller, community banks. ``A lot of CDs (certificates of deposit) would wind up not being insured,'' he said. However, Seidman said most small depositors likely would consolidate their accounts so that all of their money was guaranteed. ``This is much more likely to cut back on the guy who has quite a bit more money,'' he said. A senior Treasury official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the definition of an account, for insurance purposes, could be changed so that savers could combine all of their certificates of deposit into one savings account with varying maturities. The official stressed that limiting the number of accounts was ``one of a number of proposals floating around'' and ``we are not in any sense embracing it.'' However, Guenther's group, citing unidentified ``top policy officials,'' said a limit on multiple accounts is ``the reform concept most alive and well in Treasury circles.'' The independent bankers have been lobbying against any cutback in deposit insurance. They argue that large banks, which regulators believe must be kept from failing to protect the financial system, would have an advantage in attracting deposits over smaller institutions whose failure would not threaten the system. But many economists have cited the broad coverage of deposit insurance as one of the causes of the savings and loan debacle. Shaky institutions have no trouble attracting deposits because the accounts are federally guaranteed, they say. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said in July that the administration was considering ways to limit depositors to $100,000 coverage, but a letter from Guenther to members of his group was the first indication the administration is considering restrictions that could affect depositors with much less than $100,000. In an effort to kill the proposal, the trade group on Wednesday sent member banks 250,000 protest postcards, to be filled out by customers and mailed to President Bush. ``We hope by Monday there will be 100,000 postcards at the White House,'' Guenther said.

DOC.HEAD: Reduced Earnings Cut Into Gulf Crisis Profits, Government Says
DOC.TEXT: Big oil companies nearly doubled their profits from petroleum production after the Middle East crisis erupted, but most gains were offset by lower earnings from refining, marketing and the chemical business, a government report says. The major oil companies' net earnings rose only 1.7 percent in the third quarter, despite soaring prices for crude oil and petroleum products, the Energy Information Administration said Wednesday. ``There's no statistical evidence that profiteering took place,'' said Calvin A. Kent, administrator of the Energy Department agency, although he said he could not rule out the possibility of some isolated cases of profiteering. A study of third-quarter earnings reports from the oil companies showed that the jump in oil prices after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 ``did not result in runaway profits for U.S. companies,'' Kent said at a news conference. Some consumer groups that closely follow energy issues greeted the report with skepticism. Edwin Rothschild, an energy analyst for Public Citizen, accused the Energy Department of protecting the oil companies and said Congress should examine the companies' financial reports independently. He accused the companies of using ``all sorts of (accounting) schemes to under-report profits.'' And he contended that, especially in the weeks immediately after the Mideast crisis began, oil companies benefited significantly from inventory profits - selling cheap oil bought before the crisis at the higher rates. The report said most of the oil companies did not separately report inventory profit gains and losses in their July-September quarterly reports and that the issue would be examined further when annual reports become available early next year. The report provided no figures for specific companies, but it said that generally, companies with their own production capability fared much better than those that had to buy most of their oil. Although overall profits for the major oil companies were given at only 1.7 percent, the companies fared much better in their petroleum business. The major companies reported that earnings directly from petroleum activities increased 24 percent during the three months. But most of these gains were offset by a 50 percent decline in earnings from chemical subsidiaries that had higher costs partly because of soaring oil prices. Noting that 80 percent of the world's oil production comes from foreign countries, the report said ``the vast majority of the benefit of higher (oil) prices went to foreign interests, primarily foreign governments.'' But production profits increased sharply for the major U.S. oil companies as well. Eight U.S. oil companies, which provided production profits separately, reported earnings of nearly $1.5 billion from production during the three months, a 90 percent increase over the same period in 1989. It was unclear from the report to what extent those profits were offset by losses in refining and marketing at specific companies. Refinery profits increased at five of the companies by as much as 46 percent, while at six other companies they declined by up to 83 percent, the report said. Meanwhile, U.S. independent oil and gas producers, a relatively small segment of the industry, took advantage of the soaring world oil prices and earned $102 million during the three-month period, a 685 percent increase over the previous year. These producers reported earnings of only $13 million in the third quarter of 1989. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait led to a United Nations embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil and a shortfall of world oil supplies by 4.3 million barrels a day, prompting prices to jump even though Saudi Arabia and several other nations quickly announced they would step up production. Spot crude oil prices, which were about $21 a barrel before the invasion, peaked at $41 a barrel in October before declining. The price closed at about $30 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Offers Thanks to Troops in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's Thanksgiving radio message to American troops around the world: ``As we gather together for Thanksgiving this year, America has much to be truly grateful for. To those of you who are spending this holiday away from your loved ones to defend our nation's security and that of our allies, I am deeply grateful. To those of you on duty in the Persian Gulf, I say a special thank you. ``Recent events prove the world is still a dangerous and unstable place. Along with the triumph of freedom around the world comes new challenges - especially in the Middle East. Once again, you, the men and women of our Armed Forces, have responded to the call of duty to protect freedom and stand firm against aggression. ``And once again, you have the full support of the American people and the thanks of this president. ``You know, Barbara and I have spent a lot of Thanksgivings with a family we're proud of. Well, this year is no different, as we spend Thanksgiving in the Persian Gulf. And as Americans celebrate this special day back home, know that you are in their hearts. America is proud of you and the job you're doing. ``Almost two years ago, I began my inaugural address with a prayer, seeking God's wisdom and guidance in all that we face. Earlier this month, with American troops facing down aggression overseas, I asked the nation to join me in prayer - a prayer for the brave servicemen and women in whom we entrust the future of this country - as well as for those Americans held hostage. Now, this Thanksgiving, I hope that all Americans of all faiths and walks of life will bow their heads in appreciation for God's power to protect us and his wisdom to guide us. ``As member of our armed forces worldwide, your strength and readiness allow the flames of freedom and democracy to glow brightly. You represent America's best - the world's best hope for the future. No matter where you are, I hope you're safe and well. The entire Bush family wishes you and your family a happy Thanksgiving. May God bless you - and bring you home safely and soon.''

DOC.HEAD: Dangerous Toys Still Sold, Consumer Group Says
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Toys that could choke or strangle young children still are on store shelves this Christmas shopping season, a consumer group says. Releasing a list of allegedly hazardous toys that its members found in stores throughout the country, the U.S. Public Interest Research Group said safety standards are too lax and inadequately enforced. ``As the biggest shopping day of the year approaches, parents should not assume that the toys they find on the shelves are safe,'' Lucinda Sikes, attorney for U.S. PIRG, said at a news conference Wednesday. Because of inadequate or misleading labeling, toys containing small parts that fit easily into a small child's mouth are still available to children under 3 despite regulations designed to protect that age group, the consumer group contended. The federal Consumer Product Safety Commission sets the labeling standard, saying that toys with small parts should be labeled as not intended for use by children under 3. But in a report, ``Trouble in Toyland,'' U.S. PIRG said the labeling, even when accurately reflecting the intended age group, misleads parents by ignoring the safety rationale. The labeling often is in very small type as well, it said. ``Many parents may regard age labeling as a suggestion based on the developmental maturity of a child, not realizing that the toys labeled for use by children over 3 are often potentially lethal for children who still tend to put things in their mouths,'' Sikes said. As examples, the consumer group displayed parts that were either loose, as in puzzles, or could easily be broken off or pulled off, such as wheels or other pieces of toy cars. The report pointed to some crib gyms as particularly hazardous and said balloons can be life-threatening as well. The group, basing its report on 21 toys it said researchers had found on sale in 14 states, said industry standards for such products are being skirted or violated. David A. Miller, president of the New York-based Toy Manufacturers of America, accused the consumer group of trying to ``frighten parents about toys that are perfectly safe.'' He accused the group of trying to become ``national nannies'' and said it ignored the role of parental supervision and common sense. Glenn Bozarth of Mattell Inc., said the group ``speculated'' that a piece could break off the ``Mickeytown Ice Cream Playset'' despite thorough testing by the company showing the toy doesn't break. He said the consumer group should have approached Mattell about the complaint instead of going directly to the media. Shari Metzler of Gund Inc. in Edison, N.J., said the group included on the list a toy Siamese cat that the company quit selling two years ago. Allan Shook of Trisar Inc., of Anaheim, Calif., said the group used an old package of balloons sold by the company. He said the company changed its warning label in July to reflect that children as old as 5 face choking hazards from balloons and will include even stricter labeling next year. Sikes acknowledged that the product safety commission was working on special labeling requirements for balloons, balls and marbles. But she said the rulemaking could take years. She said she was encouraged, however, by a new law that gives the commission authority to fine manufacturers who keep putting unsafe products on the market. CPSC spokesman Dan Rumelt said the agency had not had time to review the consumer group's list. The agency held its own presentation earlier this week, urging parents and shoppers to watch for similar hazards. The commission said it received reports of 33 deaths related to toys from January 1989 to September 1990. In 20 of these cases, the children choked on small objects. The consumer group said toy-related injuries have increased steadily, rising to 148,000 in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey And Solitude for Americans in Bagdad, Worry for Human Shields
DOC.TEXT: Some of the American hostages who are spending a quiet but somber Thanksgiving in the Iraqi capital say it could be worse - they could be among the ``human shields'' held at potential military targets. ``Although we have it better than those at the sites ... we all suffer the indignity of being a hostage,'' said Roland Bergheer, among a handful of American men who planned a turkey dinner today at the U.S. Embassy residence. About 100 Americans are among the 600 Westerners held at strategic Iraqi installations to deter a feared U.S. attack. ``Everyone at the residence feels this is the greatest holiday of the year, the most meaningful, but it will be somber and quiet,'' said Bergheer, 62, a construction company executive who grew up in Los Angeles and makes his home in Las Vegas. Joe Wilson, the charge d'affaires at the American embassy, said he hoped to begin Thanksgiving with the latest of several protests to the Iraqi Foreign Ministry about the plight of Americans prevented from leaving Iraq. It is an issue that Wilson has raised at least twice a week with officials at all levels and with President Saddam Hussein during their only meeting on Aug. 6, four days after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. He said special appeals have been made for hostages with medical problems and individuals who should be evacuated for humanitarian reasons. Wilson said 75 people fall into those categories. The Iraqis have mostly ignored the appeals, even for one man whose wife died while he was being held at a strategic site. ``I tell you it is terribly frustrating,'' Wilson said. ``I don't even know if my condolence letter to the gentleman has reached him.'' He said the Iraqi response has been that the hostages are ``guests'' who will be released when Iraq receives assurances it will not be attacked. Diplomats are not allowed to visit hostages at strategic sites. The embassy tries to send the hostages their mail through the Foreign Ministry. The diplomats have set up a pen pal system in hopes of sending those hostages more regular mail. They publish a weekly newsletter with football scores and news items designed not to attract the attention of an Iraqi censor. ``We try to give them something that will remind them of home and let them know we are thinking about them,'' Wilson said. Over the months of captivity, the hostages in Baghdad have developed close relationships among themselves and with the diplomats. ``They (the hostages) are really tough people,'' Wilson said. ``They're good people. They understand the issues and know how big the issues are. ... They want to be able to walk out of here with their heads high and not as a result of some underhanded negotiations or payoff.'' The American hostages in Iraq on Wednesday addressed a Thanksgiving message to those celebrating the national holiday in the United States. The message said in part: ``The ingredients of this deeply meaningful dinner are very special, and are not available everywhere. The two main ingredients are freedom and justice for all. Freedom to be your very best, to exceed your own expectations, to worship and follow your own God, and to come and go as you please. Justice to guarantee your rights and freedoms under our constitution until proven wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: A Thanksgiving Message From Baghdad Hosatges
With PM-Gulf-Hostage-Thanksgiving
DOC.TEXT: American hostages held in Iraq have addressed a Thanksgiving message to those celebrating the national holiday in the United States. Following is the text as released to foreign reporters: ``On this most traditional of American holidays, we would like to extend our best wishes to all the Iraqis and Iraqi-Americans who are about to enjoy our national feast while in our country, the United States of America. ``The ingredients of this deeply meaningful dinner are very special, and are not available everywhere. The two main ingredients are freedom and justice for all. Freedom to be your very best, to exceed your own expectations, to worship and follow your own God, and to come and go as you please. Justice to guarantee your rights and freedoms under our constitution until proven wrong. ``So please sit down with your families and friends and enjoy this very special meal. Take a bite and savor the flavor of liberty, eat plenty and enjoy. It will be the finest meal you'll ever have. ``This is a meal that only an American can fully appreciate. Unfortunately, we are not free to enjoy the full flavor of our Thanksgiving meal while being held in Iraq, against our will.'' Signed: ``American hostages (Baghdad).''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Stolen Secrets May Have Helped China Build Neutron Bomb
DOC.TEXT: Information that helped China develop a neutron bomb was stolen from Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory through espionage, according to a published report. A lab official who spoke on the condition of anonymity told the San Jose Mercury News that espionage sometime before 1987 gave the Chinese information they needed to explode a neutron bomb on Sept. 29, 1988. The official said the information leak was a result of ``total, complete lack of management oversight.'' Details of how the information was passed remain classified. George Carver, a former deputy director of the CIA, said publicly last month that the Chinese success was based on U.S. nuclear research, the newspaper reported Wednesday. ``In 1988 ... the Chinese blossomed forth with the neutron bomb, which was made from data stolen from U.S. research centers,'' he said in a speech to Lawrence Livermore employees. ``That's what a number of people think, including my friends in the bureau (FBI),'' Carter said in a telephone interview from his office at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, D.C. Ed Appel, the head of counterintelligence in the FBI's San Francisco office, confirmed the bureau has investigated possible espionage at the lab. No arrests have been made. ``You could make the logical assumption that there have been successful espionage attempts against the lab since its inception,'' Appel said. The General Accounting Office reported in 1988 that foreign intelligence agents posing as visiting scientists had gained access to Lawrence Livermore and America's other two nuclear weapons design laboratories. The GAO said dozens of Chinese had visited Lawrence Livermore without a required background check and some were later found to have links to Chinese intelligence services. The Chinese likely lacked information on how to build parts for a neutron bomb, said John Lewis, a Chinese affairs expert at Stanford University. ``It's not a very difficult theoretical technology, it's an engineering problem,'' said Lewis, who has written a book on the Chinese nuclear weapons program. A neutron bomb is a weapon designed to kill with lethal doses of radiation without the widespread damage caused by other nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Group Lists Examples of Dangerous Toys
With PMDangerous Toys
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of 21 toys named by the private U.S. Public Interest Research Group as posing dangers to children under age three. The list is not intended to be comprehensive, the group says. Rather, it represents the types of hazards that can be posed by available toys. The list: 1. Spring N' Bounce cars. Hazard: small parts, improperly labeled. The group says the Chinese-made items were distributed by YDC of York, Pa. The company did not immediately respond to a request from The Associated Press for comment. 2. Jeep Jr. 4x4. Hazard: detachable small part (reflector); improper labeling. Messages were left at the office and answering machine of Frank Keppler, spokesman for the San Francisco-based manufacturer, Kransco. 3. Scoot Along Miss. Hazard: small parts, improper age label. Call not returned by official, Richard Nugent, vice president for operations at Empire of Carolina Inc. of Tarboro. 4. Wooden cars made by CE Ets R. Lorge of France. Hazard: small parts; labeled for 3 years or older although toy would appeal to much younger child. 5. Nashco Train Puzzle. Hazard: small parts; properly labeled though attractive to children under age 3. 6. Nashco Airplane Puzzle. Hazard: same as above. 7. Nashco Farm Puzzle. Hazard: same. The director of marketing and sales for Nashco Products Inc. of Scranton, Pa., did not return calls. The puzzles are imported from China. 8. Mickeytown Ice Cream Playset. Hazard: small part (counter top). Mattel Inc. spokesman Glenn Bozarth called the safety complaint ``speculation.'' ``They're speculating that if it were to break it would become a small part,'' he said. ``We subject all our products to testing to make sure it doesn't happen.'' He complained that the consumer group made no effort to contact the company directly with the safety concern. 9. Siamese Stuffed Cat. Hazard: small part (bell); no age labeling. Gund Inc. spokeswoman Shari Meltzer in Edison, N.J., said the product was discontinued two years ago, was never designed for small children, and had such a label the last year it was sold. 10. Unique Party Favors - 4x4 Jeeps (a package of small, brightly colored, wooden jeeps). Hazard: small parts, improperly labeled. Ray Daikeler, executive vice president of the distributor, Unique Industries of Philadelphia, was not in his office. The items are made in China. 11. Mini Mite Car Transport. Hazard: small parts; labeled for over age 3 though attractive to younger children. Made in Hong Kong. Paul Warschaw, the president of the distributor, Henry Gordy International Inc. of Plainfield, N.J., was not in his office Wednesday afternoon. 12. Toy Cowboy Hat. Hazard: small part, no age labeling. U.S. manufacturer could not be located. ``This toy cowboy hat has a cord with a plastic closure ring,'' the report says. ``The ring is easily pulled off the cord and is a small part.'' 13. Friction Powered Mini Blender and Mixer. Hazard: small parts; labeled for age 3 but with appeal to younger children. Same distributor as item No. 1. 14. Little Angel Doll. Hazard: small parts; labeled for children over 3 but with appeal to younger children. U.S. distributor of Chinese-made doll could not be found. 15. Toys'n Action Twirl'A'Way Plane. Hazard: small parts, labeled for over age 3 though having appeal to younger children. Supposed U.S. distributor could not be located. 16. Baby's First Birthday Balloons. Hazard: lack of warning of specific choking hazard from popped or uninflated balloons. Package says ``not recommended for children under 3.'' Group says ``these balloons are obviously intended for use by 1-year-olds.'' Vice President and part-owner Allan Shook of the distributor, Trisar Inc. of Anaheim, Calif., said the package that was displayed is an old one that does not reflect changes made in July to reflect that the balloons can pose a hazard for children up to age 5. He said new labels next year will tell parents to supervise the use of balloons with children up to age 6. Shook added that the balloons are distributed through party stores and card shops and never were intended to be viewed as toys. 17. Party Favors - Six Balloon Whistles. Hazard: choking; no warning label. The switchboard was closed at the alleged distributor. 18. Snoopy plush toy in tuxedo. Hazard: detachable small part (bow tie); no age labeling. 19. Baby Exerciser. Hazard: violates voluntary industry standards for labeling and strap length. Distributor Battat Inc. of Montreal was reached and copy of allegations sent by facsimile, but with no response. 20. Sesame Street Crib & Play Ten Toy with Peek-a-Boo Mirror. Hazard: no warning label, long straps. Message left with secretary at Illco Toy Co. of New York. 21. Baby Trainer. Hazard: crib gym that has no age labeling and no warning label to remove the toy when the baby playing with it can get up on his hands and knees. Straps said to be too long. No U.S. distributor listed for Dutch-made toy.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Visits To Hostages Extremely Risky, Relatives Disagree
With PM-Gulf-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The State Department contends it is ``extremely risky'' for Americans to visit hostage relatives in Iraq, but a member of a family delegation in Baghdad insists he and others were bring treated ``almost like royalty.'' In issuing the warning Wednesday, department spokesman Richard Boucher cited a close call Tuesday involving James Stevenson, an American hostage in Iraq, two of his brothers and a sister. According to Boucher's account, when the two brothers went to the Mansour Melia Hotel in Baghdad, security officials there tried to move them to the 10th floor where the detainees are held. A U.S. consular official, who was at the hotel trying to find Americans, intervened. She notified the embassy, which protested the incident. The two Americans were released. ``Had the consular officer not been there, who knows what the fate of this family might have been,'' Boucher said. ``It's incidents like these that force us to remind Americans that travel to Iraq is extremely risky. ``For those who have decided to travel, we request that they inform the State Department of their plans so we can alert our embassy in Baghdad and offer assistance as needed and as possible.'' But Stevenson's sister, Mary Trundy, reported that the group has not experienced any danger. ``They are being treated almost like royalty,'' said her husband Dennis, who spoke to Mrs. Trundy on Wednesday afternoon from Brockton, Mass. Boston television station WHDH quoted Mrs. Trundy as saying: ``We were not detained. They have treated us like a guest.'' Trundy said his wife made no mention of Tuesday's incident and he had nothing on the conditions of her brother's confinement. She planned to have Thanksgiving dinner with her brother today, he said. Trundy acknowledged he was concerned about the visit because of uncertainty as to what the Iraqis might do. ``I left the decision up to her. I didn't want to sway her one way or the other. I knew she was going,'' he said. Boucher said four families have visited relatives in Iraq and four others have indicated an intention to visit.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Emergency Hearing on Democrats' Gulf Suit
With PM-Gulf-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge plans a Dec. 4 hearing on a lawsuit by 45 House Democrats seeking to bar President Bush from ordering an attack on Iraq without congressional approval. U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene on Wednesday gave the government until Monday to file its response to the lawsuit. The judge said he would hear arguments Dec. 4 on the lawmakers' motion for a preliminary injunction in the case. The lawmakers, led by Rep. Ronald V. Dellums, D-Calif., contend in the lawsuit filed Tuesday that under the Constitution's war powers clause Congress must debate and vote on a declaration of war before American troops can be used to dislodge Iraqi forces from Kuwait. ``We're talking about a really serious situation - an emergency hearing on Dec. 4 to really determine whether the president can use the offensive option,'' said Michael Ratner, an attorney for the Center for Constitutional Rights, which represents the lawmakers. Greene, a liberal Democrat appointed by President Carter, rejected the Justice Department's motion to transfer the case to U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth, a former government attorney appointed by Reagan. Lamberth is considering a separate challenge to the president's war-making powers by Sgt. Michael R. Ange. Ange, a recently activated Army National Guard reservist, is seeking a court order that he be returned to this country. Ange lost a bid for a temporary restraining order to bar his deployment to the Middle East. But Lamberth scheduled a Dec. 10 hearing on his motion for a permanent injunction, saying the case ``poses a difficult legal question.'' In rejecting the Justice Department's transfer motion, Greene said ``the only two factors which the two actions have in common are some of the Department of Justice's apparent defenses, and the fact that there is an overlap among counsel.'' The New York City-based Center for Constitutional Rights represents both Ange and the lawmakers. The same section of the Justice Department's civil division is handling both cases.

DOC.HEAD: Milken Sobs, Then Stands Quietly at Sentencing
With PM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Moments before he was sentenced to 10 years in prison, convicted Wall Street financier Michael Milken sat in his chair crying. When U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood pronounced the sentence Wednesday, Milken stood quietly. It was the stiffest penalty delivered in cases arising from Wall Street insider-trading scandals. Milken's distress was evident from the moment he walked into the standing-room-only courtroom with his wife, Lori, on his arm. He seemed tense as he alternately fidgeted in his seat at the defense table or sat with his hands clenched in his lap. About 10 minutes into the hearing, Milken started sobbing as his lawyer, Arthur Liman, read a letter from a woman who wrote of Milken's help for her brain-damaged daughter. ``This is a man whose concerns about his friends or people in trouble always came first,'' Liman said. Milken's outburst lasted a few minutes, although he appeared to cry or be close to tears at several other points of Liman's nearly hour-long presentation. Mrs. Milken sat in the front row with family members and friends and blinked back tears as Liman described Milken as an ``extraordinary husband and father.'' Milken spoke briefly. ``I did not only violate the law but all of my values and principles. I deeply regret it and will for the rest of my life. I'm truly sorry,'' he said before slumping back in his seat. After the judge left the bench, Mrs. Milken rushed to her husband's side and hugged him. She then grabbed him by the arm and led him from the courtroom through a rear door.

As Kingfish, Reeve would pass out awards, and ``generally just get honored,'' said Carol Sherrod of the local chamber of commerce. If Reeve doesn't accept, he'll be in good company, she said. (AP) - The husband and wife team of Neal Marlens and Carol Black, who created ABC-TV's ``The Wonder Years,'' will brainstorm movies and television shows for Walt Disney Studios in an exclusive four-year deal. Reports earlier this fall estimated that Disney would pay them at least $15 million. The couple also co-produced the movie ``Soul Man'' for New World Entertainment, and wrote and produced the TV show ``Growing Pains.''

DOC.HEAD: Dismayed Friends Hope Judge Will Cut Stiff Milken Sentence
With PM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Friends of Michael Milken viewed the convicted financier's 10-year prison sentence for securities and tax fraud as unduly harsh compared to penalties imposed on other Wall street miscreants. They said they had hoped the former Drexel Burnham Lambert executive would be required only to perform community service. Now they are hoping that after Milken cooperates with investigators, as he has indicated he will do, his sentence will be reduced. ``It's like they hit me over the head with a sledgehammer. What a waste talent,'' said Richard Riordan, a prominent lawyer and philanthropist who has been an ally of Milken in many business and charitable activities. Riordan noted that U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood, who sentenced Milken in Manhattan, said she would consider reducing his punishment if he cooperates with investigators. ``And Mike will cooperate,'' Riordan said. ``He'll tell the truth.'' Riordan said he and Milken spent much of Sunday discussing charitable projects on which they have worked around the country, many for inner city children. Melba F. Coleman, a beneficiary of one of those projects, said she, too, was devastated by the news of the 10-year sentence. Milken had seemed hopeful earlier in the week that he might get only community service, she said. ``I am just devastated. I talked with him on Monday. His spirits were up,'' said Mrs. Coleman, the principal of the 102nd Street School in Watts. Milken had set up a math club for children at the school, showed up to tutor them himself, once brought along pop star Michael Jackson, and gave the children T-shirts, calculators and circus tickets. That personal involvement in the heavily minority area had won him the loyalty of Mrs. Coleman and others, who wore ``I Love Michael Milken'' buttons. ``I was optimistic he would get community service,'' Mrs. Coleman said. ``And he was optimistic too - he told me, `I hope to see you in a few weeks.''' In arguing that Milken's sentence was too severe, Riordan pointed to Ivan Boesky, the speculator in takeover stocks whose confessions to insider trading led investigators to Milken in 1986. Boesky, who served two years of a three-year term, committed more serious crimes, but ``Mike was king of the mountain, and they used Boesky to get Mike,'' Riordan said. He said that while Milken broke laws, his actions ``were not evil,'' whereas ``(Boesky) took inside information, he bribed people and he used it to make money.'' Milken's charitable contributions, particularly to minorities, are well known and were the topic of a host of pro-Milken letters written to Wood before he was sentenced. Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Richard A. Adler, for example, wrote an unsolicited letter to Wood on Milken's behalf. Adler, whose son received math lessons from Milken, noted the philanthropy began years before Milken was in trouble with the law.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Said To Postpone Discharges, Retirements and Transfers
DOC.TEXT: The Army has decided to halt retirements and discharges, as well as transfers unrelated to the Persian Gulf crisis, according to news reports. The Washington Post said in today's editions that the Army had decided to use the authority to hold personnel in the service, which was granted by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney under a little-noticed presidential order issued in August. Normally, 5 percent to 7 percent of the 760,000 soldiers in the Army would leave each month. The Post said details of the plans were being worked out, and that some exemptions would be given for hardship cases, such as family illness. The plan could keep in place most of the Army personnel who may be seeking to return to the United States from overseas bases or move from one base to another, the paper said. The Post quoted unnamed officials as interpreting the decision as move to keep officers and enlisted personnel with specific skills in place, implying that it might not be applied across-the-board. The New York Times quoted officials as saying the Army has decided to use the authority to halt about 1,500 retirements and discharges a month, but that no decision had been made by the Navy, Air Force or Marine Corps. The Times quoted Navy officials as saying they were considering using the authority to retain dentists, doctors and medical technicians. The initial report on the Pentagon decision came from CBS News. Pentagon spokesman Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner said he had no information on the subject. Meanwhile, the Army announced Wednesday that National Guard combat brigades from Georgia, Louisiana and Mississippi will be put on active duty in about a week for possible deployment to the Persian Gulf. They will be augmented by National Guard combat units from Alabama, South Carolina and Texas to create a combined fighting force of about 15,100 soldiers, the Army said. Separately, the Air Force said it was sending an unspecified number of OA-10 low-level observation aircraft to the Arabian Peninsula for Operation Desert Shield, and the Navy ordered to active duty 875 reservists from 13 states and the District of Columbia. The Air Force OA-10 planes, which are used to direct air and ground fire at enemy armored vehicles, are deploying Saturday from Davis-Monthan Air Force Base, Ariz. More than 77,000 reservists from all military services already have been called up for Desert Shield. It is the largest reserve activation since the 1961 Berlin crisis. Included in the Army statement was the first official mention that two active divisions - the 4th Infantry Division (Mechanized) of Fort Carson, Colo., and the 5th Infantry Division (Mechanized) of Fort Polk., La. - may be sent to the gulf as further reinforcements beyond the deployments already announced. The Guard brigade from Mississippi will be assigned to the 4th Infantry Division and the unit from Louisiana will be made part of the 5th Infantry Division, bringing both of those heavy units to full three-brigade strength, the Army said. The Army said the divisions, with their National Guard brigades, could be used as additions to the force now in Saudi Arabia or as rotation forces to replace units that have been there since early in the crisis sparked by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union to Pull 200,000 Troops from Asia by 1992
DOC.TEXT: Moscow plans to pull 200,000 troops out of Asia and reduce its Pacific fleet within two years, a senior Soviet official said today, challenging the United States to do the same. ``It's time to reduce the remnants of the Cold War in the Asia-Pacific region,'' said Vadim Medvedev, a close aide to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. His comments to Korean businessmen came on the heels of this week's summit in Paris, where officials formally declared the Cold War over in Europe. Medvedev, a member of the Soviet president's council of advisers, proposed that leaders in Asia meet for military consultations to speed up talks on arms control, the scaleback of forces and reduce tensions. ``We are firmly convinced that it is impossible to realize progress in the Pacific region without the essential removal of military confrontation,'' he said. ``Building on nuclear missiles has been continuing as before and naval exercises have not been reduced.'' Medvedev said that by 1992 Soviet soldiers stationed in Mongolia will be pulled out and the Soviet presence in Cam Ranh Bay, Vietnam, substantially reduced. He said the Soviet naval fleet in the Pacific will be ``drastically reduced. ``It is important for the Soviet Union and the United States to be recognized as partners by ceasing to be military adversaries in the region,'' he said. ``Despite positive developments, there have been virtually no changes in the military field.'' Medvedev said the Soviet Union supports a North Korean proposal for the withdrawal of American troops from South Korea and backs the north's demands that the divided peninsula be made into a nuclear-free zone. About 43,000 U.S. troops are stationed in South Korea to help deter communist aggression. North Korea has demanded the troops be withdrawn and nuclear weapons it claims are stored in South Korea be removed. A planned December visit to Moscow by South Korean President Roh Tae-woo is seen as a milestone in Soviet-Korean relations that may lead to reduced tensions in Korea, Medvedev said. The two nations established full diplomatic relations in September. Medvedev said Moscow wants to establish relations ``of a new quality'' with Japan and expects Gorbachev's visit to Tokyo next spring to be a turning point.

DOC.HEAD: American U. Board Rethinking $1 Million Buyout
DOC.TEXT: American University's Board of Trustees plans to hold a special meeting Dec. 6 to rethink its reported offer of a $1 million severance package to former President Richard Berendzen that has caused a campus furor. The board scheduled the meeting this week in response to protests over the proposed payout to Berendzen, who resigned last spring while under police investigation for making obscene telephone calls from his office. The trustees authorized the settlement at a closed meeting three weeks ago, on the condition that Berendzen relinquish his remaining affiliation as a tenured physics professor, The Washington Post reported today. Earlier this week, the university's acting president, Milton Greenberg, urged the board to discuss the settlement with campus groups and reconsider it in order to allay ``serious rifts'' between the trustees and the rest of the school. ``During my entire career, including more than 20 years as a senior academic administrator, never have I seen another campus-based issue evoke this degree of anguish,'' Greenberg wrote. ``Never have I seen so many speak with a single voice.'' Students, faculty members and deans have complained that the board voted to approve the settlement, which is not final, without consulting anyone on campus. They are particularly concerned that the trustees acted on a tenure question, which traditionally is the responsibility of a university's faculty. Some also contend the package is too expensive for a university with a relatively small endowment and high costs for students. Berendzen's status at AU has been ambiguous since his resignation last April. Technically, he holds a job as a physics professor, but he has not worked on campus and has not followed the necessary steps to get a sabbatical or a leave. Berendzen pleaded guilty in May to two charges of making obscene phone calls. He received two 30-day prison sentences, which were suspended on condition that he remain in outpatient psychiatric treatment. Berendzen's attorney, Richard Marks, said neither he nor his client would comment.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Man Gives Thanks After Making 2,167-Mile Appalachian Trail Hike
DOC.TEXT: Blind hiker Bill Irwin said today will be the best Thanksgiving he's ever had after becoming the first sightless man to walk the entire 2,167-mile Appalachian Trail. ``It's just an indescribable feeling of gratitude,'' Irwin said. ``I feel like I did the best I could at the time, and hopefully the Lord feels the same way.'' On Wednesday, a crowd of about 70 people fell silent as Irwin reached out and touched a sign marking the campground where he completed the eight-month trek. After the 50-year-old hiker prayed silently, the crowd broke into cheers, said David McCasland, a free-lance writer who traveled with Irwin during the final two weeks of the hike. Dozens of friends, reporters and other hikers who joined Irwin for the final 2.4-mile leg Wednesday backed away and let him walk the last tenth of a mile alone. Eighteen fellow members of the People's Memorial Christian Church in Irwin's hometown who were on hand to see their friend finish his trek sang ``Amazing Grace'' as he approached the sign marking the end of the epic hike. Irwin was given a commemorative sculpture and his guide dog Orient received a new harness and a leash. Irwin, who set out from the southern end of the trail at Springer Mountain, Ga., during September floods, arrived late Wednesday morning on a snow-covered trail at the remote Katahdin Stream campground. Along the way, the broad-shouldered Irwin's worst injury was a broken rib sustained when he slipped on a stone and his 50-pound pack swung over his head, slamming him onto a rock. In Maine, Irwin was swept off his feet while crossing the West Branch of the Piscataquis River and was carried nearly 20 yards down the icy stream, McCasland said. He also was delayed for three days in Maine by a snowstorm that left 28 inches on the ground. The sun shone brightly Wednesday. A recovering alcoholic, Irwin lost his sight nearly two years ago to a disease that destroys the retina. The Burlington, N.C., resident decided nearly a year ago to attempt the feat as an affirmation of his faith in God. Sponsors have helped pay his expenses. Irwin was with only his dog for much of the time. He couldn't see the magnificent vistas or trailside sunsets during his trek, but Irwin said the sounds and smells of the wilderness provided more than enough beauty.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Attempted In Transkei Homeland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with new details throughout, CORRECTS original coup date to 1987.
DOC.TEXT: Rebel army troops tried to seize power Thursday in the nominally independent black homeland of Transkei and clashed with loyalist forces, according to South African reports. Military ruler Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa issued a statement saying he was still in control and the coup had failed. He said the coup was headed by several whites and involved a tiny group of dissident soldiers. Holomisa identified the coup leader as a white army captain, Craig Duli, who had been a senior official in the government. He said the coup involved six whites and a handful of black troops. Holomisa and the army seized power in Transkei in 1987 and set up a government that had close ties with the African National Congress, the main black opposition group in South Africa. In recent days, he had charged that the South African government or other elements were plotting a coup against his government. South African diplomats in the homeland capital of Umtata said fighting broke out in the city around dawn Thursday when the rebels attempted to seize key government buildings. Shots had been heard and roadblocks erected, but the diplomats had no details on how serious the fighting was. ``Early this morning, there were shots that were heard in parts of Umtata,'' said South African diplomat Gert Terblanche, reached by telephone in Umtata. The independent South African Press Association said ``a large number'' of soldiers had reportedly been wounded in the fighting. It appeared fighting broke out at an army base on the outskirts of Umtata and the rebels later attempted to seize government buildings in the city, the news agency said. Transkei, with about 2.75 million people, consists of three discontiguous areas in the southeast of South Africa. It is one of four nominally independent black homelands set up by the South African government in the 1970s and 1980s as part of a plan to create separate states for blacks under the apartheid system of racial separation. No country other than South Africa recognizes the independent homelands, most of which have been pressing for reintegration into South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Junk Bond `King' Gets 10-Year Prison Term, Maybe Less if He Sings
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond ``king'' Michael Milken, credited with fueling Wall Street's corporate takeover boom of the 1980s, now personifies America's change in fortunes with his 10-year sentence for securities fraud. It was the toughest penalty imposed in cases arising from the the Wall Street scandals that followed the boom. The sentence U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood levied Wednesday could be reduced if Milken cooperates fully with prosecutors, but the stiff term undercut criticism from Milken supporters who claimed his crimes were merely technical violations. Milken had pleaded guilty to six federal felony counts and previously paid $600 million in fines and restitution. Milken, 44, stood expressionless as the judge read the sentence. His wife, Lori, was among about 200 spectators crowding the court. Lawyers, scholars and law enforcement officials agreed the term was longer than expected and concluded that Wood wanted to send a strong message that financial crime doesn't pay. ``The sentence is entirely justified in light of the severity of the crimes Milken committed, and the risks he created for the broader U.S. financial market,'' Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard Breeden said. The lengthy sentence also provides a measure of vindication for the government, which had been criticized for its zealous prosecution of Milken. They were accused of hitting Milken with an excessive 98-count indictment that included charges against his brother, Lowell, in an effort to extract a guilty plea. ``It's an indication from an impartial source that the government was right in bringing this case and prosecuting it as hard as it did, and in bringing him to justice,'' said Bruce Baird, who was head of securities fraud in the Manhattan U.S. Attorney's Office during the early stages of the Milken prosecution. ``It's stiffer than I would have guessed but every day of it richly deserved,'' he said. Milken is the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier whose pioneering use of high-yield junk bonds raised billions of dollars in capital, much of it used to finance the hostile corporate takeovers that characterized an era. He faced a maximum 28 years in prison. He already has agreed to pay $200 million in fines and place $400 million in a fund to compensate investors. Milken was ordered to report to federal custody on March 4, 1991. He will be eligible for parole after serving at least one-third of his term, meaning he could not be released until 1994. A prison was not designated. Milken also must perform 1,800 hours of community service during each of three years' probation. That equals nearly 35 hours a week. Wood said she would consider reducing the prison term if the government made such a request based on Milken's future cooperation, which is required under the plea agreement. The government has said it is continuing its investigation into lawbreaking on Wall Street, including transactions involving Milken and Drexel. Linked to scandal by former speculator Ivan Boesky in late 1986, Milken had steadfastly denied any wrongdoing and pledged to fight his March 1989 indictment. He changed his mind in April after months of negotiations. At sentencing, Wood indicated that his initial refusal to cooperate worked against him. ``Milken rode to the top in success in financial wealth and now he's hit the bottom,'' said attorney Arthur Mathews, whose client Paul Bilzerian received a four-year term, until Wednesday the longest such penalty in the Wall Street trading scandals. Defense attorney Arthur Liman asked the judge for community service only, saying Milken's crimes were ``deviations from an otherwise admirable life.'' Liman cited Milken's $360 million in charitable contributions beginning before the federal investigation, and other endeavors. ``I'm not a psychologist. I can't offer your honor an explanation as to how Michael slipped,'' Liman said. ``I can just attest to those values that come out constantly.'' But Wood said Milken's crimes were not merely technical violations brought on by Milken's overzealous desire to help clients, as the defense maintained. She said Milken obstructed the government's investigation and balked at early efforts to win his cooperation. Milken pleaded guilty to conspiracy, securities and mail fraud, violating federal securities reporting requirements, filing false information with regulators and aiding the filing of a false tax return.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Lax In Overseeing Nuclear Weapons Security, Report Says
DOC.TEXT:
Congressional investigators say the Energy Department failed to take prompt action after inspections showed some guards at nuclear weapons facilities could not shoot straight and did not know how to handcuff intruders. The General Accounting Office, an investigating arm of Congress, said Wednesday that some shortcomings uncovered in 1985 inspections at the department's Los Alamos, Argonne, Sandia and Savannah River sites went uncorrected for five years. The GAO report was requested by the House energy subcommittee on oversight and investigation and by Sens. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., and Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., after a 10-week strike by the contract security force at the Los Alamos National Laboratory last year. The congressional investigators said many guards hired as replacements during the strike did not have the required skills. They also said an unannounced exercise conducted in April showed that 75 percent of the regular security force failed at one or more of the skills required. ``For example, when the participants encountered an adversarial situation, many failed to stay behind cover and assess the situation,'' the report said. ``Instead, they left their cover and walked up to the potential adversaries to ask what they were doing.'' Consequently, it said, many of the adversaries were able to take out a visible weapon, theoretically kill the guard and make off with classified documents. It said 24 participants and hostages were ``killed'' during the test. The Energy Department referred inquiries about the report to Los Alamos, where Anna Bachicha, a public affairs officer, said the ``report was just released today and we just received a copy of it this afternoon and have not had time to fully assess it.''
---
DOC.HEAD: Study Says Deposit Law Would Help Environment
DOC.TEXT:
A new government report says imposing a deposit on beverage cans and bottles would reduce pollution and conserve energy. The study released Wednesday by the General Accounting Office, the congressional investigative agency, improves prospects for passing deposit legislation next year, said Rep. Paul Henry, R-Mich. ``It addresses all of the industry concerns,'' said Henry, who this year unsuccessfully sponsored a bill to charge a five-cent refundable deposit on soft-drink, beer and mineral water containers. Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., pushed similar legislation. ``There is no correlation between a bottle bill and a dropoff in beverage consumption,'' Henry said. ``There is no direct tie between loss of container manufacturing jobs and a bottle bill.'' William L. Ball III, president of the National Soft Drink Association, said a national deposit law ``would be an unwanted albatross around the neck of those who are serious about recycling and the environment.''
