DOC.HEAD: Nearly Quarter Million Texans, New Mexicans Live In Colonias
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a quarter million people in Texas and New Mexico live in impoverished communities along the border that lack sewer systems or adequate water supplies, congressional investigators say. A General Accounting Office study of six Texas counties along the Rio Grande found 198,000 people are living in 842 colonias - unincorporated, rural subdivisions with frequently substandard housing, inadequate roads, a lack of running water or adequate sewage systems. Sixty percent of the colonias surveyed have water supplies but less than 1 percent - or a total of three - have a public sewage disposal system, said GAO, the investigative arm of Congress. ``I'm very concerned that the lack of proper waste systems for these colonias poses a growing health risk to residents and their children. It's also contributing to environmental problems along the border,'' said Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, who requested the study. De la Garza, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, released the study Wednesday and said it ``substantiates the need to continue and strengthen our efforts to bring adequate water and sewer facilities to the hundreds of thousands of colonia residents along the Texas-Mexico border.''

DOC.HEAD: Medflies Found In California After Infestation Declared Over
DOC.TEXT: Two Medflies were found in California just two weeks after the state said it had wiped out an infestation that lasted nearly 16 months and cost $52 million to fight, agriculture officials announced. ``This is a revolting development,'' E. Leon Spaugy, Los Angeles County agricultural commissioner, said Wednesday. ``I had hoped we could get through winter without finding any.'' Spaugy said the latest outbreak could have been caused by residents bringing illegal fruit from outside the country. The unmated female Mediterranean fruit flies were trapped in residential neighborhoods in Upland and nearby Rancho Cucamonga on Nov. 15. Fly trapping will intensify around the sites where the two were found, said Don Schreiber, San Bernardino County deputy agricultural commissioner. Two weeks ago, officials declared victory in a nearly 16-month, $52 million battle against the crop-destroying pest. ``There's no question in my mind now that they never eradicated them from this area,'' said Richard Rice, a University of California, Davis entomologist. ``We had better stay pretty light on our feet.'' Rice said it took a week for authorities to identify the flies as wild and that delay is unacceptable because the Medfly reproduces so quickly. ``That's a serious flaw in their strategy right there,'' he said. ``It's just unforgivable. You can't give Medflies that window of opportunity.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drops Again, Stocks Rebound
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the yen Thursday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded. The yen closed at 127.13 yen, down 0.55 yen from Wednesday's finish of 127.68 yen. After opening at 126.93 yen, the currency ranged between 126.70 yen and 127.14 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 583.29 points, or 2.56 percent, closing at 23,400.28. The index shed 388.49 points Wednesday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 85.94, up from Wednesday's close of 85.56. Their yield fell to 7.500 percent from 7.585 percent. Many economists expect the U.S. Federal Reserve Board will move to lower interest rates further soon. Lower interest rates tend to make a nation's currency less attractive to investors. Yuichi Sugiura, a dealer at Sanwa Bank, said the dollar was also weakened by easing tensions in the Middle East. Though market players still feel uncertain about the Persian Gulf crisis, ``they lean more to the view there will be a peaceful settlement,'' Sugiura said. On the stock market, the Nikkei index started higher on small-lot buying in a favorable reaction to the yen's appreciation against the dollar as well as higher bond prices, securities dealers said. ``Share prices are rising in a broad front,'' said a dealer at Nikko Securities Co. who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Sculptor Creating Down-to-Earth Lincoln for Gettysburg Memorial
LaserPhoto HX1
DOC.TEXT: J. Seward Johnson, whose statues are so lifelike a security guard once shot one, envisions a down-to-earth rendering of Abraham Lincoln for the town where the 16th president delivered his most famous speech. Johnson's Lincoln will be near the town square, but on the sidewalk instead of a pedestal - and aside a likeness of a 20th century tourist. The tourist, dressed in slacks and a cable-knit sweater, holds a copy of the Gettysburg Address as he listens to the president. The artist, who lives near Princeton, N.J., has been commissioned to create the statue for this rural Pennsylvania town where Lincoln delivered the famed Civil War speech 127 years ago. Johnson, perched on an antique chair in the office of Civil War scholar Gabor Boritt, said the statute is designed ``to celebrate Lincoln's humanity, bring him off a pedestal, celebrate the greatness of him as a human being.'' Another purpose is ``to show that the Gettysburg Address was still a meaningful document today.'' The 268-word address, whose opening, ``Four score and seven years ago,'' is familiar to millions, is regarded by scholars as one of the most forceful and elegant speeches ever made. Lincoln delivered the address at a dedication of the national military cemetery in Gettysburg on Nov. 19, 1863. In Johnson's artwork, Lincoln is saying something to the tourist as he points to the nearby Wills House, where he stayed the night before the speech. ``He might have been saying how uncomfortable the bed was,'' Johnson said with a laugh as he flexed his long, thick fingers. ``Whatever it is, the fellow is a little bit in awe of him.'' Johnson hopes to have the artwork completed in time for next November's annual Gettysburg celebration. A model has been on display around town for several weeks, and the reception has been positive, Johnson said. He resisted suggestions that he replace the tourist's sweater with a jacket, but agreed to some minor changes. ``On something like this, I feel an artist has to be very sensitive to the people who have to live with it,'' he said. He was commissioned for the work by the Lincoln Fellowship of Pennsylvania, which sponsors the annual ceremony marking the speech. The group has sought a statue honoring Lincoln for nearly 50 years. ``The hope has been here for a long, long time and finally we are doing it,'' said Boritt, a professor of history at Gettysburg College. He said the Lincoln Fellowship is trying to raise $100,000 to pay for the statue and provide a maintenance fund. ``We are willing to accept a dollar and we will accept $10,000,'' Boritt said. The figures will be cast in bronze, but they will wear real clothes coated with a plastic-like resin. Johnson's lifelike sculptures are displayed in 26 states, the District of Columbia and several foreign countries. He tells countless tales of drivers who try to pick up an umbrella-toting statue in the classic cab-hailing pose or of people who try to strike up conversations with figures on a park bench. But one of his favorite stories involves the statue that was shot by a security guard answering a silent alarm at a house in Los Angeles. No intruder was found. ``It frightened the guard so much that he shot the sculpture,'' Johnson said. ``The more you can fool them, the better it is.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Copter Accidentally Blows Up Own Ammo Dump
DOC.TEXT: The crew of a U.S. Army Apache helicopter accidentally fired a Hellfire anti-tank missile and blew up an Air Force ammunition dump, the U.S. Central Command reported early Thursday. The pilots of the 1st Battalion of the 101st Aviation Regiment were carrying out a weapons system check on the ground Wednesday when the missile was accidentally launched, the military said. No casualties were reported in the fire at the ammunition dump and the military said damage at the airbase was minimal. In another incident, a Saudi Arabian was killed and another seriously injured in a collision between a U.S. military truck and a civilian car in Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province on Wednesday, the military said. No Americans were reported hurt and the Army and Saudi officials are investigating the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Surviving Girl Copes With AIDS Deaths of Mother and Sister; Father's Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Five-year-old Nicolette Folsom sat in the grass by the graves of her parents and baby sister in the hillside cemetery near her home and showed off an awards certificate she won at school. She spoke quietly, holding the certificate skyward. ``I brought this home and we put it on the refrigerator. But I wanted you to see it,'' she said. ``I'm doing real good in school and I'm happy in school.'' June Kenney, Nicolette's grandmother and legal guardian, recounted the scene Wednesday. Thanksgiving, the first holiday since AIDS and suicide claimed all but one member of the Folsom family, will be difficult, she said. Nicolette's mother, 29-year-old Jennifer, and her 3-year-old sister, Angela, died of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome earlier this fall. Her father, Doug, fatally shot himself in June after watching his family struggle for two years with the killer virus. Jennifer said this summer she believed she contracted the disease through a blood transfusion during an emergency appendectomy in a Massachusetts hospital in 1979, before blood supplies were tested for the AIDS virus. Angie, she said, contracted the virus during the pregnancy or later from breast feeding. Nicolette has routinely tested negative for the virus. She will be tested again in five years, Mrs. Kenney said. ``Her concept is they all have gone to some other place ... that Doug is fishing, her mother is knitting, and Angie is playing,'' she said. ``That's her concept of heaven. She thinks they'll all be together. Nicolette sees an art therapist weekly to help her cope with the loss. ``We try to tell her that everybody doesn't die young,'' her grandmother said. Mrs. Kenney said Nicolette has ``little worry people and little worry stones'' that she talks to at night. ``She talks to her mother ... once in a while she does get emotional,'' she said. ``Everybody is still trying to get through it. It's not over yet, for sure,'' said Fred Kenney, Jennifer's brother. ``Each person handles it differently. For some of us, it's been a tough time because we haven't had time to mourn yet. Now we have time to sit back and reflect,'' he said. For June and Don Kenney, the tragedy has been extra difficult. They have once again assumed the role of parents to a young child. Mrs. Kenney has also begun speaking to community organizations and support groups for the families of AIDS victims. She also is using notes kept by Jennifer over the course of her illness to write a childrens' book on coping with the death of a parent from AIDS. The family is also sending out about 600 cards of thanks to people across the country who sent messages of support, as well as gifts and money, after Jennifer spoke publicly of her family's struggle. Jennifer said at that time that she wanted people to know that AIDS is not only a big-city problem. ``Vermont does have AIDS. The children of this generation need to be taught now because we don't know if there is going to be a cure,'' she said. ``One of the things we're thankful for is the fact that she didn't die fruitlessly,'' Mrs. Kenney said Wednesday. ``But we all have our moments, each and every one of us. There are times when the sky is blue and sunny, and we think of things we used to do with Jenny, and she's not there.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Questions Finding that Rival Heart Attack Drugs are Equal
DOC.TEXT: The surprise finding earlier this year that a $76 heart attack drug is just as good as one costing 29 times more has been called into question by new research released today. The latest report bolsters the widespread skepticism among U.S. physicians that greeted the release of a major Italian study finding that the two clot-dissolving medicines are equally effective. Both drugs are intended to break up clots that plug that hearts' arteries during heart attacks. If these clots are removed within four hours or so, victims may escape permanent damage to their hearts. The chief rivals for this lucrative market are TPA, which costs $2,200 per treatment, and streptokinase, which costs $76. Early U.S. studies suggested that TPA worked better, and the medicine quickly gained about two-thirds of the U.S. market share. ``The real issue around the world is whether streptokinase is comparable to TPA,'' said Dr. Judith Hsia, principal author of the latest report. ``It's much cheaper, and many countries, including the United States, would prefer to give it if it is just as good.'' Some thought that issue was settled last March when an Italian study of 12,490 men found that the two drugs ``appear equally effective and safe for use in routine conditions of care.'' It found that about 23 percent of patients died or suffered serious heart damage, no matter which medicine they received. However, that study made little use of a blood thinner called heparin, which is routinely given with TPA by U.S. doctors. The new study shows that heparin is essential for TPA to work properly. The latest study, called the Heparin-Aspirin Reperfusion Trial, or HART, was directd by Dr. Allan M. Ross of George Washington University and published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. ``If you use TPA in a fashion that doesn't allow those opened arteries to stay open, then the gain will presumably be lost. That's the implication of HART,'' said Ross. Dr. Lawrence Cohen of Yale University agreed that the latest work casts doubt on the Italian team's conclusion. ``I think there is a distinct possibility that the survival rate might have been better in the TPA group had adjuvant therapy (heparin) been given in an optimal fashion,'' Cohen said. A new study called GUSTO - for global utilization of streptokinase and TPA - recently began on 33,000 people to settle whether TPA and heparin together save more lives than streptokinase. Answers to these questions are important financially as well as medically, since the market for clot-dissolving drugs is huge. An estimated 1.5 million Americans suffer heart attacks each year. TPA is a genetically engineered human protein that is made by Genentech. Streptokinase, produced from bacteria, is made by Hoechst AG of Germany. A new entrant in the field is the genetically engineered Eminase, which is made by SmithKline Beecham and costs $1,700. TPA acts quickly in the blood stream to break up clots, but the medicine almost immediately disappears when it is withdrawn. Streptokinase works more slowly but continues to linger in the body for hours after the treatment. In the latest study, researchers randomly assigned 205 heart attack victims to receive TPA either with or without heparin. Eighteen hours later, the once-clogged arteries were flowing freely in 82 percent of those who got heparin and in 52 percent of those who did not. This suggests that without heparin, new clots frequently formed again in their arteries.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Back in Hangar, Little Damage Found
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Atlantis sustained hardly any damage during a secret Pentagon mission that began with an unusual nighttime launch and ended with a rare Florida touchdown. ``It's probably one of the cleanest birds I've ever seen come back after a mission,'' James Harrington, NASA's director of shuttle operations, said Wednesday. Atlantis and its five astronauts landed Tuesday at Kennedy Space Center after five days in space. The shuttle was diverted to Florida because of bad weather at the main touchdown site in California. As of Wednesday afternoon, Atlantis' brakes had not been removed for inspection but were thought to be in good shape, Harrington said. The only wheel damage was scuffed rims. During the Pentagon mission, which had to be extended a day because of bad weather for landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., the crew deployed a spy satellite. Sources said the satellite will eavesdrop on Iraqi communications in the Persian Gulf. It was the sixth shuttle landing at Kennedy and the first in five years. Discovery, the last spaceship to land in Florida, blew a tire and sustained brake damage in 1985. Only three of the 28,000 heat-resistant tiles covering the shuttle will need to be replaced, Harrington said. The three tiles have ``good-sized nicks,'' he said. Usually the shuttle's tail surface is peppered with dirt kicked up from the natural runways at Edwards, Harrington said. ``We had a good, clean mission, a good, clean landing and very little tile damage overall,'' Harrington said. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration will save about $1 million and a week in processing time because Atlantis landed at Kennedy and thus avoided a cross-country trip. Atlantis' next scheduled flight is in April. The Florida landing was especially gratifying for Kennedy workers, who had been frustrated for months by hydrogen leaks that grounded Atlantis and Columbia. ``You could light up a Christmas tree with all the smiles on the troops around here,'' Harrington said. Next up is Columbia, which is expected to lift off around Dec. 2 with an astronomical observatory. NASA officials are expected to set a launch date after a review Tuesday. The mission has been on hold since hydrogen leaks grounded the shuttle in May.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Statue Piece on Display in New York Was Stolen in Turkey
DOC.TEXT: An ancient statue fragment on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was stolen and smuggled out of Turkey, according to published reports. The other half is in a museum at Antalya, near Perga, Turkey, where the statue was excavated in pieces in 1980, according to a New York Times report today based on an article in the December edition of the magazine Connoisseur. The marble piece is thought to be the top half of a statue of the mythical hero Hercules. The Turkish government has hired the New York law firm of Herrick, Feinstein to investigate allegations it was stolen, the Times said. Cornelius C. Vermeule III, curator of classical art at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, told the Times the work was one of many copies of a bronze original identified with the sculptor Lysippos of Sicyon, and likely made around 330 B.C. It was bought from a western European dealer ``with all the proper papers and credentials,'' Vermeule said. He said relicas of the Lysippos sculpture were ``in every shrine, bath, gymnasium from Gaul to Mesopotamia.'' The fragment is owned jointly by the Boston museum and collectors Leon Levy and Shelby White.

DOC.HEAD: Remains of Polish Pianist, Statesman to Return Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Paderewski pronounced pod-uh-REF-skee.
DOC.TEXT: In another signal that the Cold War is over, the remains of Polish pianist, composer and statesman Ignace Jan Paderewski are to be returned to his homeland nearly 50 years after his death. The remains will be honored with a state burial in Poland, The New York Times reported today. Paderewski, who died in 1941 at age 80, declared in his will that although his heart was to remain permanently in the United States, his body should be returned to his native Poland - but not until the nation was free and independent. The transfer of his remains has been authorized by the Polish government and is expected to be approved by the U.S. government, according to the report. Paderewski, a world-renowned pianist, held the posts of prime minister and minister of foreign affairs in a post-World War I coalition Polish government. At the time of his death, when Poland was occupied by Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union, Paderewski was president of the Polish Parliament in Exile. When he died, President Franklin D. Roosevelt authorized the placement of his remains in a crypt on the battleship Maine memorial at the Arlington National Cemetery ``until such time as Poland is again free.'' His heart was placed in a crypt in the Cypress Hills Cemetery in Brooklyn. In 1986, it was moved by the Paderewski Memorial Committee to a bronze crypt in the National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa, in Doylestown, Pa.

DOC.HEAD: Growth Boom Brings Big-City Problems to Once-Quiet California Town
By NOEL K. WILSON
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Californians seeking cheap housing have helped turn this once-quiet far town into one of the nation's fastest-growing cities, but growth has brought big-city problems like crime, drugs and crowded schools. ``Fresno, unfortunately, is growing up,'' said nurse Tom Stoeckel at Valley Medical Center, which has treated cocaine-addicted babies in its obstetrics ward and where one or two gunshot victims routinely arrive each day. ``Fresno is developing a Los-Angeles type situation - we now have drive-by shootings,'' Stoeckel said. The city of more than 350,000 also has crowded schools, street gangs and an inversion layer that makes it one of the worst smog basins in the nation. But city officials say the growth didn't catch them by surprise and, with an abundance of open land remaining, they don't expect it to ebb anytime soon. ``We were forecasting this kind of growth in 1981 and 1982,'' said Al Solis, the city's development director. In 1980, Fresno had 218,202 residents. Preliminary 1990 census figures increased the total to 350,794 - a 61 percent growth rate that boosted Fresno from the nation's 65th-largest city to 47th. It also made Fresno the fastest-growing of the nation's 50 largest cities. Officials say growth was spurred by cheap housing, an aggressive annexation program that vastly expanded the central California city's borders and an influx of Asian immigrants. An average Fresno home costs about $100,000, compared to $250,000 in San Francisco to the north or Los Angeles to the south. Among those who flocked to the area in search of cheap housing were thousands of Southeast Asian refugees, mostly Hmong. In 1979, officials say, there were about 30 Hmong in Fresno, compared to about 48,000 today. As the growth boom took place, Fresno rapidly expanded its borders, annexing 21,951 acres of adjacent county land, a move that brought 38,000 former county residents into the city. Highlighting the problems was a Labor Day rampage in which one person was killed and eight wounded. Police say four teen-agers associated with one of about 20 active street gangs went on a four-hour shooting and robbery spree, attacking people at random. Growth has also caused crowding in some schools, and school officials have switched many campuses to year-round programs to accomodate added students. Solis said environmental problems, including water shortages, could eventually slow Fresno's population boom. Several wells drilled in north Fresno produced water polluted by years of agricultural pesticide use, he said. Officials say the city's location in central California's San Joaquin Valley, with its natural inversion layer, also gives it the potential for serious smog problems. But despite the problems, Solis predicted growth will continue for several years to come. ``We don't have the limitations that other cities in California have,'' he said. ``As long as the demand is there, and the supply, we'll grow.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up Sharply, Dollar Falls A Fourth Day
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded sharply in relatively thin trading today, while the dollar fell against the yen for the fourth consecutive day. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which had lost 388.49 points Wednesday, gained 583.29 points, or 2.56 percent, closing at 23,400.28. A total of 360 million shares were traded on the first section, up from 260 million shares Wednesday. Japan's markets will be closed Friday, the nation's Labor Thangsgiving holiday. Securities dealers said the index was pushed up by brisk index-linked buying and arbitrage buying, in which investors seek to profit from price gaps between the spot and futures markets. The declining trend of Japanese interest rates was encouraging investors, they said. ``Long-term interest rates already have shown a downward trend and short-term ones seem likely to follow suit,'' said an analyst with Nomura Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. Higher interest rates tend to support a currency but discourage stock investment. The dollar closed at 127.13 yen, down 0.55 yen from Wednesday's finish of 127.68 yen. It opened at 126.93 yen and ranged between 126.70 yen and 127.14 yen. The dollar has fallen 2.60 yen in four days. Some $9.95 billion changed hands in today's spot trading, down from $15.28 billion Wednesday. Shigeto Yanase, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, said expectations of further declines in U.S. interest rates helped push the dollar lower. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 86.11 as of 4 p.m. (2 a.m. EST) from the previous day's 85.56-point finish. Their yield fell to 7.464 percent from 7.585 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Precede PALMER
Moderate Earthquakes Hit Alaska
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with two quakes striking Anchorage area, revises magnitude of latest Aleutian quake and CLARIFIES time as Anchorage time. Drops `BRF' designator in slugline. EDITS to tighten. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Quakes measuring...
DOC.TEXT: Two earthquakes about an hour apart rattled the Anchorage area shortly after another quake hit the Aleutian Island area more than 1,000 miles away. There were no reports of injuries or damage. The first of the Anchorage quakes, measuring 3.4 on the Richter scale, struck at 9:16 p.m. local time. It was centered about 20 miles north of the city, said scientists at the National Earthquake Information Center at Golden, Colo. The second quake, measuring 4.1, hit at 10:19 p.m. and was centered about 40 miles southwest of Anchorage, authorities said. A magnitude 5.3 quake struck the tip of the Aleutian Islands, about 1,100 miles to the southwest, at 8:14 p.m. Anchorage time, officials said. The quake was felt by people at the Adak Naval Station about 50 miles away. A 5.6-magnitude temblor also struck the central Aleutians Tuesday afternoon. Seismologists said they didn't know if any of the quakes were related. Quakes measuring above 5 on the Richter scale are capable of causing significant damage if they hit heavily populated areas. The 1964 Alaska quake that killed more than 100 people measured 8.4 on the Richter scale, while the San Francisco quake of 1906 was estimated to register 8.3. The October 1989 quake that hit Northern California measured 7.1.

DOC.HEAD: Humpback Whale Explores New Jersey River
DOC.TEXT: It looks like a deep-sea Thanksgiving is in store for a humpback whale after it spent the past few days exploring New Jersey's polluted waterways. The 30-foot to 35-foot-long whale, which was spotted in the Hackensack River and Newark Bay, was escorted through New York Harbor Wednesday and out into the open ocean by New Jersey State Police boats, with the help of a marine mammal expert. The same whale has been spotted in rivers around New Jersey before, said Bob Schoelkopf, director of the Marine Mammal Stranding Center, which is based in Brigantine, N.J. ``We immediately recognized it as a humpback whale that was originally spotted in New Jersey two years ago,'' Schoelkopf said. He said it appeared in the Delaware River two years ago and last year in both the Shark River and the Raritan River. ``So it does know its way around and for some reason prefers to come in and then head out again,'' Schoelkopf said. He said he recognized the animal by a distinctive notch in its dorsal fin. Humpback whales are common in the Atlantic Ocean off the northeastern United States, he said. Workers at a Public Service Electric & Gas Co. plant were the first to see the whale on its latest visit, as it swam past the generating station late Tuesday afternoon. The whale was swimming up river ``as though it wanted to look and see what was going on, and when the tide switched it switched direction,'' Schoelkopf said. ``We essentially herded it by staying behind it and on either side so it would only go in one direction,'' Schoelkopf said, adding that the whale might come back. ``This may not be the end of the story. He may end up taking a turn and going somewhere else,'' he said. ``It's hard to predict these animals.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix category code, DELETE Bjt designator, add attribution in lead
Lyme Disease May Cause Lasting Nerve Damage
DOC.TEXT: Years after the tick bite that triggers Lyme disease, people with lingering infections may suffer memory loss, shooting pains and other signs of nerve damage, the doctor who discovered the disease reported today. Antibiotics usually relieve the lingering symptoms, although recovery is seldom complete. ``This is similar to syphilis,'' said Dr. Allen C. Steere. ``Although the neurological symptoms and consequences are different, in both diseases there are long periods of latent infection in the brain followed by a variety of neurological disorders.'' Lyme disease is a bacterial infection transmitted by tiny ticks that are usually carried by deer and mice. It is common throughout the Northeast, Midwest and California. Usually the first sign of Lyme disease is a red circular rash around the tick bite. It is often accompanied by fever, fatigue, aches and other flu-like miseries. In more advanced stages, the disease can cause arthritis as well as the neurological problems. Steere, who first recognized the disease in Old Lyme, Conn. about 15 years ago, was senior author of the latest report, written with two colleagues at New England Medical Center in Boston. It was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. The doctors studied 27 patients with chronic neurological symptoms that typically began a year or two after the start of their infections. All but three of them had signs of mild brain disease, or encephalopathy. These included memory problems, such as forgetting names, missing appointments and misplacing objects. Others felt very sleepy during the day or were troubled by extreme irritability, growing angry over what would ordinarily be minor annoyances. Some also showed subtle language difficulties and trouble finding words. Most were able to keep working, but three quit their jobs, three cut back their hours and two retired early. The other major category of disorder was polyneuropathy, a disorder of the nerves outside the brain. People often had back aches with shooting pains, tingling sensations and lack of feeling in their hands and feet. The researchers found that a two-week course of antibiotic injections significantly improved the way the patients felt. But six months later, more than one-third had either relapsed or were no better. The doctors speculated that the treatment failed because it did not wipe out the bacteria completely or because the patients' nervous systems were irreversibly damaged.

DOC.HEAD: State: Hmong Relief Agency Allegedly Extorted Donations
DOC.TEXT: A private agency founded by a general who led a CIA-backed anti-communist army in Laos during the Vietnam War has been extorting money from Laotian refugees to keep up the resistance, a state agency charges. State social services officials say Lao Family Community coerced contributions from ethnic Hmong refugees on behalf of the United Lao National Liberation Front, also known as the Neo Hom. Lao Family Community funnels government aid to many of the approximately 100,000 Hmong who live in California, and also provides English classes, job training programs and counseling to Hmong residents. Some people who refused to pay were threatened with violence and some refugee families who refused to deal with the Lao Family Community lost thousands of dollars in welfare benefits, said Alicia Martinez, director of the state Department of Social Services' Civil Rights Bureau. Martinez said her own life has been threatened since her agency began its investigation 18 months ago. The two groups were founded by former Lao Army Gen. Vang Pao, a Hmong who led a CIA-backed insurgency after the communist Pathet Lao gained control of the country. Vang Pao and other officials from the Neo Hom and Lao Family deny any wrongdoing. ``Yes, there are some people working in Lao Family who have been donating money for the front, but I think that is within their right,'' said Lao Family Director Gayle Morrison. The Civil Rights Bureau has recommended that public agencies suspend Lao Family's contracts, worth about $5 million in fiscal 1989. As a result of the Civil Rights Bureau report, the six counties that deal with Lao Family have suspended contracts pending a review, Martinez said. The state attorney general's office is also investigating the groups, but no criminal charges have been filed, said Deputy Attorney General James Dutton. The Neo Hom, with 9,000 to 10,000 members in the United States, is the largest of several Lao resistance groups. From its Santa Ana headquarters, about 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles, it has legally solicited money for years to finance a guerrilla war against Laos' communist government. A reclusive hill people from northern Laos, many Hmongs had little contact with the outside world before joining a U.S.-supported campaign against communist insurgents in the early 1970s. When Laos' pro-U.S. government fell, thousands of Hmongs fled to the United States. About a dozen families told investigators Lao Family officials threatened that they would not receive benefits unless they contributed to the Neo Hom, Martinez said. Figures on how much money was allegedly extorted were not immediately available, but victims were reportedly ordered to make initial contributions of up to $100 each and then pay monthly amounts of as much as $5. Officials learned of the alleged extorition from two people who refused to deal with Lao Family. Song Moua, spokesman for the National Liberation Front, said the group has not tried to extort money. All donations go to resistance fighters and refugees still in Asia, he said. Martinez said she believed many Hmong gave in to the alleged extortion demands because they became used to corruption in their homeland. ``I think a lot of people took it as part of the system,'' she said. ``They experienced it there and they were experiencing it here.''

DOC.HEAD: Text of Statement from Mrs. Thatcher's Office
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the statement released Thursday by the office of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher: ``The prime minister, the Right Honorable Margaret Thatcher, has informed the queen that she does not intend to contest the second ballot of the election for leadership of the Conservative Party and intends to resign as prime minister as soon as a new leader of the Conservative Party has been elected. The prime minister will seek an audience of the queen later this morning to convey her decision formally. ``The prime minister has released the following statement: `Having consulted widely among my colleagues I have concluded that the unity of the party and the prospect of victory in a general election would be better served if I stood down to enable Cabinet colleagues to enter the ballot for the leadership. I should like to thank all those in Cabinet and outside who have given me such dedicated support.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Precede JIDDAH.
Baker Heads to Yemen to Seek Support on Gulf Moves
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 6 grafs new to UPDATE with Baker arriving in Yemen. San`a is cq in dateline.
DOC.TEXT: SAN`A, Yemen (AP) - Secretary of State James A. Baker III arrived in Yemen today to seek its support for a United Nations resolution authorizing military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. Baker has traveled the globe in recent weeks on an intense lobbying effort to obtain the approval of the 15 U.N. Security Council nations for such a resolution. The United States holds the rotating presidency of the council until the end of this month and had initially wanted to propose the resolution before it ceded the chair to Yemen in December. ``If this is going to happen,'' Baker said Wednesday, ``that is a process that must begin at some time. This is the 22nd of November, and November has 30 days.'' Baker was to present the U.S. case to the country's president, Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh, and Foreign Minister Abdul-Karim al-Iryani. Yemen's government has publicly sided with Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. The secretary of state, who had accompanied President Bush to Saudi Arabia, split off from the president's Thanksgiving visit to military forces in the Saudi desert. He is the first high-ranking U.S. official to visit to the Red Sea state since Bush stopped here in 1986 as vice president. Bush met Wednesday in Jiddah with the exiled emir of Kuwait, Jabber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. The president said afterward that fresh steps should be taken this month in the United Nations to free Kuwait. Yemen, located on the southwest corner of the Arabian peninsula, is the only Arab nation on the Security Council. It has in the past shown some sympathy toward Iraq and has criticized the military buildup of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein sent his foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, to Yemen on Tuesday to deliver a message on the gulf situation, according to the official Yemeni news agency. Officials said Baker would return to Jiddah tonight and might meet Friday with Malaysian officials. Malaysia, located on the southeastern tip of Asia, also is a member of the Security Council. Since last weekend, Baker has met with the foreign ministers of eight nations on the council. Next weekend, he pays a visit to Colombia where he will confer with President Cesar Gaviria. Baker said Wednesday the United States and the Soviet Union had ``unanimity of opinion with regard to the problems in the gulf.'' Baker held lengthy meetings with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Paris this week during the 34-nation summit of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Shevardnadze had said in Paris that the Security Council should ``take stock of things'' and, if need be, adopt new resolutions. However, neither he nor Gorbachev endorsed the idea of a resolution to authorize use of force. The Security Council has approved 10 resolutions against Iraq since its Aug. 2 invasion of its oil-rich neighbor. They impose an economic boycott on Iraq and occupied Kuwait, call for Iraq's unconditional withdrawal and insist upon restoration of Kuwait's previous government. Yemen has abstained from voting on half of those, according to a State Department count. None of the resolutions authorizes military action, but they leave the door open to other measures if Iraq fails to respond to the steps.

DOC.HEAD: An Iron Lady Who Transformed Britain
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Thatcher has been every bit the Iron Lady - durable, rigid, formidable in battle. Since taking power in 1979 as Britain's first woman prime minister, Mrs. Thatcher has often been unpopular, often a minority - in Britain's alliances, and even in her own Cabinet - and never in doubt. But on Thursday she announced her resignation amid a strong leadership challenge from her former defense minister, Michael Heseltine. Only Winston Churchill rivaled Mrs. Thatcher's commanding profile in 20th century Britain, and no one approached her record of three straight general election victories. In 1980, when others shirked from the radical free-market cures of Thatcherism, Mrs. Thatcher scolded her fellow Conservatives: ``You turn if you want to; the lady's not for turning.'' She dismantled Britain's version of socialism, crushed obstructive labor unions, led a military victory against Argentina in the Falkland Islands and preached military readiness to the Western alliance. Asked what she had changed in her country, her answer was simple: ``Everything.'' ``We have raised Britain in the respect of the world from what it was - broke, bankrupt, unwilling to defend itself properly,'' she said in 1987. ``We have, I think, transformed Britain.'' In the 1980s then-President Ronald Reagan was her friend and ideological soulmate, but she was one of the first Western leaders to recognize Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as ``someone we can do business with.'' Even before she became prime minister, the Soviet press had tagged her as ``the Iron Lady,'' a title she wore proudly. A political outsider, Mrs. Thatcher was proud of imposing the values she had learned from her father, a small-town grocer, on a political establishment grounded in wealth and privilege. She led the Conservative Party to election victories without ever winning the affection of most of her people. Throughout her career, she was fortunate in her opponents. She was elected party leader on May 4, 1975, ousting Edward Heath after he had lost two national elections in a row. In 1979, her election was insured by popular disgust with high inflation and labor unrest under the Labor Party government. When her own popularity ebbed in 1982, Argentina invaded the Falklands. The surge of national pride that followed the reconquest carried her triumphantly through the 1983 election. She was also helped by the split in the Labor Party, which produced a new party of the center, so that the Conservatives won elections without winning majorities of the popular vote. After the collapse of the Iron Curtain, when her gospel of military preparedness began to appear passe, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Once again, she was the best friend of an American president, backing up tough talk with ships, tanks and troops. The political left loathed her and had good reason to fear her. Liberals accused her of exacerbating divisions between rich and poor and of undermining free speech. Peter Jenkins, a leading liberal columnist, said after a decade of Thatcherism that she had overthrown ``the existing order, changed the political map and put her country on its feet again.'' ``She did all this with ruthlessness and much injustice and at a high cost in human misery, but she did it,'' commented Jenkins. For the majority who had jobs, she raised living standards dramatically - average earnings were up by nearly one-third and more Britons owned their homes. Thatcherism was all about free markets and private enterprise. She sold much of the industry the Labor government had nationalized, turning such money-losers as steel and British Airways into profitable enterprises. Her success deeply affected the Labor Party, which moved sharply to the center in hope of regaining power. To her admirers, battling Maggie was a national savior who ended Britain's postwar cycle of confrontation and decline. To her detractors, she was an anti-union bull set free in a china shop, destroying revered institutions. In 1981, after she began implementing her rigorous policies and unemployment soared to a record 3 million, Mrs. Thatcher was rated the most unpopular prime minister since opinion polls began. Even when she had become a sort of national institution, polls regularly indicated two-thirds of Britons disliked her personally. Similar majorities also said they respected her, and courage was one of the qualities they admired. She survived unscathed from an Irish Republican Army bomb that killed five people at the 1984 party convention in Brighton. ``You have to cope with it,'' she said ``Because if you didn't and they intimidated you out of doing the work you have been elected to do, it would be the end of democracy.'' In foreign policy, Britain under Mrs. Thatcher was unequivocally pro-American. In 1986, she was alone among the allies in associating herself with the U.S. bombing of Libya, allowing the bombers to fly from British bases. When the Iron Curtain crumbled in 1989 and a united Germany emerged as Europe's new superpower, Mrs. Thatcher appeared sidelined. But she reemerged as the leader most willing to rush to America's side with troops in the Persian Gulf crisis. Mrs. Thatcher fought mighty battles with fellow European Community leaders, resisting attempts to turn the community into a sort of United States of Europe. Born Oct. 13, 1925, Margaret Hilda Roberts learned her values of thrift, discipline and industry from her father, a grocer in the small town of Grantham in central England. She became involved in politics at Oxford University, where she won a chemistry degree in 1947. Her electoral career began in the traditional way, slogging through hopeless campaigns in 1950 and 1951 in districts where the Conservatives had no hope. She married wealth businessman Denis Thatcher in 1951, and their twins, Carol and Mark, came two years later. Mrs. Thatcher was elected to Parliament in 1958 for Finchley, a middle-class north London district. She was minister of pensions and national insurance from 1961-63 under prime ministers Harold Macmillan and Lord Home. Edward Heath made her education secretary in his Cabinet of 1970-74. Against formidable odds, including her social origins and her sex, she won a contest for the party leadership in 1975. W hile more prominent Conservatives held back from a challenge, Mrs. Thatcher plunged in, winning so many votes in the first round that Heath resigned. The 1975 party election was the start of what biographer Hugo Young, called ``an era in which an ordinary politician, laboring under many disadvantages, grew into an international figure who did some extraordinary things to her country.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Greet Their Commander-in-Chief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new to UPDATE with Bush addressing the troops.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops greeted commander-in-chief George Bush on Thanksgiving Day with an overriding message: Let's do something now or go home. Because of security precautions, Bush's whirlwind seven-hour visit to U.S. and allied forces in eastern Saudi Arabia was so shrouded in secrecy that troops didn't know who should be putting on the spit and polish. The president's itinerary included a meeting with about 2,000 U.S. and allied personnel at an air base, turkey dinner with about 1,200 soldiers in the desert, a Thanksgiving service on a U.S. Navy ship with about 1,500 sailors, and an address to about 1,500 Marines, Seabees and British troops in a speech broadcast by Armed Forces Radio. Bush and wife Barbara got a rousing welcome from a sun-baked crowd of several thousand troops at the main U.S. air base in Dhahran, where he spoke from an airport platform in front of parked warplanes. Bush, wearing khaki pants and a blue shirt, waded into a sea of military personnel dressed in desert camouflage uniforms to shake hands and pose for pictures. Although the troops cheered Bush, they were largely silent when he said he would not keep Americans in the gulf ``a single day longer than necessary.'' In a front-page commentary Wednesday, the English-language Saudi Gazette called the president's visit a milestone in Saudi-American relations. The newspaper said Bush won Saudi hearts by sending troops to defend the country and will win Saudi minds if he affirms that the United States will not let any Mideast country terrorize its neighbors with weapons of mass destruction. Many servicemen welcomed the president's visit as a morale-booster. Some said it showed America was standing tough. But a few said it was no big deal, appearing more interested in the turkey and trimmings laid on for them, and in listening to a live broadcast of the Detroit Lions vs. Denver Broncos football game from Pontiac, Mich. ``I think it's exciting. I wish ... he'd come and eat with us,'' said Mrs. Law, who works full-time for the Alabama National Guard. ``I'd tell him we're ready to do something. We're ready to get it over with so we can go home.'' Sgt. 1st Class Mickey Kershaw, 37, of West Islip, N.Y., said if he had the chance he'd tell Bush: ``I'd rather do it now than do it five years from now when this guy (Saddam Hussein) nukes me - and the family I intend to have.'' Staff Sgt. Mike Lytle of Langley Air Force Base, Va., said ``nobody wants bloodshed'' but Americans are impatient ``and nobody wants to sit here six months ... and wait for sanctions to take full effect.'' Sgt. Daniel Ralph, 27, of Philadelphia, an Army food inspector who was checking out turkeys in a large warehouse, said Bush's visit ``is bound to help morale.'' But Army Reserve Spec. Bobby Lampkin, 34, of Eastman, Ga., said: ``It's no biggie. There's nothing he could tell me to justify us being here.'' Chief Warrant Officer Wes Wolf, 42, of Monterey, Calif., the military food czar, said ``99.9 percent'' of the gulf forces were dining on fresh turkey, ham and roast beef, with a shrimp cocktail appetizer, lots of fruit and vegetables, sweet or mashed potatoes, and a choice of five kinds of pie for dessert. That works out to 60,000 pounds of rolled turkey, 2,000 whole turkeys, 70,000 pounds of roast beef, 45,000 pounds of ham, 45,000 pies and tens of thousands of pounds of other trimmings, he said. The Saudi government paid for half the dinner and the main Saudi food contractor, Arab Supplies and Trading, has donated 230,000 candy bars. Only one or two military units were eating pre-packaged TV-style turkey dinners known as T-rations, Wolf said. But just in case, there were 600,000 stashed in a warehouse. No matter what kind of dinner they ate, most soldiers said they'd still rather be home. ``It's really hard for me three years in a row being away from my family,'' said Anibal Cabezas, 23, of New York, who is with the 82nd Aviation Brigade. ``It seems every time the holidays come we have to go on a mission. But it's a job we have to get done. That's what we're here for.''

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze To Meet Chinese Counterpart on Gulf Crisis ^With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will meet Friday near the Chinese-Soviet border, apparently to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, a Soviet Embassy spokesman said today. Press attache Yuri Lyssenko said he had no further details about the talks, to be held in Urumqi in China's far western Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. Asked if the meeting would focus on developments in the gulf and related diplomatic efforts, Lyssenko replied: ``I suppose so. It may be since Mr. Qian has just returned from that region.'' Qian returned Nov. 13 from a Middle East diplomatic mission that took him to Iraq, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Egypt. During his stop in Cairo, Qian met with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing reiterated China's position on the gulf crisis during the weekly news briefing today, but he did not mention the planned Chinese-Soviet talks. ``As long as there is still a gleam of hope for a peaceful settlement, unremitting efforts should be continued toward this,'' Li said. Lyssenko said he did not know if Qian and Shevardnadze would discuss a possible U.N. Security Council resolution sanctioning an attack on Iraqi forces to dislodge them from Kuwait. The United States has sought support from Security Council members for such a resolution. During the news briefing, Li called the possible use of military force in the gulf ``a very serious and complicated issue which would have a major impact ... So it must be handled with great care and should not be hurried through.'' The Urumqi meeting will be the second set of talks held on short notice between Shevardnadze and Qian since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. They met Sept. 1 in the northeastern city of Harbin with the gulf situation as the major topic. Such meetings reflect the new, deepening cooperation between the two countries since they normalized relations in 1989, ending a three-decade split. The Soviet Union and China, as permanent Security Council members, have veto power over resolutions. In addition to the United States, the other permanent members are Britain and France. Chinese officials have stressed that all efforts to find a peaceful settlement to the gulf crisis must be exhausted before considering the use of military force. China has supported all Security Council resolutions aimed at forcing Iraq from Kuwait. But Chinese officials have refused to say how the China would vote if a measure seeking authorization for military force comes before the council.

DOC.HEAD: Pound Jumps on Thatcher's Resignation, Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The pound jumped today on the news of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's resignation. The dollar moved down. Gold was up. Foreign exchange dealers said investors were relieved that Mrs. Thatcher's decision had left the way clear for a new candidate who can unify the Conservative Party and put it back on course for another election victory over the Labor Party. The British pound jumped to $1.9744 in London from $1.9680 late Wednesday. DOC.HEAD: Kohl Ties Israeli, Lebanon Questions Into Resolution Of Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl called today for a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis, and said ``the time is ripe'' to solve the Arab-Israeli tensions and the Lebanon conflict as well. So far, most Western leaders have resisted tying efforts to peacefully resolve the Persian Gulf crisis in with the search for a solution to the Palestinian conflict and Lebanon's crisis. In a speech to Parliament, the chancellor also repeated his support for the creation of a United States of Europe. Kohl's government has been put on the spot by Iraq's announcement on Tuesday that it would free all German hostages, apparently in an attempt to drive a wedge into the Western alliance that is trying to force Saddam Hussein to relinquish Kuwait. The chancellor said that at the Paris summit that ended on Wednesday he found a unanimous wish ``to seek a peaceful solution'' to the crisis Saddam precipitated with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``None of us wants war,'' the chancellor said, stressing the unified front against Iraq. Kohl said the leaders in Paris also agreed that ``the time is ripe'' for the other conflicts in the Middle East to be solved by negotiations. ``There won't be any lasting peace and security in the Middle East and Near East until the Arab-Israeli conflict and the Lebanon conflict are settled by negotiations,'' Kohl told the lawmakers, drawing a round of applause.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Frees More Than 100 Hostages
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 European hostages, mainly Britons and Swiss nationals, flew out of Baghdad in two chartered planes today after Iraqi authorities freed them in response to appeals by French and Swiss delegations. One group of 83 left with right-wing French politician Jean-Marie Le Pen for Strasbourg, France, seat of the European Parliament, aboard an Iraqi Airways jetliner. The group comprised 35 Britons, 15 Italians, 15 Germans, six Irish citizens, five Dutch nationals, three Danes, two Belgians, a Portuguese and Greek, officials with Le Pen said. The other group of 36 Europeans left earlier aboard a chartered Swissair jet for Zurich with a five-member Swiss Parliamentary delegation led by Edgar Oehler, a Christian Democrat deputy. That group consisted of 16 Swiss, four Irish nationals, four Swedes, four Germans, four Dutch citizens, two Belgians and two Britons, Swiss officials reported.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Visiting US Troops in Saudi Desert
Precedes Dhahran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material from Bush visit near the front lines.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, on a Thanksgiving visit with American combat forces, said today that Iraq's efforts to build a nuclear-weapons arsenal gives ``a real sense of urgency'' to the U.S. military showdown with Baghdad. Bush and key congressional leaders hopscotched between desert sites where 230,000 soldiers were deployed in the hot, grim work of enforcing U.S. policy against Iraq. Bush explained the purpose of their sacrifice thusly: ``We're here to protect freedom, we're here to protect our future, we're here to protect innocent life,'' he said of the U.S. opposition to Iraq's August invasion of Kuwait. He said, ``There could hardly be a prouder moment than sharing Thanksgiving with this family, this American family out here.'' Earlier, he told a cheering crowd at the big U.S. air command center in Dhahran: ``What we're confronting is a classic bully who thinks he can get away with kicking sand in the face of the world.'' Bush won a rousing reception when he told an Army group: ``We are not hear on some exercise... We are not walking away until our mission is done.'' His voice rising, Bush declared in a message to Saddam Hussein: ``Free the hostages, all the hostages and free them today or you're going to pay the price.'' He was referring to the nearly one thousand Americans believed to be still in Iraq and Kuwait, most of them either in detention or not allowed to leave. Yet the troops were largely silent when Bush said he would not keep Americans in the gulf ``a single day longer than necessary.'' ``That means awhile,'' one soldier commented. ``Let's do it,'' another called out. ``Let's go get 'em today so we can go home,' said Spec. 4 Gwendolyn Page of the 988th Supply Co. from Athens, Ga.

DOC.HEAD: 500-Day Plan Architect Quits Russian Parliament
DOC.TEXT: The Russian Parliament today accepted the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Grigory Yavlinsky, co-author of a radical 500-day plan for transition to a market economy, the official Tass news agency said. Yavlinsky formally offered his resignation to the Russian lawmakers on Oct. 17, after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented an alternative plan that had no time limit. Lawmakers delayed a vote on Yavlinsky's resignation to give him time to reconsider. Tass said Yavlinsky offered his resignation because the Gorbachev plan was virtually under way nationwide and ``realization of the 500-day program, as Yavlinsky put it, was unrealistic.'' Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, Gorbachev's chief rival, has moved ahead with the 500-day plan in Russia, by far the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics. Today, Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silayev urged the republic's lawmakers to accept Yavlinsky's resignation. ``I do this with regret, but Yavlinsky wants to work in another capacity,'' Tass quoted Silayev as saying. Deputies voted 164 to 17 to accept the resignation, the independent news agency Interfax reported. Yavlinsky's resignation came a day after Yeltsin declared that Soviet republics could no longer wait for a union treaty to be approved. He said they were proceeding on their own to create a new economic union. Yeltsin on Wednesday signed a treaty with the republic of Kazakstan, the fourth bilateral treaty with another republic. The treaty with the Central Asian republic would set up direct economic, politial and cultural ties. Yeltsin signed a treaty with the Ukraine on Monday and earlier concluded pacts with Moldavia and Georgia. The move by Yeltsin, Gorbachev's main political rival, indicated he was moving to consolidate support among the republics. The two leaders have been locked in a power struggle over their divergent plans for rescuing the economy and holding the country together, resulting in a paralysis of power. ``These bilateral treaties could constitute a major, solid foundation for the future signing of a new Union Treaty,'' Yeltsin said at a news conference after the signing. At the same time, he said, they would help prevent economic chaos until such a treaty could be signed. Since Nov. 1, Yeltsin and his government have gone ahead with their own 500-day transition program, drafted by a group of economists headed by Yavlinsky and economist Stanislav Shatalin. But, legislators in the country's largest republic have been stymied because they do not have clear control of prices, currency, interest rates, land and real estate. The national legislature, the Supreme Soviet, agreed Oct. 19 on a compromise economic plan endorsed by Gorbachev that is a slower and less radical step away from central planning to a market economy.

DOC.TEXT: Later, when Bush visited an Army encampment, Capt. Michael Stevens of Miami said morale was generally high. ``It's great that he came. It gives us all a sign that he cares.'' Bush then traveled toward the front lines of the Persian Gulf crisis for an appearance carried live in the United States on breakfast-time TV. For security reasons, the White House forbid publication of the president's precise location, but Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of U.S. forces, said Bush and his wife Barbara would be within 80 miles of the border with Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. The president called it ``an unforgettable visit,'' and left with ``a prayer in our hearts, a prayer on our lips.'' ``God bless you all, God bless our faithful allies,'' Bush said. Bush was the first president to visit with U.S. troops in the field since then-President Richard M. Nixon's July 1969 visit to South Vietnam. From his first stop in Dhahran, Bush boarded a helicopter to visit troops at remote locations and to share Thanksgiving dinner. The military arranged to serve a holiday meal - shrimp cocktail, turkey, stuffing, mashed potatoes and cranberry sauce - to all the American forces stationed around the gulf. The Bushes got a rousing welcome from a sun-baked crowd of several thousand troops at Dhahran, where he spoke from an airport platform in front of parked warplanes. Bush, wearing khaki pants and an open-collar blue shirt, waded into a sea of military personnel dressed in desert camouflage uniforms to shake hands and pose for pictures. In a brief speech, Bush said the United States has acted with restraint, ``as is our way,'' against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``But Saddam is making the mistake of his life if he confuses an abundance of restraint and patience with a lack of resolve,'' he said. ``And every day that passes brings Saddam Hussein one step closer to realizing his goal of a nuclear weapons arsenal,'' Bush said. ``And, frankly, that's another reason why more, and more, our mission is marked by a real sense of urgency.'' It was a theme he struck again in his speech near the front. American and Israeli experts believe Iraq is at least five to 10 years away from building nuclear weapons, but Bush said no one should be certain of such a timetable. ``No one knows precisely when this dictator may acquire atomic weapons or exactly who they may be aimed at down the road. But we do know this for sure: he's never possessed a weapon he didn't use,'' Bush said. Today was the first time Bush has cited Iraq's nuclear program as a major reason for confronting Saddam. The president had said Wednesday he planned to tell U.S. troops they were not in Saudi Arabia on some ``mission impossible.''

Bush told the troops: ``No president - none at all - is quick to order American troops abroad. ``But there are times when all nations that value freedom must confront aggression. ``Sometimes it's a question of some pain - some pain now to avoid even worse pain later,'' he said. He met with members of the Army's 197th Infantary brigate, located in Fort Benning, Ga. and other assorted troops brought in. Sand was everywhere in the air, and huge clouds billowed as Bush's helicopter landed. The president and his wife waited in a chow line to get the food in a tent covered with camouflage netting, then joined the troops, eating at tables that were no more than slabs of plywood placed atop sandbags. Soldiers leaned their M-16 rifles up against their tables as they ate. Bush gave the troops a set of horsehoes, which he said could be won in a drawing. He said he and his sons would challenge the winner to play with them back at the White House horsehoe pits. ``My boys and I can whup you,'' he cautioned the yet-unknown winner. Bush also choppered to the USS Nassau, a helicopter carrier in the gulf. The final stop was at a forward-based Marine command post where Marines, Navy Seabees and British ``Desert Rat'' armored forces were assembled. The president was flying late in the day to Cairo and meetings with President Hosni Mubarak. He will fly to Geneva Friday to meet with Syrian President Hafez al-Assad. Secretary of State James A. Baker III accompanied the president to Saudi Arabia, but split off to fly to Yemen today to seek support for a United Nations resolution authorizing military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.

DOC.TEXT: ``Today'' newscaster Faith Daniels is getting a new NBC News daytime series that will examine social issues while CBS is putting Nell Carter in a new Saturday night comedy, the networks announced. NBC, trying to bolster its third-place daytime schedule, said Wednesday that Daniels' midday series, ``A Closer Look,'' will replace the soap opera ``Generations,'' which had drawn low ratings. Daniels will continue with ``Today.'' ``A Closer Look'' debuts Jan. 28. Seven other possible news-information series are in development, NBC said, including ``Women's Diaries'' with former NBC News star Linda Ellerbee. Although ``Generations'' has trailed in its time period, various black groups had campaigned to save the soap opera, which broke new ground when it premiered in March 1989 by focusing on a black family as well as a white family. Carter's new series, ``You Take the Kids,'' is set to debut Dec. 15 on CBS. She and Roger E. Mosley star as parents of a blue-collar family in Pittsburgh. Carter previously starred in ``Gimme a Break,'' while Mosley was in ``Magnum P.I.'' ``Lenny,'' which was pulled from its Wednesday night slot on CBS because of low ratings, will also move to Saturdays on Dec. 15, the network said. To make room, CBS is dropping ``The Hogan Family'' and ``The Family Man.'' The network said it is canceling ``The Hogan Family,'' which was picked up after NBC dropped it last season. It said it will bring ``The Family Man'' back to the air next spring.

DOC.HEAD: Shock, Delight, or Flowers: Reaction to Thatcher's Resignation Varies
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Party colleagues of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expressed shock and amazement at her decision Thursday to resign, although some said she had done the right thing. The opposition Labor Party members said they were delighted. Conservative lawmaker Peter Thurnham turned up at Mrs. Thatcher's 10 Downing Street office with two dozen red roses for her. ``In condolence?'' a reporter asked. ``Yes,'' Thurnham replied bluntly. More flowers turned up throughout the day from admirers around the country. They included lilies, seen as a symbol of a passing era. Mrs. Thatcher said she will step down as prime minister when a new party leader was chosen. ``Thank you for all you have done for our country,'' said a message attached to one bunch. Kenneth Baker, Conservative Party chairman, said: ``I am very saddened indeed that our greatest peacetime prime minister has left government. She is an outstanding leader not only of our country and the world and I do not believe we will see her like again.'' Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock was cheerful following Mrs' Thatcher's announcement, calling it, ``Good, very good indeed.'' ``I cannot pretend otherwise. Let's have a general election now,'' said Kinnock, whose party has led recent public opinion polls. Paddy Ashdown, leader of the smaller opposition Liberal Democrats, said: ``The prime minister has taken the right decision for her own reputation, for the unity of her party, and for the good of Britain.'' ``I just can't believe it has happened,'' said James Spicer, Conservative vice chairman and a close friend of Mrs. Thatcher. He added, in a reference to politicians who were dismissed or resigned from Mrs. Thatcher's government: ``I don't know quite what the reaction will be worldwide. I am sure it will be shock and amazement that someone of her caliber can have ended her career like this - pulled down by a mixture of envy and dislike borne of being cast aside.'' Sir John Stokes, Conservative Party lawmaker, said the party had thrown out its greatest leader. ``The age of chivalry has gone and disloyalty has triumphed.'' Conservative lawmaker John Hannam thought Mrs. Thatcher had had a ``very good chance'' of winning the next round of voting in the party's process of choosing their leader. But he conceded Mrs. Thatcher had to consider whether she could carry on without the full backing of the party's 372 legislators. Fellow Conservative Neville Trotter said: ``I think she has done the right thing. She has put the interests of the party first.'' Trotter said the leadership election would take place in a ``calmer, cooler atmosphere'' now that Mrs. Thatcher had resigned. ``She will always be remembered as one of the greatest political leaders in our history,'' said Sir Geoffrey Howe, a close colleague of Mrs. Thatcher for 15 years. But it was Howe's resignation as deputy prime minister on Nov. 1 in protest at what he saw as Mrs. Thatcher's negative attitudes to European integration that was crucial in forcing the leadership contest. On Nov. 14, former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine announced a formal challenge to Mrs. Thatcher's leadership. He gathered enough votes Tuesday to force Mrs. Thatcher to a second ballot - and he appeared to be picking up strength, leading to Mrs. Thatcher's decision to resign. A tribute to Mrs. Thatcher had been written in the Cabinet record for Thursday. It read in part: ``We thank you most warmly for your leadership and we extend to both you and your husband (retired oil executive Denis Thatcher) who has supported you so marvelously, all our best wishes for the future. Your place in our country's history is already assured.''
