DOC.TEXT: The giant balloon heroes of the Macy's parade drew oohs and ahs in New York City, while across the nation millions of Thanksgiving feasts were being prepared today for soldiers, the homeless and others. The television bad boy and a dozen other big balloons rolled down Manhattan streets today as the 64th annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade got under way shortly after 9 a.m. The weather was just about perfect for a parade: sunny with temperatures in the low 40s, a welcome change from last year's five inches of snow. The celebration began early as parents brought their children to Central Park on Wednesday night to see balloons being prepared. The nationally televised parade, with ``Today'' show celebrities Deborah Norville and Willard Scott as hosts, included a cartoon celebrity lineup that featured spike-haired underachiever Bart Simpson, making his first appearance, and Kermit the Frog, returning after a three-year absence. The poignancy of Kermit's return was not missed by Paul Oppold, 27, of New York, who stopped smiling as he peered at the giant frog whose creator, Jim Henson, died earlier this year. ``Kermit makes me sad,'' he said. Meanwhile, at military bases around the nation, turkey with all the trimmings was being prepared for families of servicemen spending Thanksgiving in the Persian Gulf and for soldiers expected to ship out after the holiday. ``We expect a big turnout,'' said Richard Olson, a spokesman at Fort Stewart in Hinesville, Ga., where post officials planned to feed about 5,500 people. ``Wives are getting together decorations. There is a big push to get the families to come in and eat in the dining facilities.'' In Jacksonville, N.C., the town surrounding the Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Base, more than 300 civilians held a candlelight Thanksgiving service Wednesday. Some 30,000 base Marines are awaiting word on deployment orders that will take them to the Persian Gulf. ``We are thankful that our nation has the moral courage and physical strength to resist the aggression of a mad man,'' Brig. Gen. Charles Krulak, commanding general of the 2nd Marine Fourth Service Support Group at Camp Lejeune, told the service. Also around the nation, volunteers were preparing holiday dinners for thousands of poor and homeless people. In Los Angeles, such celebrities as actors Jeff and Lloyd Bridges, Ed Asner, Leonard Nimoy, Cesar Romero, Earl Holliman and Heather Locklear and her husband, Motley Crue drummer Tommy Lee, served holiday dinners a day early Wednesday to some 30,000 homeless people. The annual feast at the Los Angeles Mission was offered early to allow poor people to take advantage of meals planned by other relief agencies today, said the Rev. Mark Holsinger, the mission's director.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Calls Early Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with background, comment, other details; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Poul Schlueter today called early elections for Dec. 12 after his minority government failed to gain support in parliament for its economic program. Talks broke down late Wednesday between Schlueter's center-right coalition and the main opposition Social Democrats on an economic package that included tax reform. Denmark's personal income taxes average around 52 percent and climb progressively to 68 percent, the second-highest in Europe after Sweden. Despite agreement on the need to cut taxes, the political factions differ about how to fill the gap in state revenues left by a proposed tax break while staying within the government's tight 1991 draft budget. A total of 13 parties will be contesting seats in the 179-seat legislature, where Schlueter commands only 67 votes. The Social Democrats have 55 seats. Since his Conservative-led government could not muster a majority in the Folketing, or parliament, for its draft budget, Schlueter announced the election without the traditional debate. Some commentators questioned whether the ballot was really necessary. A regular election is already scheduled for next year. But Schleuter said elections were needed now to give the government the authority to carry out tax reforms without further delay. ``It is necessary to get it over with as quickly as possible,'' he said in a short statement. Economy Minister Niels Helveg Petersen, leader of the Social-Liberal Party, the junior coalition partner, said he regretted the election call at a time when the two sides had narrowed their differences. ``The coalition parties will campaign singly and together to gain the extra backing needed to carry out its economic package,'' said Petersen. Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, the foreign minister and leader of the Liberal Party -the senior coalition partner - welcomed the poll. He said there were major differences in principle between the government and the Social Democrats on taxes and economic policy. The government would continue to work for tax relief, Ellemann-Jensen said. Social Democratic leader Svend Auken said the party would run on a platform of fuller employment, environmental protection and tax breaks for middle income groups. The jobless rate stands at 9.8 percent. Auken criticized Schlueter for wanting to give tax relief to the affluent while running up a $5.3 billion budget deficit. The coalition parties - Conservatives, Liberals and Social Liberals - had agreed with the Social Democrats on lowering income taxes at the top of the scale to bring them more into line with those of Denmark's European Community partners.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys Shinto Shrine As Emperor Holds Final Enthronement Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito today began the most controversial ceremony in his accession to the Chrysanthemum Throne, a communion with the mythical sun goddess from whom legend says the imperial line descended. The Shinto rite has been performed by most of Japan's monarchs since at least the seventh century, and in the past was believed to give monarchs their status as living gods. But protests were held across the country against the state-funded rite, which has been criticized by many Japanese as violating the constitution's separation of church and state. Hundreds of scholars in the north and labor unionists in the west held peaceful demontrations, while hundreds of Christians nationwide fasted. About 30,000 police were assigned to security in Tokyo alone because of the threat of violence by ultra-leftist radicals who want to abolish the monarchy. As the ceremony began this evening, radicals fired six metal projectiles from homemade mortar-like launchers at an imperial villa in Kyoto, western Japan, police said. Radicals were believed responsible for a fire that destroyed a Shinto shrine in southern Japan today, police said. On Wednesday, anti-monarchy radicals shoveled human waste from a truck near the Imperial Palace. Akihito, 56, is the first Japanese emperor to be enthroned not as a god-king but as a symbol of his people's sovereignty. But that has not diminished the pomp and ceremony of his multimillion-dollar coronation. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, dressed in a swallow-tailed coat, arrived at the palace this evening to attend the communion, one of the final events surrounding the enthronement. Nearly 900 Japanese dignitaries were expected to attend. Unlike Akihito's formal state enthronement ceremony Nov. 12 that was viewed by foreign dignitaries representing 158 countries, no foreigners were invited to the communion, which is to end before dawn Friday. During the rite, called the Daijosai or Great Food Offering Ritual, Akihito offers rice, wine and other foods from around the country to the sun goddess Amaterasu, from whom legend says the imperial line descended. Only two female attendants, clad in white and red kimono and with their hair tied in pony tails nearly 6{ feet long, witness the Daijosai. The ceremony is held in the torch-lit inner sanctuary of a specially built hall on the palace grounds. The rite is performed only once by each emperor. Akihito, wearing his most holy white silk robes for the rite and surrounded by court chamberlains, slowly proceeded to the sanctuary, led by two attendants lighting the way with torches. Other attendants carried a large parasol over Akihito's head, or unrolled a rush mat before him. Yet another rolled up the mat behind the emperor after each deliberate step. Inside the sanctuary, out of view of the 733 Japanese guests seated in large tents nearby, the offerings were to be made to an altar placed beside a stylized bed, from which the goddess is summoned. Scholars before World War II theorized that at one time the ceremony might have involved the emperor symbolically having sex with the sun goddess, representing a union with the divine. Palace officials, however, deny that theory and said the emperor would not touch the bed. After the first communion this evening, the ceremony was to be repeated after midnight in an identical hall located just yards away from the first one. Haunting court music was to be played throughout. Akihito, like his father, the late Emperor Hirohito, performs dozens of religious ceremonies at the palace each year, carrying on the priest-king role that has been handed down from ancient times. That role, however, has periodically come under fire since the end of World War II, and opposition political parties, Christian organizations and other groups claim the government is violation the constitutional separation of church and state by spending an estimated $17 million on the coronation rites. Hirohito, who died in January 1989 at age 87, renounced the concept of imperial divinity on New Year's Day 1946, at the urging of the U.S.-led occupation forces. The country's post-war constitution specifies that the emperor is a national symbol, and not a god-king as tradition had had it. Critics say repeating the Shinto rites for Akihito's enthronement could encourage a return to the feverish emperor-worship that helped lead the nation into war.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Thatcher As Steadfast Ally
With PM-Gulf-Bush
DOC.DATELINE: IN THE DESERT OF EASTERN SAUDI ARABIA (AP)
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, learning of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's decision to resign while he was visiting American troops deep in the Saudi desert, praised the British leader as ``an outstanding ally of the United States.'' ``You always know where she was and what she believed,'' Bush told reporters at a Marine outpost not far from the Kuwaiti border. ``She has always been an outstanding ally of the United States.'' The president learned of Mrs. Thatcher's decision from his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, during his tour of military encampments in the Saudi Desert. That tour included a visit to a group of British ``Desert Rats'' soldiers. ``You know of my high regard for Prime Minister Thatcher,'' Bush said. ``We obviously will work with the next prime minister and I expect they will stay right on course with us.'' ``In a personal sense, I would send my best to her,'' Bush said. ``I will miss her.'' At one point during his tour, a Marine was overheard telling the president he was surprised Mrs. Thatcher had resigned. ``I thought she'd duke it out,'' the Marine said. ``So did I,'' the president replied.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Resigns As Prime Minister
LaserPhotos LON1,5,6
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with quotes, figures on troop deployment; Edits to trim; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the ``Iron Lady'' to the end, announced her resignation today after 11{ years of power - and then ordered more British troops to the Persian Gulf. The startling news that Britain's first woman prime minister would call it quits came only one day after she had vowed: ``I fight on, I fight to win.'' The seemingly indomitable Mrs. Thatcher, Europe's longest-serving leader, was driven out by a rebellion in the ranks of her Conservative party, which now faces a three-man race to succeed her. The troop deployment was decided at the same Cabinet meeting in which the prime minister was warned that she would lose to Michael Heseltine in the second round of the Conservative Party leadership election. Under Britain's parliamentary system, the leader of the majority party is the prime minister. The prime minister had been sinking in the polls amid dissatisfaction over tax policies and high inflation. Mrs. Thatcher had failed on Tuesday to decisively fend off a challenge by the popular Michael Heseltine, who resigned as her defense minister in 1986, in the first round of voting by Conservative members of Parliament. ``I have concluded the unity of the party and prospects of victory in a general election would be better served if I stood down to enable Cabinet colleagues to enter the ballot for the leadership,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in a statement released by her office. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and treasury chief John Major, released from the obligations of loyalty, both jumped into the race, saying they were joining in ``a friendly contest.'' Wearing a royal blue suit and pearls as she faced a packed House of Commons on Thursday, Mrs. Thatcher appeared calm and in command. Fielding a friendly question, she said: ``Yes ... I do look back with some pride and some satisfaction at our achievements for our country over the last 11{ years.'' Conservative lawmaker Anthony Marlow told her it was a time of sadness and happiness. ``Sadness for her, from the great well of affection that exists for here in the house. Happiness in celebration of what has been, is and will remain, the greatest peacetime political reign of this century,'' Marlow said. When opposition Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock pressed his demand for a national election, Mrs. Thatcher said that was no more in the cards than it was when Labor Prime Minister Harold Wilson resigned in 1976 and was succeeded by James Callaghan. Speaking in the House of Commons, Defense Secretary Tom King said the new deployment in the Persian Gulf would involve 14,000 troops, bringing the total number of British soldiers in Saudi Arabia to more than 30,000. That would make the British troop commmitment to the multinational forces arrayed against Iraq in the gulf the second-largest behind the United States, which has deployed 250,000 soldiers and promised another 100,000. Earlier, Mrs. Thatcher smiled but said nothing to reporters as she left her office to go to Buckingham Palace to inform Queen Elizabeth II of her decision. Her office said her resignation would take effect as soon as her party has a new leader. The announcement that Mrs. Thatcher would resign came barely 2{ hours before the deadline for nominations. In next Tuesday's second round of voting, only a simple majority will be needed to win. Mrs. Thatcher has been assailed for imposing a new per capita tax on local services that makes princes pay the same as paupers. The dissatisfaction hit new heights several weeks ago when she resisted backing monetary union for the European Community at a meeting of its leaders. Heseltine, 57, has promised a more ``caring capitalism,'' a review of the local services tax and closer ties to the 12-nation European Community. Labor had been leading the Conservatives in the polls for 16 months, but several recent surveys showed the Conservatives leading if Heseltine were the leader. Heseltine won enough votes in the first round of balloting among the 372 Conservative members of 650-seat House of Commons to deny Mrs. Thatcher an outright victory, and many observers saw that failure as tantamount to defeat. Labor leader Neil Kinnock hailed the news of his nemesis' departure. ``Good. Very good indeed. I cannot pretend otherwise,'' Kinnock said. Whoever becomes prime minister must call new parliamentary elections by mid-1992. Mrs. Thatcher, struggling to stay in power, had rushed back on Wednesday from a European summit in Paris, changed campaign managers and tried to hustle votes in the Commons tearoom. Shares on the London Stock Exchange shot higher following the news Mrs. Thatcher was withdrawing from the leadership challenge.

Here is a transcript of President Bush's remarks at a U.S. Marine outpost Thursday. Q: (Off mike) - disproportionate share of the burden. Our troops outnumber the other forces here something like four to one. PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, we're by far the largest country and also when you're the leader in the world for peace and for freedom, you bear a disproportionate responsibility and we're prepared to do that. I'm pleased that 23 countries are involved. I'm pleased that other forces are moving in. I saw the ... Desert Rats here today and I'm very proud once again we're shoulder to shoulder with the Brits, for example. We have Arab forces here. But we're the United States of America, and we have a disproportionate responsibility to lead and to stand for something and that's what we're doing. And that's - Q: Speaking of the Brits, what is your reaction to Margaret Thatcher's decision to resign? PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, of course, you know of my high regard for Prime Minister Thatcher and I - we will obviously work with the next prim minister and I expect that knowing the fiber there that they'll stay right on course with us. But on a very personal sense, I would express my - my - send my best to her at this difficult time. She's been a staunch friend and ally. She's a woman of principle. She stood for what she believes. You always know where she was and what she believed. And I think everybody in America would agree that Margaret Thatcher has been an outstanding ally for the United States. And I, you know, am certain that this will continue with the United Kingdom. But on a personal basis, I'll miss her because I value her counsel. I value her long experience, that - the wisdom that comes from her long experience. And she has been an outstanding prime minister for the United Kingdom and an outstanding friend of the United States. Q: Mr. President ... what did you learn by walking in the same footsteps as the soldiers you sent - PRESIDENT BUSH: I learned a lot about the kids just from looking them in the eye. And I learned once again something I already knew, how lucky we are to have this all volunteer force as strong, as well trained and as highly motivated as they are. And I they're just like my own kids. Probably wish they were home. It's Thanksgiving Day in the United States. And I learned that they're willing to be apart from their own loved ones, because they feel it is their duty and their obligation. Q: Had you - PRESIDENT BUSH: And they're strong and they're tough, and they're - I - I've been very moved by today, I'll tell you. Q: Had you been concerned about the morale, sir, given the fact that it's almost four months now, and they've had no - nothing to fight? PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I think the waiting is a difficult - difficult part of this, but I think they, like their president, would prefer a peaceful solution. But like their president, I sense a certain resolve on their part that if they have to do something they're prepared to do it. And they want to do it and do it fast. And they want to do it and get it over. And I can understand that. I was in their shape forty-some years ago today - forty-six. And - so I - I - I've been very moved and motivated myself by this. And I'll go the extra mile for peace. We've been doing it. We've been showing patience and restraint. But I also know that this Saddam Hussein is cruel and he's brutal, and he's violating the rights of individuals. And I don't believe there's a Marine out here, or an Army person, or a Navy person, or an Air Force man or woman, or a British rat, or our Arab allies, that are not as upset as I am about the way innocent civilians are being treated. And I'll damn sure tell you I'm upset about it. And we'll try the peaceful route. We're trying it. But there will be no compromise with this kind of aggression. We're not going to compromise. Q: Sir, you talked - PRESIDENT BUSH: Thank you all. Q: - evasively today about a nuclear - Saddam's nuclear capability. PRESIDENT BUSH: Yes, I'm concerned about that. Q: What's behind this? Is - PRESIDENT BUSH: There's nothing behind it. It's just the fact that I think the longer it goes one, why, I'm concerned about it. That's what's behind it. Q: You have new information that it's closer than you thought before? Q: Just - I would just stay with what I said here today. And I - when I said that he is - remember that he's used every weapon he's had, I'm thinking primarily of the brutality of those chemical weapons that he did use on his own people. And I hope the American people understand this more clearly now. But I darn sure get the feeling that the people out here understand it. Thank you all. Q: President Bush, this is an emotional day for you, sir, wasn't it? PRESIDENT BUSH: It was a very emotional day for me, and I - I'm - I think we are very fortunate to have this kind of dedicated young man and young woman in the sands of Saudi Arabia today. And it's only the United States that can lead like this. It's only the United States of America. And we have others with us, but these are the ones that are doing the heavy lifting. And God bless them all.

Prince William Officer Killed in Shootout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to include identity of slain officer; SUBS 6th graf, bgng: Laclair, 36 xxx to CORRECT location of elbow wound.
DOC.TEXT: A Prince William County police officer and an unidentified gunman were killed early today in a shootout outside a Dale City home. Officer Philip Michael Pennington was a member of the Prince William police SWAT team sent to the home to investigate the wounding of an Arlington County deputy earlier Thursday, a Prince William County police spokesman said. SWAT team members and Arlington police converged on the house about 6:30 a.m., spokesman Sgt. Barry Bernard said. ``At that time there was an exchange of gunfire. As a result of that we had one Prince William County police officer who is dead. We also have an unidentified male dead at the scene,'' Bernard said. Arlington County police spokesman Tom Bell said the officers were trying to serve an arrest warrant for the shooting of Arlington County Sheriff's Capt. Daryl Laclair. Laclair, 36 and a 10-year veteran, was shot in the face and left elbow as he approached a car on a busy county highway shortly after midnight Thursday, Bell said. ``A motorist pulled beside him in the left lane and motioned for him to stop. After pulling over, he was proceeding toward the car and the motorist got out and fired three shots,'' Bell said. The wounded Laclair shot out the rear window of the motorists' gold Buick as the car sped away, Bell said. Laclair was admitted to Arlington Hospital, where he was listed in satisfactory condition. A witness reported the Buick's license number to police, who traced it to the Dale City home, Bell said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush in Saudi; More Hostages Freed; Pentagon Moves To Boost Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Britain to send more troops to gulf, some American hostages brought to Baghdad for Thanksgiving dinner
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave thanks with U.S. troops in the Saudi desert today, and Britain announced it was almost doubling the number of military personnel it has deployed in the Persian Gulf. Saddam Hussein, meanwhile, released more than 100 European hostages today, but American captives in Iraq marked a Thanksgiving full of fear and uncertainty. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was in Yemen seeking support for a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing force against Iraq. Bush became the first U.S. president to visit front-line troops since President Richard M. Nixon made a 1969 trip to South Vietnam. ``What we're confronting is a classic bully who thinks he can get away with kicking sand in the face of the world,'' he told soldiers and airmen at an Air Force command center in Dhahran. Britain's Defense Secretary Tom King said the new deployment in the Persian Gulf would involve 14,000 troops, bringing the total number of British military personnel in Saudi Arabia to more than 30,000. That would make the British troop commmitment to the multinational forces arrayed against Iraq in the gulf the second-largest behind the United States, which has deployed 250,000 soldiers and promised another 100,000. The European hostages, mainly Britons and Swiss, left Baghdad today aboard two chartered planes. Saddam had freed them in reponse to appeals by French and Swiss delegations. One group of 83 left with right-wing French politician Jean-Marie Le Pen for Strasbourg, France aboard an Iraqi Airways jetliner. Another 36 Europeans left earlier aboard a chartered Swissair jet for Zurich with a five-member Swiss parliamentary delegation. Hundreds of Americans are still held in Iraq, some of them detained as ``human shields'' at key installations. Twelve American captives were brought to a swank Baghdad country club by Iraqi authorities for a Thanksgiving meal of turkey. One of the hostages, Donald Whitely, 49, of Shreveport, La., said he hoped he would be freed soon because his father was seriously ill and ``I want to see him before he dies.'' Some of the catives were reunited with members of their families who had flown to Baghdad to see them against U.S. government advice. In Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl called today for a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis, and said ``the time is ripe'' to solve the Arab-Israeli tensions and the Lebanon conflict as well. So far, most Western leaders have resisted linking efforts to peacefully resolve the crisis with the search for a solution to the Palestinian question and Lebanon's more than 15-year-old civil war. The U.S. buildup in the gulf region has led to a manpower squeeze in the military, and there were reports today that the Army has decided to halt retirements and discharges for the duration of the crisis. The alliance that has gathered armies, navies and air forces in the region in response to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait is enforcing a U.N.-ordered trade embargo that aims to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait. But the embargo is widely thought by allied leaders to be slow in squeezing the Iraqis. Bush lobbied hard during this week's European security summit in Paris for support for a U.N. resolution authorizing military action to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. In Paris, Both Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and French President Francois Mitterrand on Wednesday called for a U.N. Security Council meeting to determine what further action should be taken against Iraq. Baker has also pursued a resolution on the use of force in meetings over the past week with the foreign ministers of eight of the U.N. Security Council's 15 members. Today, he traveled to Yemen, which is the only Arab member of the Security Council. Yemen has abstained in voting on about half of the 10 Security Council resolutions condemning Iraq for grabbing Kuwait. U.N. officials say the Bush administration wants a vote on the military strike resolution next week because it holds the Security Council's rotating presidency this month and must cede it to Yemen in December. In eastern Saudi Arabia, Bush and his wife Barbara got a rousing welcome from several thousand troops. He told the troops the United States has acted with restraint against Iraq so far, but warned: ``Saddam is making the mistake of his life if he confuses an abundance of restraint and patience with a lack of resolve.'' In his speech, Bush for the first time cited Iraq's nuclear program as a major reason for confronting Saddam. American and Israeli experts believe Iraq is five to 10 years away from building nuclear weapons. Even so, the president said, ``every day that passes brings Saddam Hussein one step closer to realizing his goal of a nuclear weapons arsenal.''

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Calls Thatcher Resignation `Selfless'
With PM-Britain-Thatcher, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan today called the resignation of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher a selfless act, and praised her as a bold and visionary ally during his own years of power. ``As she has done throughout her career in public service, Margaret Thatcher has made a selfless and courageous decision in what she believes is the best interests of her country,'' Reagan said in a statement. ``I could always count on her wise counsel, her firm support, and her loyal friendship,'' he said. ``Margaret Thatcher is truly a world statesman.'' Thatcher failed Tuesday to decisively fend off a challenge by the popular Michael Heseltine, who resigned as her defense minister in 1986, in the first round of voting by Conservative members of Parliament. She at first vowed to fight to win in a second round of voting set for next week. But today, Thatcher announced her resignation, saying it was for the good of the party. During her 11{ years in power, Britain's first female prime minister found a close ally in Reagan, who shared many of her political philosophies. Thatcher, unequivocally pro-American in foreign policy, was a champion of free markets and private enterprise, as was Reagan. While the 1980s era of Reaganomics saw the United States become more and more deeply mired in debt, the British economy thrived on the Iron Lady's radical policies. ``Through her bold and visionary policies, Margaret Thatcher restored Great Britain to prosperity and improved the quality of life for all her people,'' Reagan said.

DOC.HEAD: Dessert Dilemma: What to Do With 1,000 Pounds of Raspberry Goo?
DOC.TEXT: What do you do with 1,000 pounds of raspberry goo? If you're smart, you'll put it in a tart, and not down a storm drain, hoping it'll be washed away by a good rain. Evan D. Hansen was fined $500 for dumping the dessert, raspberry gelatin and whipped cream, down a storm drain, violating the state's Water Pollution Control Act. Hansen was faced with the dessert dilemma following a Sept. 5 contest in which participants attempted to perform the most outrageous stunts to win $5,000 from a local radio station. Hansen won by cutting the roof from a station wagon, filling it with raspberry gelatin and topping it with whipped cream. He then dressed in a white tuxedo, jumped in the gelatin and drove the car across the parking lot. Problems occurred when he tried to get rid of the goo. Hansen said he hired a waste disposal company to remove the gelatin from his car but their pump clogged. So he dumped it into a storm drain, which empties into Big Cottonwood Creek. ``I knew t was biodegradable and figured the rain would take care of it,'' said Hansen. ``I'm sure there was absolutely no damage.'' Kent Miner, director of water quality and hazardous waste for the Salt Lake City-County Health Department, said the environmental consequences of the illegal discharge were minor, but the law mandates a fine for the unauthorized release of wastes into a stream.

DOC.HEAD: Explosions Rock Capital, But No Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas set off a mortar barrage in the capital before dawn Thursday, awakening residents and rattling windows but causing only minor damage, authorities said. In the provincial capital of San Miguel, 75 miles east of San Salvador, military sources said five soldiers were killed in an overnight guerrilla mortar attack on the headquarters of the 3rd army brigade. The sources said four other soldiers were wounded in the attack, during which five rebel projectiles fell inside the compound. The attacks were the latest in a guerrilla operation begun Tuesday with battles in seven of El Salvador's 14 provinces. The leftist guerrillas have been fighting a succession of U.S-backed conservative governments for a decade, and more than 72,000 people have been killed. Elsewhere, military sources reported combat between government troops and leftist insurgents early Thursday in San Jose Guayabal, 11 miles northeast of San Salvador, and Mercedes Umana, 50 miles east of the capital. The sources said guerrillas and soldiers also battled in Jucuapa, 60 miles east of San Salvador, and in Torola, near the Honduran border in the northeastern province of Morazan. No casualties apart from those in San Miguel were immediately reported from the renewed fighting, part of a rebel offensive that began Tuesday and has killed about 80 people wounded nearly 270. In San Salvador, powerful rebel-launched homemade mortars damaged a metal high-tension wire tower just outside the San Antonio Abad power station on the city's northwestern edge before dawn, officials said. Two of the seven or eight projectiles launched at the station landed about 150 yards from the utility and damaged two private homes. Shortly after the barrage, two air force helicopters strafed and rocketed the slopes of the San Salvador volcano looming above the power station. Several hundred guerrillas are believed to be based on the mountain.

DOC.HEAD: Boss to New Prison Guard Graduates: Congratulations! You're Fired!
DOC.TEXT: As proud family members watched, 154 new prison guards graduated from the state Correctional Academy - but then they were promptly told by their boss that they're being laid off. ``The hard part is six weeks ago these guys gave up jobs to work for me ... and now they're on the street,'' state Corrections Commissioner Thomas Coughlin said Wednesday after the ceremony. Coughlin told the new guards, who come from across New York, that they'll lose their jobs the day after Christmas. That's when they will have completed their four weeks of on-the-job training at various state prisons. Under state contracts with their employees, it is required that the newest employees are laid off first. The layoffs, from the $21,000-a-year rookie guard jobs, are part of Gov. Mario Cuomo's plan to reduce a potential $1 billion budget deficit this year with 2,000 state agency firings. In all, Coughlin has to lay off about 300 guards and 400 teachers and other civilian prison employees as part of the Cuomo plan. ``These poor folks, through no fault of their own, got caught up ... in the cuts,'' Coughlin said. ``They had to go.'' About 400 people, including family members of the new guards, listened silently to the commissioner's comments at the start of the ceremony, said Coughlin. ``There was so much anxiety in the room,'' Coughlin said of the fact that last Saturday it was announced that 300 guards would be laid off. ``They probably saw the handwriting on the wall.'' There's a good chance the fired guards will be rehired as other guards quit or retire and the state opens new prisons, Coughlin said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Americans Among 38 Dead in Thai Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans were among 38 people who died in the crash of a Thai plane carrying foreign vacationers to a resort island, the U.S. Embassy said Thursday. The Bangkok Airways plane slammed into coconut trees in heavy rain and gusty wind late Wednesday as it prepared to land on Koh Samui, police said. Witnesses said it exploded and then crashed about six miles from the airport. Everyone aboard the plane, a de Havilland turbo-prop, was killed, including the five crew members and 33 mostly foreign passengers, officials said. The airport, with no radar or advanced ground control equipment, opened only last year to draw more foreign tourists to the pristine island in the Gulf of Thailand, 300 miles south of Bangkok. Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan ordered an investigation into the crash and an inspection of safety conditions at Koh Samui's airport, his spokesman Suvit Yodmani said. The flight recorder containing the conversation between the plane and the aircraft was found Wednesday but not yet analyzed, police said. The Bangkok Airways plane was on a 50-minute flight from Bangkok when it crashed. U.S. Embassy spokesman James Williams said at least two Americans were aboard - Edward G. Lincoln and Miss Kathleen Lincoln. Williams said he had no other immediate information. The passengers also included four or five Japanese, two Australians, and one German, said Nanthika Niyomrerk of the public relations department of Bangkok Airways. There also may have been Swedes and Finns aboard, she said. No other information on nationalities of victims was immediately available. Passanee Thongsuk, a hotel receptionist, said she saw the plane crash and explode about 6:20 p.m. Ms. Passanee said she was watching the sky because her hotel was expecting some of the tourists aboard the plane to check in. ``I saw the plane slowly heading down,'' she said. ``A few seconds later, I saw a big fire and smoke ... There was a loud explosion.'' ``It came down between some houses nearthe main road,'' she said. ``The people living there were very lucky to escape.'' Dr. Suvit Nantapanich, the director of Samui Hospital, said the bodies would be flown to Bangkok on Thursday. The plane was flying from Bangkok on the scenic 50-minute run to the island. The aircraft was a de Havilland Dash 8 Series 100 plane, one of two delivered to Bangkok Airways last year, said an aviation source in Seattle, who is familiar with de Havilland operations. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the planes are built in Toronto by de Havilland Canada, a Boeing subsidiary. Boeing has its headquarters in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: New Clean Air Law May Provide Feast for Environmental Companies
DOC.TEXT: For five years David Sundstrom has tried to sell utilities on a system that turns coal into cleaner-burning gas and produces electricity with less pollution. Usually they would listen, he says, and ``then sit on their hands.'' No more. Utility executives now are seeking out Sundstrom's company, Destec Energy Inc., and trekking in steady numbers to the Dow Chemical Co. subsidiary's coal gasification demonstration plant in Louisiana to learn more. ``There is now a line outside the door. There will be plenty of business for Destec,'' says Charles Goff, the company's president. Its one-man sales force is being expanded. The smiles at Destec - and at hundreds of environmental services companies like it nationwide - stem from the 1990 Clean Air Act signed into law by President Bush on Nov. 15, marking a new era in air pollution controls. The tougher clean air requirements that will be phased in over the next dozen years are expected to cost polluters - and their customers - as much as $11 billion a year within five years and more than $25 billion a year by the 2005. That's money that will be going into someone else's pocketbook. Destec hopes to capture a large chunk of the money. So do low-sulfur coal producers, manufactures of auto emissions equipment, builders of $100 million ``scrubbers'' for power plants, designers of pollution monitoring gear, brokers in pollution allowances and droves of lawyers and consultants needed to make sense of the dozens of new government regulations yet to come. The Environmental Protection Agency also is hiring people to help develop and implement the regulations. ``There are going to be an awful lot of people that will be big winners,'' says Bruce Braine, a vice president of ICF Resources Inc., an environmental consulting firm in Fairfax, Va. The new clean air law will require tougher emissions controls on automobiles, force factories and thousands of businesses to install new pollution control equipment, and require that electric utilities cut in half releases of sulfur dioxide that cause acid rain. Electric rate payers will see higher bills, especially in parts of the Midwest; car prices likely will go up, as will gasoline and possibly other products. The acid rain requirements will force utilities to buy expensive pollution control equipment or shift away from high-sulfur coal. That has people smiling at the A.T. Massey Coal Co. in Richmond, Va., the biggest producer of low-sulfur coal in the East, where T-shirts have begun to sprout declaring: ``Massey Lite Coal: High in BTUs, Low in Sulfur.'' ``We're trying to give Massey an identity,'' says Jerry Eyster, vice president for corporate development. He predicts competition will still be keen with western low-sulfur coal producers. That's fine with the Burlington Northern Railroad, one of the major shippers of low-sulfur coal out of Wyoming's Powder River Basin. The railroad has begun test runs of coal shipments farther East than normal and anticipates that the clean air requirements will boost volume by 10 percent. A key and innovative part of the new law will allow utilities to trade pollution allowances to ease the cost of compliance. That has telephones ringing in the Washington office of AERX, a company that specializes in such trades. ``Clearly we're going to be a winner,'' says John Palmisano, president and founder of the firm. ``We're hiring. We look at 1991 as a good year and 1992 as a very good year.'' The natural gas industry also sees dollar signs. Industrial plants and electric utilities will eye the cleaner fuel, as will fleet vehicle operators in the nation's smog-clogged cities. Pacific Gas & Electric Co. in California hopes to capitalize with plans to develop a network of outlets dispensing natural gas for fleet vehicles and eventually private cars. At Tecogen Inc. in Waltham, Mass., the clean air bill means a major marketing boost for a new engine that uses compressed natural gas. The company already has an agreement to supply 10 of the engines for school buses as part of a pilot program in California, but now expects interest to jump. Ravinder Sakhuja, Tecogen's president, said the company is expected to triple its revenue from the current $20 million a year within four or five years because of new business. Companies like Allied-Signal Automotive Catalyst Co. in Tulsa, Okla., also expect business to prosper as automakers will demand more sophisticated emissions control equipment. ``The R&D people, the engineering people, those people are winners,'' said Jim Hiera, the company's director of marketing. The required sale of cleaner-burning gasoline in cities with the worst smog will increase gasoline costs in 1995. Some of the money will go to Archer-Daniel-Midland Co., which produces ethanol, a corn-based additive, as well as to farmers. NaTec Resources Inc. in Houston is pushing a process in which baking soda would be used to chemically transform sulfur dioxide at coal-burning power plants into sodium sulfate that can be used in laundry detergent. Paul Portney, vice president of Resources for the Future, a Washington-based environmental research group, says tens of billions of dollars will be spent on cleaning up the nation's air over the next 10 years to 15 years. ``There's no way to spend a dollar without it going to somebody,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: Growing Opposition to Plan to Eject 7,000 Romanians From Austria
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Despite growing opposition to the plan, this country that has traditionally sheltered East bloc refugees is preparing to send home 7,000 Romanians in its largest forced repatriation in decades. ``I cannot keep ... everyone happy,'' Interior Minister Franz Loeschnak said Wednesday of the burgeoning criticism from newspapers, politicians and the Roman Catholic Church. On Thursday, Protestant church leaders also announced their opposition. About 80 people gathered this afternoon near an anti-fascist memorial to peacefully protest the government plan. More than 11,000 Romanians have fled their troubled homeland this year alone, by far the largest nationality among more than 18,000 asylum-seekers who have arrived in Austria in 1990. The government has refused to say when the first Romanians would be ejected. But a source, who asked not to be more closely identified, said the process was tentatively scheduled to begin this month. About 60 Romanians who have been convicted of crimes in Austria will be the first to go home, he said. Romanians whose asylum requests had been refused and those without jobs or permanent residence will also be forced to leave, Loeschnak told Austrian radio. Loeschnak said that about 1,200 Romanian refugees had already been singled out, and aides confirmed plans to send about 7,000 back once all the paperwork is completed. Most have been living in government-funded refugee camps or rooms. Historians say the ejections would be the country's largest since thousands of refugees were forcibly relocated after World War II by the four victorious powers who occupied Austria until 1955. With the toppling of communist regimes in Eastern Europe, the refugee issue has grown in importance in Austria, which offered haven for decades to the politically persecuted from the other side of the Iron Curtain. Hundreds of thousands of Hungarians were welcomed in 1956 after Soviet tanks crushed their uprising; more than 100,000 Czechoslovaks gained free entry in 1968 following the Warsaw Pact invasion of their country. No one was sent back against his will during the four decades of communism in Eastern Europe. But sentiment has changed in the past year, as East Europeans flood through newly opened borders - most to visit, some to stay. Romanians have been the target of most of the enmity. While most other East Europeans appear content to visit and return home, Romanians have continued to flee economic malaise and political uncertainty unmatched in most of the other former Soviet bloc nations. Of the 18,603 people who sought asylum up to September, 11,038 were Romanian, according to Interior Ministry figures. Turks were the next largest group at 1,478. The influx has overwhelmed many Austrians used to a more quiet life. Many now say that with the repressive communist regimes just a memory, most of those seeking to stay in Austria only want a higher standard of living. ``I'm afraid to go shopping on Mariahilferstrasse nowadays,'' said Jo Mestitz, an 84-year old widow who lives near the broad shopping street in Vienna's sixth district. ``You're likely to get overrun by Poles, and all you hear spoken is Czech or Hungarian.'' Originally, only refugee aid organizations objected to the government's plan. But by Wednesday, criticism had grown to include political figures from the partners in the governing coalition and Roman Catholic bishops, who have the ear of more than 80 percent of the nation's 7.6 million people. ``Mass deportations of people have never been justified, because each individual's fate is different from someone else's,'' said Bishop Florian Kuntner, president of the Bishops' Commission for Justice and Peace. State-owned Austrian Airlines announced it would not fly any Romanian back home against his will, and it urged the Interior Ministry to reconsider. Austrian radio said negotiations had been started with Lauda Air, the nation's private international airline. Many newspapers denounced the plan in stinging editorials. ``It is bad that a minister of an Austrian government has received such a task, and it is bad that he accepts it without regard to human rights and humanity,'' said the Neue Zeit newspaper. It indirectly compared the plan to the deportations of Jews to the Auschwitz death camp in Nazi-occupied Poland during World War II. But Interior Ministry spokesman Rainer Mayerhofer said most Austrians supported the move.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant's Sons Quiz Jurors, Force A Mistrial
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old boy and his 11-year-old brother decided to ask jurors in a federal trial how they thought things were going for their dad, the defendant. The perplexed judge was forced to declare a mistrial. The defense was about to begin its side Wednesday when the sons of defendant Gunther Russbacher quizzed jurors entering the courtroom, said Public Defender Mark Coleman. ``They didn't know any better,'' Coleman said. ``Adults generally know better than to talk to the jury, but the boys didn't.'' Russbacher is accused of impersonating a Navy captain and a U.S. attorney. Prosecutor Jon Conklin, who had completed his case, found the forced mistrial a ``disappointment, very frustrating.'' A juror told a court clerk about the boys' questions, and he notified Judge Edward Dean Price. He told the attorneys he had no choice but to declare a mistrial. A new trial will be scheduled later for Russbacher. He is accused of requisitioning a government jet while pretending to be a federal attorney, then flying to Seattle to get his girlfriend and on to Reno where they were married. When arrested July 31, Russbacher and his wife were staying at Castle Air Force Base where he allegedly was pretending to be a Navy captain.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Die In New Cholera Outbreak
DOC.TEXT: Eight people died and 99 have been hospitalized in a cholera outbreak in northern Zambia, provincial officials said Thursday. The deaths occurred since Monday near the town of Mbale, 630 miles north of Lusaka, the Zambian capital, said district governor Lightwell Sibale. He said police erected roadblocks to stop non-essential traffic leaving affected areas. Cholera is an infectious intestinal disease caused by poor sanitation and bad hygiene. Earlier this year, cholera killed more than 200 people in the densely populated urban areas of Lusaka, Kafue and Kabwe.

DOC.HEAD: European Parliament Calls For Gladio Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The European Parliament on Thursday called for an investigation into the activities of secret anti-communist organizations set up in the 1950s to counter a possible Soviet invasion of Western Europe. In a resolution passed by a vote of 65-41 with 13 abstentions, the Parliament Ealso asked the 12 EC governments to look into possible links between the network of secret groups and right-wing terrorism in Europe over the last two decades. The resolution urged the governments to undertake a ``full investigation into the nature, structure, aims and all other aspects of these clandestine organizations.'' The network was organized by West European intelligence agencies to carry out sabotage and surveillance in case of a Soviet invasion. It involved hundreds of operatives with access to extensive caches of weapons, according to recent disclosures by West European officials. Some officials have suggested that the organization, called ``Gladio'' after its Italian code name, was involved in right-wing terrorism during the 1970s, especially in Italy. The Parliament, the European Community's assembly, condemned the network, which it said had ``escaped all democratic control.'' Some government leaders said they knew nothing about the clandestine groups in their countries. The Parliament called on EC governments to dismantle any remaining ``clandestine military and paramilitary networks.'' The assembly urged EC governments to examine the network's ``composition and modus operandi and to clarify any action they may have taken to destabilize the democratic structures of the (EC) member states.'' The resolution singled out the United States for special criticism, protesting ``vigorously'' against the efforts of U.S. officials ``to encourage the establishment in Europe'' of such a network. Some Christian Democrats in the Parliament voted against the resolution to avoid criticizing members of their party in power in many West European countries when such networks were set up.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Falls Under Wheel of Tractor Driven by 6-Year-Old Sister
DOC.TEXT: A 21-month-old boy died in his father's arms after falling under a wheel of a tractor being driven by his 6-year-old sister, who regularly helped out on the family farm, authorities reported. Matthew Dragt apparently was trying to get into the driver's seat when he fell Wednesday, said his father, William Dragt, 32. ``He'd try once in a while to drive,'' he said. ``Apparently, he decided he wanted to really drive, but he ended up on the ground and it rolled over him.'' Dragt told Tulare County sheriff's deputies that his daughter, Rachel, often drove the tractor while he stood on a trailer tossing hay to their cows. Dragt said he often had his three children - Matthew, Rachel and 4-year-old Daniel - with him while he did the chores on their dairy farm 150 miles north of Los Angeles. ``They loved to be with me when I fed the cows; that was one of their greatest things,'' Dragt said. ``My oldest girl usually drives for me. She goes real slow.''

DOC.HEAD: With Thatcher's Demise, US Loses Its Staunchest Ally
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For almost a decade, Margaret Thatcher was regarded at the White House as America's best friend, the trusted ally whose strong views reinforced the conservative tone of administration policies. Among Western allies, she was alone at Ronald Reagan's side in 1986 in supporting the U.S. bombing of Libya. In the Persian Gulf crisis, she boldly joined with George Bush in sending troops to the Middle East. ``You always know where she was and what she believed,'' Bush said upon hearing of her decision to resign. ``She has always been an outstanding ally of the United States,'' he said. ``I will miss her.'' There were many doubters around the world when Reagan arrived in Washington with an economic program of free-market capitalism that seemed out of step with the times. Mrs. Thatcher wasn't one of the skeptics; she was advocating a similar program at home. They shared rocky relations with organized labor. Reagan successfully fired the nation's air traffic controllers, dealing a devastating blow to labor. She, too, smashed restive unions. On foreign policy, she frequently was more right wing than Reagan - certainly more so than Bush. Reagan never made any secret of his special affection for the British prime minister. They were ideological soulmates and called each other Ronnie and Margaret. At international gatherings, they usually were side by side. Two years ago as they met for the final time before Reagan left office, the president said he was leaving the White House with ``considerable satisfaction in the knowledge that Margaret Thatcher will still reside at No. 10 Downing Street.'' She later wrote him a ``Dear Ron'' letter in which she praised him as ``a great president, one of the greatest.'' Like Reagan, she was deeply suspicious of the Soviet Union. Together they advocated a hard line toward Moscow and championed military readiness - even though she was the first to recognize Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a leader she could do business with. Mrs. Thatcher encouraged the huge Pentagon buildup that Reagan nurtured under the theme of peace through strength. She was a big backer of U.S. efforts to install medium-range missiles in Europe and always seemed cautious - perhaps reluctant - when it came to disarmament. When Argentina and Britain clashed militarily over the Falkland Islands, the United States was forced to make a painful choice between two allies. Ronnie sided with Margaret. Washington's special relationship with London seemed to slip when Reagan left power. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher disagreed publicly last year over her government's decision to deport Vietnamese and Cambodian ``boat people'' who were fleeing their countries to Hong Kong. Bush, a veteran of world politics, knew many leaders around the globe. Mrs. Thatcher suddenly seemed to be just one of the gang. The Berlin Wall was collapsing and it appeared as if Bush found German Chancellor Helmut Kohl more interesting than Mrs. Thatcher. She was merely one in a parade of foreign dignitaries who got the prized invitation to visit Bush at Camp David this year. Nevertheless, Bush said he expected the ``special relationship'' between the United States and Great Britain to remain on a ``steady keel.'' Mrs. Thatcher did her part, demonstrating her loyalty. For awhile she and Bush were seemingly alone in their suspicions of Gorbachev's unilateral cutbacks in troops and arms in Europe, and appeared uncertain how to respond. Under intense pressure from Congress, Bush began to warm to the Soviet leader. Now they seem almost best of friends. On the Persian Gulf, Bush said he would not rule out possible military force, and ordered a huge buildup of troops to make his threat credible. Mrs. Thatcher, characteristically, was tougher. She said that unless Saddam Hussein got out of Kuwait soon, the West would have to use military force to dislodge him. She called Saddam ``a loser,'' and the state-controlled Iraqi news agency replied that she was an ``old hag.'' Now, she is leaving. No one suspects that Britain's new leadership - whoever it is - will take a soft line toward Iraq. Yet, if the going gets tough, it might have been comforting for Bush to be able to hear the tough old line from Thatcher.

DOC.HEAD: `Now That She's Gone, Where Do We Find a Leader?'
With AM-British-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: On the streets of central London, Britons were suprised and even shocked at Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's abrupt resignation Thursday. Some people cheered and some were saddened. But young or old, male or female, white collar or blue, nearly everyone expressed surprise that the woman who is as much a British institution as the corner pub was suddenly gone. ``It was quite a shock, I suppose. I didn't think she would quit. All I could think when I saw the newswoman announcing it on TV this morning was that this was truly a historic day,'' said Christine Scott, 49, a school administrator on her way to lunch on Fleet Street. The prime minister's resignation filled radio and TV airwaves throughout the day, but many people first heard the news on their way to work. ``I was on the elevator in the Hampstead tube station when a woman came dashing on and said, `That's it, Maggie's gone, she resigned,' and everyone cheered. They also read an announcement on the loudspeaker in the underground,'' said Elizabeth Gore, acting head of the language department at the City Literary University in Bolton Court. Bus company inspectors hopped on the city's red double-decker buses to announce the resignation. The pilot of a British Airways flight from Paris to London relayed the news from the control tower at Heathrow Airport to passengers. ``I'm very sad,'' said Sonya Davis, a manager at British Telecom, waiting for a friend outside the Temple tube station. ``At least she knew what she was doing. ... I thought she'd stay for a fight. It's a bit daunting to know she has given up.'' Some people worried that without Mrs. Thatcher no one was guiding the ship of state through the turbulent waters of the Persian Gulf. ``The only person happy today is Saddam Hussein,'' said Charles Lord, a 60-year-old clerk at the Bank of England. Behind the Old Bailey, several young lawyers said they were more than ready for a change. ``I'm very pleased. It's great, somebody else will now have a chance and that's very good for the country,'' said Angus Charlton, a 25-year-old lawyer in a Savile Row suit. ``Now the Tories have to reunify, to paper over the cracks that this leadership fight has created.'' Many of those happy to see her go, expressed a tinge of regret. ``It's a shame really, because she did lots of good things,'' said Michael Davies, a 27-year-old taxi driver. ``But in the last couple of years she has just gone too far.'' Davies, like many other people, listed the poll tax as a major cause of Mrs. Thatcher's decline in popular support. ``There's no way to alienate a person faster than taking money out of his pocket,'' Davies said. ``There's the poll tax, that's what will kill the Tories. She also dismantled the national health so I now have to buy private health insurance. ``Between one thing and another, she has cost me a couple of thousand quid (pounds) this year and that's a lot of money for a working person.'' The poll tax replaces a tax on property owners and is paid by every adult. Davies said he liked Michael Heseltine, the former defense minister who challenged Mrs. Thatcher for the party leadership and garnered enough support on Tuesday to precipitate her resignation. None of the dozen people interviewed expressed much liking for the two men who entered the race after Mrs. Thatcher resigned - Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd or Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major. ``One of the things I liked about Maggie was that you felt she could cope with anyone and anything in the world. She could stand up to anybody,'' said Mrs. Scott. ``I don't feel that way about any of the others. Now that she's gone, where do we find a leader?'' Claude Musselwhite, a retired businessman walking near Westminster Abbey, said that while he felt sad, ``it was probably time. Still, there has never been anyone like her and there may never be again.''

DOC.HEAD: Peru's Congress Gives Initial Approval to Issuing New Currency
DOC.TEXT: The House of Deputies has approved issuance of a new currency to replace the ``inti'' introduced almost six years ago. The bill approving the creation of the ``nuevo sol'' will now be presented before the Senate, which is expected to approve the project. One nuevo sol will equal one million intis. The new currency is expected to be issued in January. It takes its name from the ``sol,'' the currency in circulation at the time the inti was first issued. At present, about 440,000 intis are needed to buy a dollar. When first introduced, it took about 6 intis to purchase a dollar. Since taking office July 28, President Alberto Fujimori has imposed harsh measures aimed at eliminating hyperinflation, which has run at nearly 10,000 percent over the past 12 months. Monthly inflation in October fell below 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Warns of Travel to Sudan
DOC.TEXT: The State Department cautioned U.S. citizens on Thursday to postpone non-essential travel to Sudan, where large demonstrations against the United States and in favor of Iraq have taken place. ``Although these demonstrations were orderly and kept under control by government security forces, the situation could change quickly,'' the department said. The department said it has authorized voluntary departure of dependents of U.S. government personnel in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital. ``Private citizens whose presence is not essential should consider leaving as well,'' the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Released Iraqi POWs Arrive Home
DOC.TEXT: A total of 279 Iraqi prisoners of war released by Iran arrived in Baghdad on Thursday, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. Their arrival followed the release by Iraq and return to Tehran the previous day of 238 Iranian POWs. This was the first exchange between the two countries in nearly two months. The exchanges started in mid-August after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein abruptly agreed to all Iran's conditions for a peace treaty to formally end the 1980-88 war between them. He was apparently seeking peace on his eastern border while trying to consolidate his hold on the oil-rich Arab emirate of Kuwait, which he invaded on Aug. 2. The prisoner exchanges were suspended by Iraq without explanation Sept. 20, after 37,000 men had been repatriated. The International Committee of the Red Cross said 25,000 men remained interned, without giving a breakdown. The exchange started again following last week's visit to Baghdad by Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati. He was the highest Iranian official to visit Iraq since Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Determined To Be Nuclear Power - Question Is When
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is on a crash program to become the first Arab state to have nuclear weapons, but experts differ on how close the Iraqi arsenal is to being ready. President Bush told U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia Thursday their mission was marked by ``a real sense of urgency'' because of President Saddam Hussein's progress in acquiring nuclear arms. But, he added, ``No one knows precisely'' how near Iraq is to becoming a nuclear power. Some analysts in Israel, which tracks the Iraqi program very closely, estimate Saddam is two to five years away from producing atomic warheads for his extensive missile stockpiles or building a nuclear bomb he can drop from a fighter jet. Other experts put the timetable at 10 years away, especially if the program has been set back because of the international trade embargo against Iraq. ``Iraq could have a nuclear weapons production capability within 10 years,'' said Mike Eisenstadt, author of a report on Iraq's nuclear, chemical and biological capabilities issued recently by the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. ``If it receives help from abroad ... it could be producing nuclear weapons within as little as five years,'' said Eisenstadt, who also serves as a civilian analyst for U.S. Army Intelligence. The Iraqi program got its start with help from France, which sold two nuclear reactors to Baghdad in 1976 for the production of electricity. But Israel, citing intelligence information, said Iraq was using the reactors to produce nuclear weapons with the help of 150 pounds of enriched uranium supplied by France. The substance is essential for exploding nuclear weapons, and Israel has reportedly obtained sufficient amounts to produce its own nuclear arsenal. In 1981, Israeli fighter planes bombed the Iraqi nuclear facility outside Baghdad. Israel drew international condemnation, but the Iraqi program was brought to a standstill. The enriched uranium that was left over from the French shipment - estimated at about 27 pounds - was placed under the safeguards program of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty of which Iraq is a signatory. That means inspectors from the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency periodically inspect the material to make sure Iraq isn't diverting it for weapons production. The next inspection is scheduled next week, and although the results generally remain classified, U.S. experts have said Iraq's willingness to allow the inspection indicates it has not diverted the material. Nonetheless, State Department officials say Iraq could have acquired other uranium which is not under the inspection program. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, according to Eisenstadt's report, Iraq acquired 250 tons of uranium ore concentrate from Brazil, Portugal and Niger. This material is not weapons-grade but could have been used to extract plutonium - another essential component in a nuclear weapon, said Eisenstadt. In 1987, Iraq revived its nuclear program, experts say. Rather than rebuilding the bombed reactor, Iraq decided to acquire a gas centrifuge device for enriching uranium, according to experts and press reports. Brazil and Pakistan, both burgeoning nuclear powers, have reportedly used this method successfully but it took each of them about a decade to have operational centrifuges. Iraq could use the uranium ore concentrate, which is not subject to IAEA inspection, to power the centrifuge which produces enriched uranium, experts say. Work on the Iraqi project is reportedly being conducted at the Saad 16 facility near the city of Mosul, at another site in a mountain near Irbil, and at the Tuwaitha nuclear center outside Baghdad. West German firms, taking advantage of their country's formerly loose export restriction laws, were instrumental in helping Iraq's gas centrifuge project. So were China, Pakistan, and - inadvertently - several American and British firms. Last year, U.S. customs agents seized vacuum pumps bound for Iraq from a Rochester, N.Y. company, saying the Iraqis could have used them in their nuclear program. British customs agents, acting on a tip from U.S. officials, earlier this year seized a shipment of krytons to Iraq. Krytons are used to detonate nuclear weapons. After the seizure, Saddam announced his country could produce the devices on its own. In addition to the concentrate uranium, known as yellowcake, Iraq may also be trying to extract the metal from a mine in the northern part of the country. Recent Soviet satellite pictures have found an industrial operation, including new roads and two excavation sites, in the Gara mountains, 40 miles south of the Turkish border, according to the respected Jane's Defense Weekly.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Tree Growers Push Environmental Angle
DOC.TEXT: Christmas tree growers are trying to capitalize on America's newfound environmental awareness, touting their evergreens as the responsible alternative to plastic ``petrochemical trees.'' ``Real trees are recyclable; they're biodegradable,'' said Jeanne Weiss, assistant director of public relations for the National Christmas Tree Association in Milwaukee. Plastic trees ``are made out of oil byproducts,'' Weiss said Tuesday. On the other hand, some environmentalists point out that chemicals often are used on real trees, and that plastic trees at least are reusable. Artificial trees for several years have held a steady 50 percent share of the holiday market. Even so, Weiss forecasts shoppers will buy 36 million cut Christmas trees this season - a $341 million business for wholesalers. Michigan, the nation's largest commercial tree producer, will cut about 7 million trees this year. In 1988, the national Christmas tree growers group put $1 million into a television advertising campaign playing on the nostalgic charm of cut trees. This year, Weiss said, ``with all that publicity about Earth Day, we thought that should carry over to Christmas.'' The environmental tactic is part defense. Weiss said she often sees comments such as: ``buy an artificial tree and save a real tree.'' ``That is not what we want to see,'' said Weiss. The association has an armory of Christmas tree trivia for its campaign: -For every tree cut, three are planted, most on land where other crops fail. -Most trees sold in the United States are grown here while artificial trees come from places like Hong Kong or Taiwan. -The nation's approximately 1 million acres of Christmas trees supply enough oxygen for 18 million people. Those trees also absorb carbon dioxide, one of the gases warming the Earth through the ``greenhouse effect.'' But a real Christmas tree doesn't necessarily mean an environmentally safe tree, said Jane Elder, Midwest representative for the Sierra Club in Madison, Wis. She said Christmas tree buyers should be aware that most live trees are sprayed with a variety of chemicals, even paint. ``There are questions they should ask: Was it grown with herbicides or pesticides or sprayed with dyes or other chemical additives that will add to the pollution stream? ... You get into the question of is it worth it for a tree that is just slightly more emerald green,'' she said. Buyers should also consider how they'll dispose of the tree, Elder said. ``If you are going to buy a petrochemical Christmas tree and keep it for your lifetime and pass it down to your grandchildren, then I suppose that, too, is environmentally sound,'' she said. Pesticides and other chemicals are as much a part of the Christmas tree industry as other agricultural products, said Michael Gabrione, general manager of M. Walter Christmas Trees, Inc., in Chicago. The company has Christmas tree farms from Michigan to Nova Scotia and ships trees across the country. ``If we have to have totally organic Christmas trees, everybody in the Christmas tree industry is going to be in big trouble,'' Gabrione said. ``People aren't going to get the same kind of product they are used to.'' Walter Christmas Trees follows industry practice and paints its Scotch pines green. Otherwise, the trees would have a yellowish cast and, Gabrione said, ``people expect a Christmas-tree green color.'' The paint also helps the tree retain moisture after it's cut. Weiss couldn't say what chemicals are commonly used by Christmas tree growers. Neither could Laurie Dornbush, executive director of the Michigan Christmas Tree Association. ``It's something we want to look at,'' Dornbush said Tuesday from her office in Okemos. She's interested in finding out what kind of chemical residues are left on trees by the time they wind up in living rooms or as garden mulch.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Extremists Kill 16 Bus Passengers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with one report saying 25 were killed; pickup 5th pvs, `Thursday's attack...'
DOC.TEXT: Suspected Sikh gunmen on Thursday ambushed three buses, killing at least 16 people in the attacks outside the capital of Punjab state, news agencies reported. United News of India said the attacks took place near Paroll village outside Chandigarh, 150 miles north of New Delhi. The United News of India said state police chief K.P.S. Gill confirmed 16 deaths. Several people were injured, Gill was quoted as saying. Another news agency, Press Trust of India, quoted unnamed police sources as saying that 25 people were killed. PTI said militants forced passengers ``of a particular community'' to get off the buses and killed them. The phrasing indicated the victims were Hindus. Indian news media do not identify the religion of the victims in such attacks believing that it will exacerbate communal tensions. The reports said Gill had rushed to the site and details were not immediately available. Thursday's attack was the latest in a series of mass killings by Sikh extremists who are fighting to set up an independent nation in the northern state, a rich farming area bordering Pakistan. In the last major attack, Sikh gunmen killed 13 people Tuesday evening in a crowded market in Amritsar, the holy Sikh city and the center of the separatist campaign. At least 170 people have died in Punjab in the last 10 days in militant attacks. Victims have included bus passengers, people doing morning exercise, farmers and members of security forces. United News of India said 11 other people were killed by Sikh extremists in the state Thursday in separate incidents. It did not give details. More than 2,900 people have been killed in Punjab this year by the militants who have been waging the insurrection since 1982, complaining their community is disriminated against by the Hindu-dominated government. Sikhs are in a slight majority in Punjab but nationwide form only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-ANC Homeland Resists Coup Try, Charges South African Involvement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to CORRECT that coup leader is white; Pickup 5th, `Holomisa, whose...'
DOC.TEXT: A band of white and black rebel army troops mounted a failed coup attempt today in the black homeland of Transkei and 17 people died in the fighting with loyalist forces, reports said. Military ruler Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa told a rally late Thursday in Transkei's capital, Umtata, that the coup attempt had been put down, the independent South African Press Association reported. Holomisa said the leader of the uprising, former Holomisa aide Craig Duli, was dead, the agency said. There was no independent confirmation of the report. Telephone lines to Transkei were cut later in the afternoon and there was no answer at the Transkei Embassy in Pretoria. Holomisa said the coup attempt was headed by Duli, a former member of the military council, and involved about six whites and a handful of black troops. Duli is black and had been Holomisa's chief of military intelligence. Holomisa, whose government has ties with the anti-apartheid African National Congress, said earlier that he suspected the South African government might have been involved in the coup attempt. South African Foreign Minister Pik Botha denied any South African effort to topple the government in the homeland of 2.75 million people, which covers three areas scattered in southeastern South Africa. Homomisa said in addition to Duli, 11 co-conspirators died in battles with government soldiers who surrounded the building in Umtata where the rebels had taken refuge. The press agency said five government soldiers were also killed. Earlier, South African diplomats in Umtata said fighting broke out about dawn when the rebels tried to seize key government buildings in the city. Umtata is about 370 miles south of Johannesburg. The Press Association said it appeared fighting began at an army base on the outskirts of Umtata and the rebels later attempted to seize government buildings in the city. ``Early this morning, there were shots that were heard in parts of Umtata,'' said South African diplomat Gert Terblanche, reached by telephone in Umtata. Diplomats said roadblocks were put up across the city. Local journalists said there was scattered gunfire and a number of government soldiers were taken to hospitals. South African press reports said the airport at Umtata came under heavy mortar fire. Terrified civilians tried to leave parts of Umtata to escape fighting, according to reports from Transkei. Holomisa and the army seized power in Transkei in 1987 and set up a government that has ties with the ANC, the main black opposition group in South Africa. Duli helped Holomisa seized power, but the two had a falling out later and Duli had been imprisoned until recently on charges of possessing weapons. The Transkei military had a few white officers when it was set up. It is one of four nominally independent black homelands set up by the South Afican government in the 1970s and 1980s as part of a plan to create separate states for blacks under the apartheid system of racial separation. No country other than South Africa recognizes the independent homelands, most of which have been pressing for reintegration into South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Key Events in Thatcher's Political Career
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronology of key events in British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's political career: --- 1958 - Elected to the House of Commons, representing the north London suburb of Finchley. 1961 - Appointed a deputy minister for Pensions and National Insurance, serving until 1964. 1970 - Appointed education secretary in Cabinet of Conservative Prime Minister Edward Heath, serving until 1974. Feb. 11, 1975 - Defeats Heath in contest for leadership of the Conservative Party, then in opposition. May 4, 1979 - Becomes prime minister when Conservatives win parliamentary majority in general election. April 2, 1982 - Argentine forces invade the Falkland Islands, claiming the British colony as their own. Britain sends a naval task force and reclaims the South Atlantic islands June 14-15 after the Argentines surrender. The war cost 255 British lives and 650 Argentine. July 9, 1982 - Begins second term as prime minister after Conservatives win general election. March 12, 1984 - The National Union of Mineworkers, opposing plans to close 20 unprofitable mines, begins a strike that lasts 51 weeks - the longest and most violent strike in British history and a watershed in Mrs. Thatcher's effort to crush union power. Oct. 12, 1984 - Mrs. Thatcher escapes injury as Irish Republican Army bombs her hotel in Brighton during the Conservative Party conference. Five people are killed and 31 injured. March 3, 1985 - Miners vote to return to work without a settlement. Jan. 6, 1986 - Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine resigns from Cabinet in dispute over American-led takeover of Westland PLC helicopter manufacturer. Heseltine sought a British-European rescue bid. June 11, 1987 - Leads Conservatives to election victory, becoming the only prime minister of the 20th century to win three elections consecutively. Oct. 26, 1989 - Nigel Lawson, chancellor of the exchequer, resigns following conflicts Mrs. Thatcher over the monetary policy. Nov. 1, 1990 - Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe, a former foreign secretary and the last of Mrs. Thatcher's original Cabinet, resigns over her stance toward European union. Nov. 13, 1990 - Howe tells House of Commons that Mrs. Thatcher is jeopardizing vital British interests and dividing the government. Nov. 14, 1990 - Michael Heseltine declares his challenge for leadership of the party and the prime minister's job, Mrs. Thatcher's first serious challenger after 15 years at the helm of the party and more than 11 in power.
