Nov. 20, 1990 - Mrs. Thatcher fails to defeat Heseltine outright in a party leadership election, forcing a second round. Nov. 22, 1990 - After talks with supporters, Mrs. Thatcher announces her resignation, effective after the election of a new party leader. She also dispatches 14,000 more British troops to the Persian Gulf, bringing Britain's component of the U.S.-dominated international force to more than 30,000.

DOC.HEAD: Train-Bus Crash Kills 19 In Ukraine
DOC.TEXT: A train and bus collided on a railway crossing in the Ukrainian city of Donetsk on Thursday, killing at least 19 people and wounding 13, Tass reported. The official Soviet news agency said the bus tried to cross the railway tracks in front of the oncoming train, ignoring red lights and signals from a railroad workers. The bus driver was not hurt in the collision, Tass said. The Railway Ministry is investigating, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Hollywood High Band Finally Invited To Hollywood Christmas Parade
DOC.TEXT: The Hollywood High School marching band, once so bad the chamber of commerce banned it from playing in the Hollywood Christmas Parade, returns this year with snappy new uniforms and renewed spirit. On Sunday, the band will join other bands, floats and performers in the 1990 parade after an eight-year absence. It has been a long road back to respectability for the band, which at one point lacked enough members to form the ``H'' in Hollywood. ``This is going to be our crowning glory,'' said band director Joe Montgomery. ``Two years ago, we had seven people.'' The band now boasts 99 members, although only 50 will participate in the parade. For all its progress, the band has only enough red-white-and-silver uniforms to outfit half of its members. The band has not played in the parade since 1982. The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce, which sponsors the event, said the band failed to measure up to parade standards. The school's exclusion from the parade had been a source of embarrassment. For decades, the band traditionally led the parade. Eighty percent of Hollywood High's 2,000 students are immigrants who struggle with English and work after school to help support their families. ``They had so many ethnic groups, no one wanted to play an instrument. ... All they wanted to do was study,'' said parade chairman John Golden. Montgomery was undaunted by the diversity and language barriers when he took over as director three years ago. He quickly began recruiting musicians. Among those marching in the parade Sunday will be a Chinese trumpet player, a Vietnamese drummer, a Hungarian drum majorette, an Armenian bell player and a Salvadoran saxophonist. Montgomery said the band has no intention of resting on its laurels. ``Next year,'' he said, ``we would like to lead the parade.''

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Food For Soviets Available But Shouldn't Be Needed - Yet
DOC.TEXT: There is no evidence of widespread hunger in the Soviet Union, one of the world's biggest grain growers, and a food aid program shouldn't be necessary this year, U.S. officials say. ``They produce an awful lot of meat and potatoes,'' one analyst said. Germany already has pledged food aid to the Soviets, and President Bush said in Paris this week he ``would want to try to help...if there's a real need there.'' Canada, Italy and Spain all have extended bank credits and in some cases pledges of other assistance to help the beleaguered Gorbachev government. The United States and other Western countries may join forces to feed the Soviet people if starvation appears imminent, but U.S. specialists in Soviet agriculture, economic and political affairs said in interviews this week there is no evidence at this point of genuine need. ``Food aid shouldn't be necessary this year,'' said one highly placed State Department official, who discussed the situation on condition he not be identified. ``The countryside appears to have food. The agricultural regions of the Soviet Union and the cities in those regions appear to have food. Moscow and Leningrad, while obviously not an overflowing cornucopia, have food.'' The grain harvest was exceptionally good this year, milk production is at record levels and meat could exceed last year's levels. Potato output is down, but not to a critical point. ``There is a problem for those on fixed incomes who cannot supplement their diets by shopping every so often at the rinok,'' or private farmers' market, the official said. ``But basically, even those people are getting along. We don't have any evidence of significant or widespread hunger, imminent starvation or anything like that.'' John Hardt, a Soviet affairs analyst with the Library of Congress, said the key to any assistance program should be setting conditions and imposing discipline to ensure that the Soviets implement the transition to a market system that Gorbachev has promised. Experts say the Soviet Union alone can solve the main problem, a distribution system unable to deliver food to those in need. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher likened a Soviet aid program to pouring money down a hole. ``Clearly, it's mostly a political consideration, not a nutritional or an economic consideration,'' one U.S. source said. ``The Germans offering food aid put some pressure on the rest of us to show the same kind of concern, but it's exasperating because it's their (the Soviets') problem to solve, and they're not taking the necessary steps.'' The U.S. administration's political concerns were evident in Bush's remarks in Paris, where he joined Gorbachev and the leaders of 32 other nations to formally put an end to the Cold War. ``We would always be open-minded on humanitarian aid if there's a real need there,'' the American president said, adding: ``We want to try to help with the evolution of market systems and the evolution - the change that's taking place. And you also want to help new friends when you find them, if they're in jeopardy.'' U.S. officials expect critical shortages to show up first in heavily industrialized cities in the Urals, where food production was actively discouraged for decades, and in the Far North, where farming is limited by the frigid climate. Those areas, as well as the largest and once-privileged cities of Moscow and Leningrad, are most dependent on a distribution system that, notoriously wasteful in the best of times, is now collapsing. Collective and state farms and authorities in agricultural regions simply refuse to honor state-imposed contracts that require them to sell a certain amount of their products to the All-Union Fund for distribution to other parts of the country. The Soviets did increase wholesale food prices in September and October in an attempt to restock the All-Union Fund and provide commodities for the cities. U.S. observers say the move had some impact but was offset by the precipitous decline in the value of the ruble and the determination of farms and local officials to horde products for themselves or trade them directly for consumer goods. As a result, Moscow, which under the old system always enjoyed the best of what was available because it was the center of political power and influence, is now in worse shape than many other areas. But an experienced State Department official said, ``I personally find it difficult to believe the American taxpayer would support substantial amounts of food assistance to a country that just had the greatest bumper crop in history and which exports food to other countries unless there's really starvation.'' The Soviet Union not only sells some food abroad, the official noted, but gives food relief aid to Ethiopia. Asked if a relief program would serve the secondary goal of shoring up the Gorbachev government, the official said, ``If it comes to providing U.S. assistance, it will be when things have reached a dire state of affairs, and in that situation, it's difficult to believe there will still be much of a Soviet government left to worry about.'' In 1921, when famine and civil war swept the fledgling communist state, the United States launched an ambitious program to relieve the disaster that eventually killed an estimated 3 million people. ``We ran soup kitchens, we had an elaborate distribution scheme, we took food in trucks, in donkey carts, in horse-drawn carts, dog sleds, whatever it took to reach starving people,'' the official said. ``We might not do something that elaborate this time, but we should take steps to make sure the food gets to the people who really need it.''

DOC.HEAD: Yemen Rejects Baker Request For Support On U.N. Resolution
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III was rebuffed Thursday in efforts to get Yemen, the only Arab nation on the U.N. Security Council, to support a resolution authorizing the use of force to oust Iraq from Kuwait. Yemen's president, Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh, standing next to Baker, criticized the military buildup in the region and called for an Arab solution to the crisis. ``Of course, we don't support the presence of foreign forces in the region,'' he said at the end of two hours of talks with Baker at his residence in the Yemeni capital of San'a. Saleh said the foreign troops have ``complicated the problem, rather than solved it.'' Baker was the highest ranking American official to visit Yemen since President Bush made a trip in 1986 when he was vice president. He flew to San'a from Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, where Bush was spending Thanksgiving with some of the 230,000 American servicemen in the region. Yemen, a poor country on the southwestern tip of the Arabian peninsula, has gained prominence in the gulf crisis because of its current seat on the U.N. Security Council. In December, it will assume the council's presidency, now held by the United States. Any resolution giving advance authority to use military force against Iraq would have to be approved by the 15-nation Security Council. Saleh, when asked whether he would support such a statement, was interrupted by his foreign minister, Abdul-Karim al-Iryani, who said, ``There is no resolution.'' A State Department official, asked later about the Yemeni position, replied, ``They didn't say no.'' Yemen has abstained from voting on five of the 10 resolutions passed by the Security Council against Iraq since its Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait. Baker said both governments prefer a peaceful end to the crisis. But, he said, ``we find some differences of opinion as to what the best method of achieving a peaceful political solution ( would be).'' Later, the State Department official, demanding anonymity, said Baker was ``not disappointed or discouraged by the visit.'' `We knew it was going to be a very tough nut,'' the official said. Baker, in response to questions from local reporters, said the United States wanted to bring its troops home as soon as possible. But, he said, Saddam was a brutal dictator who wanted to develop a nuclear weapons capability. ``This man must be stopped.'' The State Department official also said Baker has raised with Saudi officials concerns about the recent expulsion of hundreds of thousands of Yemeni workers from the kingdom. Saudi Arabia, apparently angered by Yemen's sympathy for Iraq, has cancelled special privileges for Yemeni workers and traders, forcing them to have a Saudi sponsor to do business in the country. No such requirement previously existed. Before starting his talks, Baker took an hour-long stroll through the Old City of San'a, a tangle of narrow streets dating back 2,500 years. Hundreds of Yemenis, many wearing a traditional dagger strapped to their waists, pushed in the crowded market area to get a glimpse of him. Friendly merchants offered Baker a taste of the raisins, nuts, coffee and other food displayed for buyers. Baker, who was escorted by Iryani, even rubbed his fingers on the green leaves of qat, a mild narcotic that local residents sometimes chew to induce euphoria. After his talks, Baker returned to Jiddah where he was to meet with Saudi officials on Friday. Efforts to arrange a meeting with Malaysian officials while in the region fell through. Malaysia also is a member of the Security Council. He will travel next to Bogota, Colombia, to meet with President Cesar Gaviria. Colombia is another council member.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia's Communist Party Shuffles Top Body
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's Communist Party on Thursday elected a new slate of leaders for the third time in less than a year, reflecting fast-paced political changes in the Soviet-bloc nation. The party also reaffirmed Mongolia's close ties to the Soviet Union and warned that anti-Soviet sentiment, now openly and widely expressed, is not in Mongolia's own best interests, China's official Xinhua News Agency reported. ``Mistakes in the past should not be exploited as excuses for opposing good-neighborly relations with the great neighbor (and) publishing various slanders against the Soviet Union,'' Xinhua paraphrased the Mongolian party as saying in a statement. Xinhua filed its dispatch from the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, where the Mongolian party's Central Committee has been meeting. The party's formal name is the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party. Mongolia is sandwiched between the Soviet Union and China. Xinhua said the Central Committee appointed five new members to the party's six-seat top body, the Presidium. It first removed three Presidium members for unspecified work-related reasons, while a fourth, N. Michigdorg, already had resigned to become ambassador to Moscow. Xinhua did not mention the two other members of the old Presidium, party chairman Gombojavyn Ochirbat and L. Tudev, director of the party newspaper Unen. They apparently retained their seats, pushing the Presidium size to seven members. The Presidium, formerly known as the Politburo, sets basic policy for the party, which has ruled Mongolia for nearly seven decades. It ruled by terror for much of that time, but allowed multiparty elections in July for the first time ever and won a majority in the legislature. New opposition parties also made a strong showing and now fill several key government posts. Mongolia's dramatic changes began in March, when the party bowed to months of popular demonstrations. It appointed a new party leadership, headed by Ochirbat, and renounced its monopoly on power. A second shuffle was made a month later, when the party replaced most of its Central Committee with younger, pro-reform members. The new appointments continue the trend. The oldest of the five is Budragchagyn Dashyonden, 44, the party secretary for Ulan Bator city. Earlier in the party Central Committee session, Ochirbat acknowledged that Mongolia's economic situation is worsening, Xinhua reported. Production has dropped while prices and unemployment have risen, it said. One reason for Mongolia's economic woes is a sharp reduction in Soviet financial aid and trade as Moscow tries to grapple with its own serious economic problems. Many Mongolians blame Moscow in part for the economy's basic weaknesses, including a weak manufacturing base. For decades, Mongolia exported raw materials to the Soviet Union in return for finished products. The example of Soviet glasnost helped accelerate Mongolia's movement toward democracy, and ironically made it possible for the first time for Mongolians to openly express their resentment of Soviet economic, military, political and cultural dominance.

DOC.HEAD: Small Dent Found in Alaska Pipeline; To Be Repaired Next Week
DOC.TEXT: A small dent was discovered in the trans-Alaska pipeline during an investigation of allegedly shoddy inspection work, officials said. But the reinspection of pipeline sections originally tested for corrosion and cracking by Thorpe Technical Service has turned up nothing that implicates Thorpe, said Alyeska Pipeline Service Co. spokeswoman Marnie Isaacs on Wednesday. Alyeska officials, not Thorpe workers, were responsible for making visual inspections of the pipe for flaws like the dent, Isaacs said. Fired Thorpe employee Edward Thompson prompted the investigation more than a month ago by alleging that he and other workers were untrained and pipeline flaws were covered up. Plans to boost the pipeline's flow have been put off until the investigation is complete. The dent, less than an inch across, will be repaired next week, Alyeska officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Serious U.S. Malady In Desert on Thanksgiving: Homesickness
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A woman reservist broke into tears saying grace at Thanksgiving dinner and recalling loved ones at home. A tough sergeant said the holiday meant nothing without his family. A truck-load of soldiers, spotting reporters at an air base just after President Bush left, shouted: ``Why are we over here? This ain't our war. Send us home.'' In the desert of Saudi Arabia, there was a serious American malady this Thanksgiving: homesickness. There were no complaints about the turkey, stuffing, sweet potatoes or pie but it wasn't mom's or grandma's, and it had to be chowed down in about 30 minutes maximum so another of the 230,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf could get a seat at the table. ``I'm very homesick right now,'' said Pfc. Tracey Jackman, 19, of Corry, Pa., as she helped put up orange Thanksgiving decorations and remembered wintery holidays past with her parents. Minutes later, she burst into tears. ``Get this meal over with - I'll feel a lot better!'' shouted Sgt. Donald W. Engelhardt, 31, of Ft. Bragg, N.C., an Army cook with the 25th Signals Battalion who was carrying whole turkeys from the kitchen to the dining room to be used for decoration. ``Thanksgiving don't mean nothing to me because I don't have my loved ones with me,'' he said. ``If you weren't putting out so much for a meal, you wouldn't feel so bad. I'm very homesick.'' Sgt. Donna Hogg, 32, of Beverly Hills, Calif., who was the nanny for television personality Ed McMahon when her National Guard unit got called up, broke down as she said grace at a table with five fellow reservists. ``We miss our families. We wish we could be with them,'' she said, her voice cracking with emotion, ``...and we hope that they are as blessed as we are today.'' Her unit, the 1113th Transportation Co., from Sacramento, California, had all spent a near-sleepless week getting the ingredients for Thanksgiving dinner to military kitchens across the country. ``It's a lot more work - that's about it,'' said Spec. Clint Myers, 19, of Duncan, Oklahoma, who was chopping lettuce for Thanksgiving salad in a tent at a desert field kitchen, and thinking about happier holidays watching football games with his grandfather. The soldiers in the truck who shouted at reporters near the base that they wanted to go home were voicing the widespread sentiment of many troops who missed seeing Bush during his seven-hour whirlwind visit. ``He sent us all over here,'' said Sgt. Engelhardt. ``If we're going to go to war, let's go to war. If we're going to go home, let's go home.'' Sgt. Hogg said: ``We shouldn't be here. I figured we agreed to defend our country, not to go defend oil and all that stuff. That's ridiculous.'' Army Sgt. Cedric D. Clay, 32, a food service officer with the Army's 80th Ordinance Division, whose wife in Tacoma, Wash., is expecting their first child any day now, said he hoped the confrontation with Iraq could be settled without bloodshed. ``There's too many gung-hos out there,'' he said. ``A life is something very precious. I just hope this thing gets settled really fast because this is a dangerous situation.'' The U.S. military got high marks for trying to bring Thanksgiving to the desert, and make servicemen feel close to home, even if they didn't always succeed. Sgt. Lacey Santee, 25, of Sacramento, Calif., said the troops should look at every holiday as special, no matter where they are. ``You've just got to think your family is going to be with you no matter where you're at. That's how I think of it,'' she said. ``I figure if I'm eating this now, they're eating at the same time, or somewhere around there, they're having a turkey dinner, so it's like I'm almost with them. So that makes it a lot better.''

DOC.HEAD: Leathernecks Pause to Give Thanks With Turkey Supper in the Sand
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines sang ``America'' and bowed their hatless heads in silent prayer Thursday before tasting their Thanksgiving turkey among the lengthening shadows in the Saudi desert. Clusters of men from Headquarters and Service Co. of the 1st Battalion, 5th Infantry Regiment, stacked their weapons and ate their supper sitting in the sand shaded by their HUMVEE trucks and military vehicles. They consumed their special meal without presidential fanfare, without football and without the company of loved ones thousands of miles away. But they gave thanks just the same. ``We got to be thankful we haven't gone to war yet, and we pray there's a peaceful solution to all this,'' said Lance Cpl. Steve Soukup of Coeburn, Virginia. Just before the Marines queued up in chow line for their turkey treats, more than a few of these desert-hardened troops choked back tears when Chaplain Paschal Dawson led them in a chorus of ``America'' and offered a prayer. ``One of the things we have to be thankful for is we live in America,'' said Dawson, a native of Homer, Louisiana. ``Although we're here, it's not the end of the world. We're here to do what we got to do.'' Because it was a holiday, most of the Marines had light duties and took advantage of their free time to play volleyball, pitch softballs, wrestle in the sand and write letters home. Coincidentally, it was the unit's 100th day in the desert. ``It's a small price to pay when you're one of the world's finest,'' said Lance Cpl. Eddie Simpson of Sligo, Pennsylvania, who was showing off his pet scorpion named ``Taz.'' ``Marines are funny,'' said 2nd Lt. Tim Nichols of Sterling, Virginia. ``They bitch a lot. It's hot. The scorpions stink. The wild dogs come around in the morning. But we'll stay out here as long as we're needed.'' The dinner came from a field kitchen of the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force, probably the largest field kitchen in the Marine Corps since World War II. Cooks got up at 3 a.m. to begin preparing 12,000 fresh turkey dinners. About 3,000 troops deployed closest to the Kuwaiti border had to settle for the military version of turkey TV dinners. They cooked 2,500 pounds of turkey, a ton of ham, 34 cases of shrimp, 34 cases of potatoes and handed out over 1,800 pies. They also distributed 2,000 cases of soda pop, enough for each Marine to get two cans. One of the dinners cooked here was delivered to President George Bush, who dined with another unit. They didn't hear Bush's speech and they couldn't watch football because the vast majority have no TVs. There were no parades and no liquor, but there were plenty of flies and desert heat. ``You can't be mad because you're away from home,'' said Corpsman Donnie Henderson, 23, of Milwaukee, Wisconsin. ``Besides, the Marine Corps is our family.'' Out in the field, 1st Sgt. Alonzo Sledge of Memphis, Tennessee, was able to phone his family back in the states and attend battalion church services. He was also standing by his horseshoe pit if the president had decided to come by and toss a few ringers. ``Everyone should be thankful we're alive to see this day. And we're free,'' said Sledge, a 20-year veteran of the Corps. ``Lots of people take things for granted that Marines feel are special.'' If there were regrets at being away, they were balanced by duty. ``People would be fools not to want to be home for Thanksgiving and Christmas. But we got a job to do,'' said Cpl. Ed Walsh, 21, of Las Vegas, Nevada. ``I'd rather be with the Marines. It's where I belong. They don't care if you eat your salad with the wrong fork,'' Walsh said. But he had a tug from home because his mother sent him a cassette tape this week that said: ``Thanksgiving's going to be rough because I won't have you to taste the stuffing to see that it's just right.''

DOC.HEAD: Britain to Send 14,000 More Troops to Persian Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain announced Thursday it was nearly doubling its troops deployed in the Persian Gulf, sending 14,000 more soldiers to join the 16,000 already in the region. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher moved to send more troops to the gulf on Thursday, at the same Cabinet meeting at which she was warned she would lose her bid for the party leadership and thus leadership of the country. She later announced her resignation. Mrs. Thatcher has been an implacable opponent of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, and her party indicated her policies in the gulf would be continued. Former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine, who challenged Mrs. Thatcher for the party leadership and prompted her resignation, expressed his firm support for the new deployment. ``It was essential that the military capablity of (the British) force have total credibilty,'' he said. ``The announcement you have made this afternoon carries the wholehearted and unanimous support'' of all Conservatives. The new deployments would make the British troop commitment to the multinational forces in the region the second-largest behind the United States, which has sent 250,000 and promised another 100,000. Defense Secretary Tom King went before the House of Commons to explain the deployment. ``It remains the government's firm objective to resolve this crisis as soon as possible and by peaceful means,'' he told lawmakers. ``To do this, it is essential to establish a credible offensive military option. ``Saddam Hussein must be made to realize that he is faced with a military force that will otherwise compel him to withdraw,'' King said. At least 26 nations have contributed troops to the multinational effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait, which Saddam Hussein invaded Aug. 2 in a dispute over land, oil and money. The additional troops bring the strength of the 1st Army Division to 25,000 and total British forces committed to the Gulf to 30,000, King said. The 4th Brigade, currently stationed in Germany, division headquarters and supporting arms will join the 9,500-strong 7th Armored Brigade to form the 1st Armored Division, he said. The additional brigade will include an armored regiment of Challenger Tanks, two armored infantry battions with Warrior fighting vehicles, an armored reconnaissance squadron, a Royal Artillery field regiment, engineers and other supporting services. The government is sending anti-tank Lynx helicopters and the army's most potent artillery system, the Multiple Launch Rocket system, King said. The system is capable of rapid fire over long range and will be able to counter Iraq's G5 howitzers. King said he discussed the new troop deployment in meetings last week with Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, who welcomed the news and offered to help provide food, fuel, trnsport and accomodations. The announcement coincided with the resignation of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who sat behind King as he addressed the House of Commons. There was concern that Britain's domestic political problems not damage the effort to drive Iraqi occupation forces from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 170 Passengers Survive Plane Crash In Siberia
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet jetliner overshot an airport runway in Siberia, breaking both wings and seriously damaging its landing gear, but none of the 176 passengers was injured, Soviet media reported Thursday. The accident occurred late Wednesday as the Ilyushin-62 flying from Moscow tried to land at Yakutsk, the government newspaper Izvestia said. First reports from Soviet television Wednesday night said 176 people were killed when the Aeroflot plane crashed at the airport, 2,600 miles east of Moscow. It gave no source for its information. But Izvestia said the plane landed in a ravine about one-half mile beyond the runway. It said the passengers were taken to the airport terminal, and 20 suffered bruises. One woman was treated in hospital for unspecified injuries, it said. Radio Moscow and other media reported Thursday that the airplane lost both wings in the crash as well as parts of its undercarriage. Most media reports said 176 people were aboard but did not say how many crew were on the plane. Valentin Popov, an inspector at the airport, said there were 174 passengers aboard and a crew of 10. Marina Potapova, a shift supervisor at the Magan Airport in Yakutsk, also said 174 passeners were aboard and that nobody was killed in the accident. Ms. Potapova said by telephone that many of the passengers continued on to their destinations. She did not know whether there were any foreigners on board. She also said that the plane was in one piece. The independent Postfactum news agency also reported the crash and said there were no injuries. It said the aircraft collided with ground installations and was seriously damaged. Both Popov and Ms. Potapova said the plane had been diverted to Magan, the city's second airport, because of poor visibility at the main Yakutsk airport.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Science Couple Asks Court For Sentence Reduction
DOC.TEXT: A Christian Scientist couple convicted of manslaughter in the death of their 2-year-old son have has asked for a sentence reduction, charging that their probation is disruptive and unconstitutional. Lawyers for David and Ginger Twitchell filed a memorandum Wednesday in Suffolk Superior Court seeking to reduce the couple's 10-year probation to five years and to eliminate regular medical checkups for their children. The Twitchells were convicted July 4 of involuntary manslaughter for relying on spiritual healing to treat their son Robyn, who died of a bowel obstruction on April 8, 1986. The Twitchells have appealed the verdict. Judge Sandra Hamlin had ordered the Twitchells, who now live in Brentwood, N.Y., to take their three remaining children for periodic checkups by a physician and get them immediate medical attention if they showed signs of serious illness. Hamlin also ordered maximum probation supervision. New York officials believe that means the Twitchells must meet twice a week with a probation representative, Twitchell attorney Stephen Lyons told the Boston Herald. ``I don't think Judge Hamlin intended the probation to be that intrusive,'' Lyons said. In an affidavit filed with the court, Mrs. Twitchell, 34, said her two youngest children have had medical checkups and the oldest has an appointment this week. ``Our life as a family would be less disrupted and more calm if the number of probation visits were reduced and if such visits were at our home only or if we could have the conversations regarding medical care by telephone,'' she said. The Twitchell children range in age from 1 to 9 years old.

DOC.HEAD: More Troops Sent To Armenia-Azerbaijan Border To Stop Fighting
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Thursday sent troops to beef up border posts along the troubled border between the southern republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia after four days of ethnic-inspired shootings, Tass reported. The official Soviet news agency said Armenian gunmen armed with heavy-caliber machine guns, trench mortars and flame-throwers stolen from Soviet army depots have fired on border posts and several villages inside Azerbaijan. A total of two Azerbaijanis and five Armenians have been reportedly killed. Armenians and Azerbaijanis have been clashing for nearly three years over control of Nagorno-Karabakh, a mainly Armenian region inside of Azerbaijan. More than 220 people have been killed. Soviet Interior Ministry troops have repeatedly been dispatched to restore order. Tass did not say how many troops were sent Thursday, but it reported that 20 additional soldiers were dispatched Wednesday. As many as 29,000 troops have been stationed in the area. ``The concentration of (government) forces on a small section of border between the two Transcaucasian republics was necessary to stop Armenian gunmen,'' Vyacheslav Ponomarev, deputy commander of the Interior Ministry troops, told Tass. He said the gunmen fired for four days on several villages in the Lachin district of Nagorno-Karabakh and on border posts in the mountainous Goris district of Armenia. ``The border posts are located in the most dangerous areas of the terrorists' activities,'' Ponomarev was quoted as saying. ``We believe that this terrorist action had been thoroughly planned.'' Tass quoted Viktor Polyanichko, second secretary of the Communist Party of Azerbaijan, as saying that Armenian gunmen ``are destabilizing the situation in the region. Therefore it is necessary to act resolutely, efficiently and consistently in combating them.'' Polyanichko said 53 people, including children, have been killed in Lachin since the ethnic violence broke out in February 1988. In an attempt to end this dispute, and other ethnic violence, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued a decree in July ordering all outlawed guerrilla groups to turn in their weapons and disband, The decree was largely ignored. Despite strict laws prohibiting gun ownership, the use of illegal weapons is a growing problem in the Soviet Union. Many weapons are stolen from police stations and military bases or sold by Afghan veterans.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Uneasy About Bush-Assad Meeting
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel indicated Thursday it was troubled by President Bush's plans to meet Syrian President Hafez Assad and unhappy that Israel was not a stop on the president's Middle East visit. Syria has long been one of Israel's most intractable enemies. It has one of the biggest Arab armies and sponsors guerrilla groups that engage pro-Israeli forces in battle in southern Lebanon. The new concern surfaced amid strains in U.S.-Israeli ties over Israel's policies in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``I think to the extent that questions arise in Israel over the meeting between President Bush and Hafez Assad, they are about the fact that for the past few months ... senior Americans are visiting the region,'' but not Israel, Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said. ``We aren't offended by this,'' Arens said in a speech at Tel Aviv University, but added pointedly: ``One can easily see that misunderstandings could arise of the fact that President Bush travels to Arab countries in the region...but prefers not to visit Israel.'' Arens also said there was ``a gap in perception between us and the United States'' regarding Syria. ``In Israel we don't feel such a big difference'' between Assad and Iraq's Saddam Hussein, he said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was more circumspect in expressing concern. ``We only hope this meeting between Assad and the president of the United States will not encourage an aggressive policy by Syria toward Israel,'' he said. But Shamir also suggested Israel understood Bush's need to reinforce an Arab coalition against Iraq. ``We must look at the meeting tomorrow with Assad on this background,'' he said in an interview with state television and radio. Shamir is also facing some difficulties in arranging a White House meeting on his upcoming visit to Washington, Israeli reports said. They suggested the United States was anxious to avoid offending its Arab allies in the anti-Iraq coalition. Some Israeli editorial writers were also critical of the United States. ``The American disregard for Israel ... is infuriating and insulting. It creates a deception for the Arabs that after the Persian Gulf crisis is over the new coalition will be able to march together toward Jerusalem,'' said the daily Hadashot.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Shakes Peruvian Coast North Of Lima
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake rocked the Pacific coastline north of Lima on Thursday, the Geophysical Institute said. No serious injuries or major damage were reported. The temblor, measuring 4.9 on the Richter scale, was centered 170 miles north of Lima, the institute said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage in populated areas. On May 29, an earthquake registering 6.3 on the Richter scale killed 135 people in the jungles of northern Peru. Quakes are a frequent occurrence in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Security Laid on for U.S. President's Visit
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian security agents sealed off parts of an eastern suburb Thursday as President Bush began an 18-hour visit in Cairo. The measures were the tightest in memory for a visiting head of state. Hours before the president and Mrs. Bush arrived, rangers armed with automatic rifles conducted anti-terrorist drills at Cairo International Airport where the president's Air Force One was to park. Police with dogs patrolled the airport. Other security agents warned residents along the six-mile motorcade route to the palace where the Bushes were staying to shutter their windows, close their curtains and stay indoors as the official motorcade passed by. Hundreds of uniformed and plainclothed policemen lined the motorcade route, and four helicopters clattered overhead. A security helicopter hovered near the airport terminal where President Hosni Mubarak and his wife welcomed the Bushes. About 50 cars trailed the two presidential limousines as the motorcade set out for the Kubbah presidential guest palace. All roads leading to the palace had been sealed off by security forces two hours earlier. The palace, the residence of Egypt's last monarch, King Farouk, is in a 70-acre garden surrounded by thick concrete walls 13 feet tall with watch towers at the corners. Not all the security arrangements proved effective. Residents living along the motorcade route said they largely ignored the orders to stay indoors, opening windows and standing on balconies to watch the procession. Two hours before the Bushes arrived, army rangers with automatic rifles and wearing fatigues carried out an anti-terrorist drill on the tarmac where Air Force One was to land. About 20 rangers repeatedly rushed toward a man apparently representing Bush, surrounding him and facing outward to protect him from imaginary terrorists.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Across Northwest, And From Texas To New York
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell from Texas to New York in advance of a strong cold front Thursday, and the soaked Northwest got more rain and snow. At midday, the cold front extended across north-central Ohio, south-central Indiana, southeastern Missouri and south-central Oklahoma to central Texas. Ahead of the cold front, rain extended from western New York state across western Pennsylvania, western West Virginia, Ohio, southeastern Indiana, Kentucky, western and central Tennessee, northwestern Mississippi, and central Arkansas. Rain and occasional thunderstorms reached across southern Arkansas, northern Louisiana, southeastern Oklahoma and from northeastern Texas to the Texas Big Bend region. Flood warnings were posted for sections of eastern Texas after locally heavy rain overnight that included 5.5 inches at Wills Point, the National Weather Service said. Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., reached 56 degrees just after midnight, tying the city's high temperature record for November, but then the cold front moved through and the temperature dropped to 40 degrees by 5 a.m. Traverse City, Mich., warmed to 63 during the early morning, a record for the date, then cooled to 44 before daybreak. In the Northwest, rain fell over western Montana, the Idaho Panhandle, Washington and northwestern Oregon, with snow at higher elevations. Snow also fell in the mountains of west-central Wyoming. Washington's Snoqualmie Pass got 2.5 inches of rain from 3 a.m. Wednesday to 3 a.m. Thursday, enough to melt snow on the road over the pass. Warm rain also melted 3 inches of snow cover at Mullan, Idaho, during the morning. Flood warnings were posted for sections of rivers in western Washington. High wind blew across the Northwest and northern Rockies, with gusts during the morning to 92 mph at Rustic, Colo.; 80 in Wyoming near Laramie, Cheyenne and Wheatland; 75 at Squaw Mountain, Colo.; 71 near Hanford, Wash.; and 60 at Cody, Wyo., and Wenatchee, Wash. In eastern Washington, several highways were closed by wind and blowing dust, and trees were downed by high wind near Spokane and at Rockford, Idaho, the weather service said. Elsewhere at midday, showers were scattered over southern Florida, and light rain fell over east-central Minnesota. Thursday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 5 above zero at Gunnison, Colo.,and Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 28 at Warroad, Minn., to 87 at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Leaders Pay Tribute To Mrs. Thatcher's Courage
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's international admirers praised her courage and achievements Thursday after she announced she would resign. Even her foes tempered scorn with praise for a formidable adversary. Said President Bush, ``I will miss her.'' He called her ``an outstanding ally of the United States,'' adding, ``You always knew where she was and what she believed.'' Vitaly Ignatenko, spokesman for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, told the independent Interfax news agency: ``Political, economic and cultural ties between our countries have become of greater importance'' in the Thatcher era. ``Our relations ... were marked by constructivism and dialogue.'' The reluctance Mrs. Thatcher showed toward increasing European unity was the source of most criticism. But in a joyful and unambiguous response, Iraq saw the Persian Gulf crisis as cause of her downfall. Bitterness was undisguised in the comment from Argentina's Nicanor Costa Mendez, foreign minister during his country's 1982 Falklands War with Britain. ``I can't say that it makes me sad,'' he said. ``I believe that the extreme positions - unnecessarily extreme, unjustifiably extreme - of the prime minister were one of the causes of the war, and one of the biggest impediments to achieve agreement after.'' Socialist President Mario Soares of Portugal singled out ``her systematic opposition to the advances of the European Community.'' ``During her long mandate,'' he said, ``the preoccupations of social justice receded many times before purely development objectives, causing a climate of discontent in British public opinion to which Mrs. Thatcher appeared insensitive.'' But Soares also lauded the British prime minister as a ``determined politician (who) took courageous positions on critical occasions in international life and without doubt marked an era in the contemporary history of her country.'' German Finance Minister Theo Waigel noted, ``Despite her critical position on some questions of European integration, she accomplished a great deal for European politics.'' A neutral letter from Socialist President Francois Mitterrand of France told Mrs. Thatcher she had ``marked an important moment in the history of your country and that of Europe.'' Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said growing opposition to her hard line against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait ``buried Mrs. Thatcher'' just as the 1956 crisis over Britain's attack on the Suez Canal ruined former Prime Minister Anthony Eden. Britain stepped in after Egypt nationalized the canal. On Thursday, Britain announced it was nearly doubling its troops deployed in the gulf as part of the multinational force arrayed against Iraq, sending 14,000 more soldiers to join the 16,000 already in the region. South African President F.W. de Klerk praised Mrs. Thatcher, who opposed sanctions on South Africa, for standing up to world pressure and standing by Pretoria. ``She had faith in South Africa's ability to solve its problems in a democratic way ... She had the courage of her convictions,'' he said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel saidafter hearing of her resignation that Israel ``feels a moment of sorrow because we all know this special personality, Mrs. Thatcher, who did many things and was an outstanding leader.'' Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan said the British prime minister ``is a rare leader of firm convictions who was invigorated the United Kingdom and I feel great regret that she has withdrawn from the front line.'' Belgium's prime minister, Wilfried Martens, applauded ``the determining role she played during more than 10 years in her own country and on the international scene.'' Said Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia, ``Even those like myself who have been at odds with Margaret Thatcher on particular issues have admired her courage and tenacity of purpose. ``Whatever the forces arrayed against her, she was always prepared to pursue with the utmost vigor those positions in which she believed.'' Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers said, ``In the many years that she placed such an important stamp on the policies of the United Kingdom, Mrs. Thatcher has shown that she does not avoid making difficult decisions that she deems to be in the nation's interest. This, too, is such a decision which deserves respect.'' Former French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, now a legislator in the European Parliament, said Mrs. Thatcher's decision to quit was ``dignified and courageous.'' ``Margaret Thatcher will be seen with Winston Churchill as the greatest British prime minister of the last 50 years. The curtain has fallen on the Iron Lady. She deserves our congratulations.'' Even European Commission President Jacques Delors, Mrs. Thatcher's archenemy in Europe, spoke of his ``high esteem'' for her, despite their differences. Alfred Dregger, parliamentary leader of Germany's governing Christian Democratic Union, said Mrs. Thatcher played a major role in securing Western solidarity in the ``historical conflict for freedom and democracy. We thank her for that.'' Former President Reagan spoke with great warmth of his closest foreign ally. ``Margaret Thatcher's resoluteness played a key role in ending the Cold War,'' he said. ``She stood up to the Soviets and let them know she meant business. Her deep and abiding dedication to the principles of liberty and democracy served as an inspiration to oppressed peoples everywhere who knew that Margaret Thatcher would never waver in her belief that all men and women are entitled to live in freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Resigns, Criticizes Colombian President
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Alfonso Gomez resigned Thursday following public criticism for his punishment of an army general involved in fighting leftist rebels. In an angry letter to President Cesar Gaviria, Gomez objected to criticisms of officials who battle to maintain democracy. Gomez came under fire this month after ordering the removal of Gen. Jesus Armando Arias, who led the army in a bloody battle against the leftist guerrilla group M-19. M-19 rebels took over Bogota's Palace of Justice in 1985, and subsequent fighting with the army claimed about 100 lives, including half the justices on Colombia's Supreme Court. The attorney general's office said Arias's troops unnecessarily killed dozens of civilians in routing the rebels. It said Arias failed to protect the lives of hostages held by the M-19. Although Gomez had talked of resigning since August, the Arias controversy appeared to expedite his exit. Army officers and right-wing politicians criticized the attorney general for ``punishing a defender of society.'' They said former subversives were being unjustly praised. In the years since the Palace of Justice clash, the M-19 has renounced armed struggle and become a legitimate political party. Opinion polls indicate the M-19 will receive more votes than any other party for seats in an upcoming assembly to reform Colombia's constitution. In his resignation letter, Gomez said politicians are using the Arias case for their own electoral ends. M-19's leader, Antonio Navarro, called the decision to punish Arias inopportune because it revived past controversy at a time his group needs support for the constitutional assembly. Members of congress rejected the decision to sanction Arias, who retired from active duty four months ago. After the decision, they voted him a symbolic promotion.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Rifles Taken Off Store Shelves
DOC.TEXT: Toy AK-47 assault rifles have been withdrawn from sale at two major shopping chains in New Zealand in the wake of the Aramoana massacre that left 14 people dead. The Cargo King stores have removed their stock of about 2,000 toy rifle replicas from shelves, saying it would be insensitive to offer them for sale. Cargo King managing director Wally Brewer said the store had offered the plastic AK-47 replicas the past three or four Christmas seasons and they had been a big seller. The recalled stock was likely to be ``thrown away,'' he said. Woolworths, with 52 outlets, has also withdrawn the toy rifles. Last week, David Gray used a Chinese-made AK-47 rifle and other weapons during a rampage in the village of Aramoana on New Zealand's South Island, killing 13, including three children, before being fatally shot by police.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Los Angeles-dated item in AM--People, a0560, to fix TV husband's occupation to restaurant owner sted construction foreman.
DOC.TEXT: Tony-award winning actress Patti LuPone, who plays Libby Thacher on the ABC series ``Life Goes On,'' gave birth to her first child, Joshua Luke. The 8-pound, 1-ounce boy was born Wednesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said publicist Ellen Gonzalez. Miss LuPone, 41, is also portrayed as pregnant on ``Life Goes On'' until the end of the show's second season. In the series, Miss LuPone plays a working mother with a husband who runs a restaurant and a son with Down's syndrome. In 1989, Miss LuPone played Florine, the wife of Boolie in the Oscar-winning movie ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' The actress won a Tony for her role in the musical ``Evita.'' She is married to assistant cameraman Matt Johnston.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Militia Agrees to Withdraw from Beirut
DOC.TEXT: The Lebanese Forces Christian militia agreed Thursday to withdraw from east Beirut to allow the government to create a militia-free capital and reunite Beirut after 15 years of civil war. Druse and Shiite Moslem militias already have pulled out of districts they controlled in the combat-scarred city of 700,000 people. Samir Geagea, commander of the 6,000-strong Christian force, said he set no deadline for the evacuation to allow the government to decide how soon it will be able to fill the security vacuum created by withdrawal. ``We have agreed to withdraw,'' Geagea said in an interview broadcast by his TV station, the Lebanese Broadcasting Corp. ``We will pull out at a moment's notice once the government readies the army force that will take over from us to avert a security vacuum.'' ``The government will have to set the deadline,'' Geagea said. Defense Minister Albert Mansour said earlier Thursday, ``Implementation of the greater Beirut plan will start today. ``It will be an Independence Day gift for the Lebanese people.'' Mansour spoke to reporters after a modest military parade in Moslem west Beirut to mark 47 years of independence from France for this nation of roughly 3.5 million people. The decision marked a change in attitude by the Lebanese Forces, the Christians' main fighting machine in the civil war against Moslems. The militia had defied a government order to withdraw by last Monday, Nov. 19. Geagea explained that the government ``has given us solid guarantees to prevent any reprisals in east Beirut after we pull out.'' He had demanded assurance that his Christian rival, Elie Hobeika, would not move into east Beirut once the Lebanese Forces leave. Hobeika's militiamen and Syrian-backed irregulars moved into the eastern suburbs after Lebanese army units backed by a Syrian army contingent crushed an 11-month rebellion by Gen. Michel Aoun in an eight-hour battle on Oct. 13. A Lebanese Forces official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the retreat to the hinterland several miles north and northeast of Beirut ``could be completed in a day or two.'' He would not speculate on when it might begin. Greater Beirut stretches along a 15-mile coastal strip from the Dog River in the north to the Damour River in the south. President Elias Hrawi told the nation over television Wednesday that ``greater Beirut is coming and no one will be able to prevent its emergence.''

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Denies Its Bank Held Shares in Drug Company
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican on Thursday denied a German television report that its bank once held shares in a drug company producing birth control pills. However, a spokesman at the Geneva headquarters of the pharmaceutical company Serono, named in the report, said the Vatican did have shares in its Rome subsidiary in the 1960s and possibly early 1970s. The spokesman, Cristophe Lamps, however, denied the company made birth control pills. ``We're just the opposite. We are the leader in fertility'' treatment, Lamps said in a telephone interview. The Vatican vigorously prohibits its faithful to use any form of artificial birth control. The pope recently urged Roman Catholic pharmacists not to sell drugs that directly or indirectly hurt life. The German television report Wednesday night on private station RTL Plus alleged that the church received financial gain from the sale of birth control pills while the Vatican bank held a majority of shares in Serono. The report alleged that Serono began producing birth control pills in 1968, the year the Roman Catholic Church staunchly laid out its opposition to artificial contraceptive methods in Pope Paul VI's encyclical ``Humanae Vita.'' The report said the Vatican bank, formally called the Institute for Religious Works (IOR), sold its shares in Serono in 1970 to a Milan-based bank, in which it held a 20 percent stake. ``The IOR never possessed shares in the cited pharmaceutical company (Serono), something that would be without a doubt be contrary to the aims of the Institute,'' Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said in a written statement. When told the Vatican had denied its bank had held shares, Lamps said he didn't know which specific agency of the Vatican held the shares. Lamps said he could not say whether the Vatican holdings in Serono had constituted a majority. Navarro could not be reached for further comment. Lamps said similar reports linking the Vatican and Serono have surfaced in the past.

DOC.HEAD: Laundry Worker Killed After Accidentally Falling Into Dryer
DOC.TEXT: A commercial laundry worker was killed when he was apparently knocked into a huge dryer by 100 pounds of wet clothing. Alfredo Castro, 31, was preparing to clean the dryer Wednesday night when a pile of wet laundry came down a shuttle belt and somehow knocked him inside the machine, police said. Castro was trapped inside the dryer at the H & L Association for its six-minute cycle and ejected when it was completed, police said. Co-workers heard a loud thumping noise coming from the machine, then spotted bloodstained clothing and eventually Castro's body being ejected. He was pronounced dead at Boston City Hospital. William Day, controller for the association, said he did not know why the machine was on. ``Oh, God, this is a tragedy,'' he said. Police said they believe the death was an accident.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Soviet Leader May Not Accept Nobel Prize in Person
DOC.TEXT: Advisors to Mikhail S. Gorbachev indicated Thursday that economic and political problems at home may prevent the Soviet president from collecting his Nobel Peace Prize in person, Norwegian television reported. NRK television correspondent Hans-Wilhelm Steinfeld reported from Moscow that Gorbachev's staff had discussed Thursday whether the president should travel to Oslo, Norway, on Dec. 10 to collect the prize. Steinfeld said an adviser to Gorbachev told him that ``if Gorbachev does not come it is because of the troubles at home.'' He did not identify the adviser or give other details. Previous reports have suggested Gorbachev might not stay the usual three days in Norway that peace prize winners normally spend to attend a banquet and give a speech. But Gorbachev did say, when he was awarded the prize last month, that he would come to Oslo to receive it. Norwegian Foreign Department spokesman Bjoern Blokhus said there had been ``no word or indication'' from Moscow that Gorbachev was reversing his plans to come to the prize ceremony. The Soviet embassy in Oslo has gotten no word from the Kremlin, said an official who declined to give his name. Gorbachev said during his visit to the Conference on Cooperation and Security meeting held in Paris this week that his schedule for early December was not yet set. Blokhus said Norway's foreign minister, Thorvald Stoltenberg, had raised the issue of Gorbachev's schedule with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze during the summit in Paris. Norwegian security officials, preparing the most extensive safety measures they have ever contemplated, have said it is difficult to plan if they don't know when Gorbachev is coming, how long he is staying and which events he will attend. ``Shevardnadze said Norway would be informed about the extension of the visit within a few days,'' Blokhus said.

DOC.HEAD: Betting Odds Narrow on Tories with Thatcher's Resignation
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Thatcher's resignation improved her Conservative Party's odds in the next general election, British bookmakers reported Thursday. But the Tories still trail the Socialist Labor Party at the bookmakers. The next election must be held by mid-1992. Betting giant William Hill offered odds on a Tory victory of 11-10. On Wednesday the odds had been slightly longer at 5-4. The Labor Party has led the Tories in opinion polls for more than a year. Bookmakers Ladbrokes said one London bettor lost $39,400 that he placed on Mrs. Thatcher to win the Conservative Party leadership struggle.

DOC.HEAD: Thanksgiving A Day For All Manner of Events
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after the 6th, ``At parade,'' to update with recovery of balloon and Philadelphia parade. INSERTS 2 grafs after the 12th graf, ``This is the worst,'' to add Texas town celebration, Seattle.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Roundup, Bjt
LaserPhotos NY20 and WX11
DOC.TEXT: Thanksgiving 1990 was a day for some to run a grueling marathon while most of us sat down and ate too much. Many wolfed down turkey but a few fed the birds a treat. Restaurants fed the homeless for free. And Bart Simpson barged down Broadway. And in the midst of the good times and celebration, it was a day of tears for some whose loved ones were in the Middle East. Television gave most of the country an armchair view of the 64th Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade in New York with its marching bands, floats and helium-filled cartoon character balloons. More than 1 million people lined the streets to watch the parade with many of the youngsters cheering a huge figure of underachiever Bart Simpson. Things didn't go quite so smoothly in Detroit, where a 30-foot-long, $15,000 helium balloon of ``Chilly Willy'' the penguin broke away late Wednesday and floated away. At parade time Thursday, a pilot spotted the flightless bird at an altitude of about 5,000 feet over Detroit, said Bill Robertson, control tower manager at Windsor Airport, across the Detroit River in Ontario. The Coast Guard recovered it later in Lake St. Clair, 45 miles north. Thousands of people also lined downtown streets in Philadelphia to watch bands, floats, giant balloons and more than 5,000 marchers under a warm, clear sky. ``There's a lot of good spirit here, plus it's a perfect dy for a parade,'' said Bill McColgan, 32, of Levittown, Pa. Kermit the Frog returned to the New York parade in honor of Muppets creator Jim Henson, who died this year. ``Kermit makes me sad,'' said New Yorker Paul Oppold, 27, who lost his smile when the green frog was tugged into view. At the end of the parade, about 20 AIDS activists unfurled banners that read: ``4,752 AIDS Deaths 'till Christmas'' and ``Ask Santa Claus for National Health Care.'' While people stood on the curb to watch in New York, and others put their feet up in front of the tube, about 30,000 people donned sweatsuits and thundered off on the Atlanta Track Club's annual 26.2-mile marathon. The route they followed is the one recommended for marathon events when Atlanta is host to the 1996 Summer Olympics. Thanksgiving was a little sadder in coastal Georgia, where families of soldiers sent to the Persian Gulf with the 24th Infantry Division kept each other company. ``My husband called last night. It was fantastic,'' said Brenda Mustoe of Savannah, whose husband, Victor, is a chief warrant officer with the division. However, ``This is all I've been doing today - crying,'' she said. ``This is the worst thing in the world,'' said Judy Rachell, of Belleville, Ill.; two of her three children are in Saudi Arabia. Mrs. Rachell said she at first didn't want to prepare a Thanksgiving dinner but her husband insisted nothing be different. ``So I'm preparing the meal and I plan to set places for my sons.'' A 77-year tradition continued in the hamlet of Vattman, Texas, where Thanksgiving is a community rather than family event and locals and outsiders turn out for a picnic and games and dancing. ``I'm so elated. It's so grand. I couldn't ask for anything nicer,'' said Teddy Marie Wallace during a brief lull in serving the midday dinner crowd. In Seattle's Occidental Park, Mayor Norm Rice and the Strand Helpers served a noontime turkey meal to more than 200 homeless people. Denver restaurateur ``Daddy'' Bruce Randolph cooked for 100,000 in his 29th annual Thanksgiving free feast for the needy. Randolph said he had plenty of food. ``There are no cutoffs in the number of people who can come to dinner,'' he said. At Al's Place in Tulsa, Okla., proprietor Al Beck provided free breakfast for about 500 people. ``I got just a little bit tired of these people coming by here hungry all the time,'' said Beck. ``I saw 'em eating out of the Dumpster. You've know you have some problems when that happens.'' Some Arkansas residents benefited from the work of an Oklahoma City program. About 75,000 pounds of turkey, chicken, canned vegetables and cookies were distributed to 2,000 people in the towns of Dumas, Wright and Eudora by the Feed the Children program of the Larry Jones Ministries. ``Whoever had something to do with it, they done something good for Eudora because we have a hard time here,'' said Eudora resident Indiana Birt, who is in her 80s. She had expected her Thanksgiving meal to consist of sweetbread and leftover chicken wings. In Florida, volunteers at the Miami Rescue Mission prepared 1 ton of turkey meat, 1,000 pounds of dressing, 45 cases of potatoes and 40 cases of string beans for the homeless and needy. Turkey wasn't the main attraction everywhere. About 25 turkeys had the table all to themselves at the Farm Sanctuary, a 175-acre refuge in Watkins Glen, N.Y., where unwanted farm animals can live out their lives. A turkey's table manners are strictly for the birds, said Blanche Kent, the farm's shelter manager. ``They peck at each other's plates,'' Kent said. ``They're excited by all the colors, especially the red in the cranberries. And they love pumpkin pie.''

DOC.HEAD: 200,000 Sheep Killed in Australian Bush Fires
DOC.TEXT: Officials said Thursday that as many as 200,000 sheep may have been killed after a series of bush fires that also destroyed 395,000 acres of valuable grazing land. The Department of Agriculture in New South Wales said the fire in the southwest area of the state known as the Riverina affected 20 major property owners. The blaze, which began Wednesday morning, was contained by late Thursday after firefighters from neighboring communities and volunteers from Sydney assisted in the fighting the fire. In early December, killing of surplus sheep - approximately 10 percent, or 20 million - of Australia's stock, is scheduled to begin. The slaughter will involve mostly old stock in an attempt to cut down on an oversupply of sheep brought on by lower wool prices, high interest rates and poor mutton sales. The 200,000 sheep killed in the fire were considered prime stock and would not have been considered for the slaughter, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer and Gunman Dead in Shootout
DOC.TEXT: A police officer and gunman were killed in a shootout Thursday when a SWAT team stormed a house to arrest a man wanted for wounding another officer earlier in the day. The shootout erupted when Prince William County Police SWAT team members arrived Thursday morning at the home of Mark Francis Arban, sought in the shooting of a sheriff's captain during a traffic stop about six hours earlier. When Arban refused to open the door, police broke it down with a battering ram, said Prince William police Sgt. Barry Bernard. A shot was fired as police entered the house, but Bernard said it was not known who fired it. ``Several minutes passed - I'm not certain how long - then there was another exchange of gunfire,'' he said. Arban, 31, and Philip Michael Pennington, 35, an 11-year veteran of the Prince William force, were fatally wounded, said Bernard. Arban died inside the house, where he lived alone in this city about 20 miles south of Arlington. Pennington died in a hospital emergency room. Police were trying to determine how many shots had been fired, Bernard said. Police carried what appeared to be semiautomatic rifle out of the house, witnesses said. Arlington County Sheriff's Capt. Daryl Laclair, 36, was shot in the face and left elbow shortly after midnight as he approached a car on a busy county highway, said authorities. The motorist had motioned for the captain to pull over. Laclair was hospitalized in satisfactory condition Thursday, a hospital official said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Investigating Fire, Explosions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last 2 grafs with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comment from base spokesman..
DOC.TEXT: A truck carrying 21 tons of military explosives caught fire, setting off several blasts and closing a major highway for 9{ hours, authorities said. No injuries were reported in the fire and explosions Wednesday on a military truck traveling on Highway 95 about 160 miles northwest of Las Vegas, said Nevada Highway Patrol Sgt. Mill Marquardt. The highway, the main route between Las Vegas and Reno, was closed until Thursday morning, Marquardt said. ``We had the Fourth of July out there for a while,'' he said. Military authorities described the cargo as Class A explosives, said Marquardt. The 18-wheel tractor-trailer was loaded with 81mm mortar rounds being shipped from the Sierra Army Depot in Herlong, Calif., to the East Coast, said Maj. Greg Kreis, spokesman for Nellis Air Force Base in Las Vegas. Kreis did not know the ammunition's ultimate destination. Military officials were investigating the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Thatcher Resigns, Leaving Party Torn by Succession Struggle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 24 grafs to UPDATE with no-confidence vote outcome, ADD Thatcher accomplishments, other. Picks up 23rd graf, On Tuesday ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON1,4,5,6,8,20,23,NY8
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called it quits Thursday, leaving her nation transformed by 11{ years of Thatcherism and her party torn by a bitter and potentially destructive struggle for succession. The ``Iron Lady'' informed her Cabinet of her decision to resign the morning after she declared she would ``fight on'' to a second round of the leadership election against former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine. ``She told us of her decision and then got on with business,'' said Transport Secretary Cecil Parkinson. At the same Cabinet meeting, she decided to commit 14,000 more British troops to the Persian Gulf. As flowers and tributes poured into the official residence at 10 Downing Street, she passionately defended her government against a motion of no-confidence introduced by Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. ``I'm enjoying this! I'm enjoying this!'' she shouted in the House of Commons, full to overflowing for a sometimes rude, sometimes sentimental debate. A tired-looking Mrs. Thatcher was sometimes hoarse and frequently coughed. The motion of censure, which could have brought down the government, was resoundingly defeated by a 120-vote majority in the 650-seat House late Thursday, with no Tory defectors. No longer shackled by loyalty, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and treasury chief John Major earlier Thursday quickly jumped into the leadership contest, which will be settled next week. Thursday was the deadline for nominations. After succeeding Laborite James Callaghan as prime minister in 1979, Mrs. Thatcher relentlessly promoted capitalism in Britain. She sold many nationalized industries to private shareholders, including British Steel and British Airways; crushed the power of labor unions and cut tax rates. By directing a risky but successful war against Argentina in the Falklands in 1982 and through her close relationship with President Ronald Reagan, she was widely credited with restoring Britain's self-image as a world power. At home, the party rebellion had been building for years, but news that Margaret Thatcher walked away from a fight surprised the world. ``I thought she'd duke it out,'' a U.S. Marine in Saudi Arabia remarked to President Bush. ``So did I,'' the president said. Mrs. Thatcher, 65, was Europe's longest-serving prime minister in this century, the only one to win three consecutive elections, for 15 years the unchallenged leader of the Conservative Party. The ``Iron Lady'' tag was an unintended tribute from Moscow, from the days in the 1970s when she was opposition leader and an enthusiastic Cold Warrior. She decided to resign two days after joining 33 other world leaders in signing the Charter of Paris, marking the formal end of the Cold War. Mrs. Thatcher had chosen to play the world stage rather than stay home to campaign in Tuesday's first-round battle with Heseltine for the party leadership. She hustled back Wednesday, replaced her campaign manager and personally lobbied for votes in the House tearoom, but it was too late. Until the Conservatives choose their new leader, Mrs. Thatcher is still prime minister - and a fighting one at that. She also retains her seat as a member of Parliament from Finchley in north London. ``I do look back with some pride and some satisfaction at our achievements for our country over the last 11{ years,'' she said. Conservative lawmakers accepted her departure with sadness and relief, praising her courage in putting the party before herself. The Labor Party lauded the grocer's daughter, but didn't hide its glee. The news, Kinnock said, was ``very good indeed. I cannot pretend otherwise.'' Mrs. Thatcher released a statement through her office saying: ``I have concluded the unity of the party and prospects of victory in a general election would be better served if I stood down to enable Cabinet colleagues to enter the ballot for the leadership.'' Kinnock, redirecting his fire to the leader to come, told Mrs. Thatcher, ``You showed that you amount to more than those who have turned on you in recent days.'' He pressed his demand for a national election, which Mrs. Thatcher said was no more possible than when Labor Prime Minister Harold Wilson resigned in 1976 and was succeeded by Callaghan. Hurd and Major, who issued a joint statement pledging a ``friendly'' campaign, sat together in the House; Heseltine sat further away. Though Mrs. Thatcher finished 52 votes ahead of Heseltine in the leadership ballot Tuesday, it wasn't enough to win and some Cabinet members warned her that support was eroding. On Tuesday, a simple majority of 187 of the 372 Tory lawmakers will be sufficient to win. If necessary, a third and final ballot will be held on Thursday. The Conservatives have trailed Labor for 16 months in opinion polls following a rash of unpopular measures including a per-capita tax to replace the property tax. Anxiety over their chances in a general election, which must be held by mid-1992, fomented the Conservative Party rebellion that led to Mrs. Thatcher's downfall. Her daughter, Carol, said the prime minister was the victim of ``a gutless act of treachery.'' The morning Cabinet meeting was solemn and quiet, ministers said. ``There was a general air of sadness,'' said Education Secretary Kenneth Clarke. Press Association, the domestic news agency, quoted ministers as saying Mrs. Thatcher was close to tears. Later, Mrs. Thatcher smiled as she emerged from her office to be driven to Buckingham Palace to inform Queen Elizabeth II of her decision. Hundreds of people stood quietly at the barricades to watch her pass. Heseltine, who heard the news while planting an acorn at the London Zoo, called her rule ``by any standards ... remarkable.'' ``Nothing I am going to say today is going to diminish or blur the very high regard people wish to express for what she has achieved,'' said Heseltine, who resigned as defense secretary in 1986 in a dispute with the prime minister. Nigel Lawson, who quit as Mrs. Thatcher's treasury chief last year told British Broadcasting Corp. radio: ``Margaret Thatcher, who has never lacked courage, had the courage to resign.'' ``She has done the right thing for the party and the country,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Visits Troops; Britain Doubling Deployment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Saddam visiting troops in Kuwait, Bush arriving in Cairo, Bush plans. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Hundreds of U.S...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,4,5,6; LaserColor DHA101,102,104, 105,106
DOC.TEXT: President Bush shared turkey and trimmings Thursday with front-line U.S. forces he called ``this American family out here'' in the Saudi desert. In nearby Kuwait, Saddam Hussein reviewed Iraqi troops he said were prepared to battle ``evil basphemers.'' An American hostage in Iraq said his Thanksgiving wish was to be home with his family because ``this is what the day is for.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, meanwhile, sought the support of Yemen, the only Arab state on the U.N. Security Council, for a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq. Yemen, which has tilted toward Iraq in the past, did not promise any backing, but reportedly suggested it might not oppose the measure. The anti-Iraq coalition got a boost Thursday with Britain's announcement it would nearly double its forces in the Persian Gulf, to 30,000 troops. It could be Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's final act of defiance at the Iraqi president. Mrs. Thatcher said Thursday she would step down amid disagreements in the ruling party over her leadership. Bush arrived late Thursday in Cairo, Egypt, where he is expected to meet Friday with President Hosni Mubarak. The Egyptian leader has led Arab opposition to the Iraqi invasion. Later Friday, Bush is scheduled to fly to Geneva, his last stop on an eight-day overseas trip, to confer with Syrian President Hafez Assad, a bitter foe of Saddam. As the gulf crisis dragged on toward the four-month mark, Saddam made angry new threats against the U.S.-led lliance trying to force him to relinquish Kuwait, the oil-rich emirate his troops overran Aug. 2. ``We are not seeking war, but if war is imposed on us we will fight in a manner that will please friends and incense the evil blasphemers,'' he told officers in Kuwait, according to the official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus. Saddam's visit to Kuwait was his second since the invasion. He also toured troop positions in southern Iraq. ``We want to tell Bush ... we will destroy you no matter how heavily your teeth are filled with poison,'' Saddam said Wednesday, the news agency reported. Iraq has an estimated 430,000 troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq. On Thursday, more than 100 European hostages, mainly British and Swiss nationals, flew out of Baghdad in two chartered planes. Iraq freed them in response to appeals by French and Swiss delegations. Hundreds of U.S. hostages are still being held in Iraq, some of them detained at key installations as ``human shields'' against attack. Iraqi authorities brought a dozen of them American captives to a posh Baghdad country club for a Thanksgiving dinner. While glad of a break in the monotony of their months-long detention, some of the ``guests,'' as Iraq calls them, said they'd had enough of Iraqi hospitality. ``On Thanksgiving Day we should be reunited with our families. This is what the day is for,'' said Billy Rodebush, 53, of McAlester, Okla. ``Nobody should be detained against his will.'' Some Americans who came to Iraq against the advice of the U.S. government were allowed to visit with family members being held hostage. Bush's one-day visit with soldiers in the Saudi desert marked the first presidential visit in more than two decades to U.S. combat troops in the field. The last such trip was President Nixon's visit to American soldiers in South Vietnam in 1969. Bush and his wife, Barbara, clad in camouflage gear, waited in a chow line with troops deployed at a desolate desert outpost 65 miles from the Kuwait border. Alongside the soldiers, they hunkered down at makeshift tables made of plywood and sandbags for a turkey dinner amid the blowing sand. ``There could hardly be a prouder moment than sharing Thanksgiving with this family, this American family out here,'' the president said. U.S. officials said the troops in and around the gulf had a Thanksgiving meal was the closest the military could come to home cooking - fresh turkey, ham and roast beef, fruit and vegetables, sweet or mashed potatoes, and a choice of five kinds of pie for dessert. Some soldiers were also able to listen to a broadcast of the Detroit Lions- Denver Broncos football game from Pontiac, Mich. Still, many were homesick. One soldier - 23-year-old Anibal Cabezas of New York, with the 82nd Aviation Brigade - said it was hard to be so far away at the holidays, but added: ``It's a job we have to get done. That's what we're here for.'' U.S. officials, meanwhile, are weighing ways to make more troops available for service in the gulf if needed. Pentagon officials said Thursday the Army is considering freezing the release of officers and enlisted personnel from units in the United States. That would expand a policy that has been in effect since August, curtailing release of active-duty troops in the gulf region and of personnel in some specialties who have not gone overseas. Bush recently ordered the U.S. troop strength in the area nearly doubled, to more than 400,000, to provide the ability to mount an offensive if needed. Baker, who has been on an international lobbying drive to win support for a U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq, held talks Thursday with Yemen's president, Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh. Afterward, Saleh said foreign forces have ``complicated the problem, rather than solved it.'' But a State Department official, asked later about the Yemeni position on the use-of-force measure, replied: ``They didn't say no.'' Any resolution giving advance authority to use military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait would have to be approved by the 15-nation Security Council. Also, Yemen will take over the rotating presidency of the council from the United States in December. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Thursday ``the time is ripe'' to settle the Arab-Israeli tensions and the Lebanese conflict, in addition to the gulf crisis. So far, most Western leaders have resisted linking various Middle East disputes with the standoff caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
