DOC.HEAD: Russia Can't Transform Economy Alone, Prime Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: The Russian republic's 500-day economic reform plan cannot be fully implemented without the national government's help, the prime minister of the largest and richest republic said Thursday. Ivan Silayev's comments to the Russian Federation parliament were a tacit acknowledgment that Russia lacks clear control over key economic catalysts such as prices, currency, interest rates and land. Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin moved ahead with the 500-day program to move to a free market economy on Nov. 1, after the national government adopted a slower, less radical blueprint favored by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Yeltsin's political rival. The national and Russian governments have issued conflicting orders that have effectively torpedoed both plans. ``A considerable part of the 500-days program can and will be implemented,'' but it is not a ``totally autonomous republican'' plan and hinges on decisions by the national government, the official Tass news agency quoted Silayav as saying. Silayav did not elaborate on his comment, Tass said. Russia has half the Soviet Union's 285 million people, three-quarters of its land mass and the bulk of its natural resources. Earlier Thursday, the Russian parliament accepted the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Grigory Yavlinsky, co-author of a 500-day plan designed to be implemented by the entire Soviet Union. Yavlinsky formally offered his resignation Oct. 17 after Gorbachev came out in favor of the less radical plan. Lawmakers postponed the vote on Yavlinsky's resignation to give him time to reconsider, but Silayev urged them Thursday to accept it. Deputies voted 164-17 to accept the resignation, the independent news agency Interfax reported. ``I do this with regret, but Yavlinsky wants to work in another capacity,'' Tass quoted Silayev as saying. A government spokesman said Yavlinsky has been offered the job as chairman of Yeltsin's council of economic advisers. Yavlinsky's resignation came a day after Yeltsin declared the 15 Soviet republics could no longer wait for a new union treaty and were proceeding on their own to create a new economic union. Yeltsin on Wednesday signed a treaty with the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan. It was Russia's fourth bilateral treaty with another republic. The treaties, which bypass the Kremlin, cover direct economic, political and cultural ties. Yeltsin signed a similar treaty with the Ukraine on Monday, and earlier concluded pacts with Moldavia and Georgia. On Thursday, he met Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov and Prime Minister Ivars Godmanis to continue negotiating a treaty with the Baltic republic. The Ukrainian treaty was approved by the republic's lawmakers on Thursday, and parliamentary president Leonid Kravchuk praised it because ``our desires and actions were not imposed upon us by anybody.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian, Pakistani Prime Ministers Agree to Talk Out Differences
DOC.TEXT: New prime ministers Chandra Shekhar of India and Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan agreed Thursday to talk out their differences but refused to budge on the issue that nearly brought them to war last spring. They will resume talks on reducing tensions in Kashmir province and on two minor border issues, said a joint statement. Their meeting on a sandy, tropical Indian Ocean island was the first in two years by leaders of the two rival nations and the first foreign policy encounter for both men, who took office less than three weeks ago. It was held during a three-day summit of the seven-nation South Asia Association for Regional Cooperation. Chandra Shekhar told Indian reporters ``I felt right at home'' at his meeting with Sharif. ``It was just like a family gathering. I found him to be very cooperative. We are both eager to have the best of relations.'' India and Pakistan mobilized their armies for war after India cracked down on pro-Pakistani Moslem insurgents in Jammu-Kashmir, the only state in Hindu-dominated India with a Moslem majority. Fighting was averted largely through U.S. diplomatic efforts. ``The two prime ministers decided that all differences between the two countries should be resolved peacefully and through dialogue,'' said the statement read by Pakistan's foreign secretary, Shaharyar Khan. He said Sharif raised the Kashmir issue and outlined Pakistan's position. Chandra Shekhar restated India's stand ``on interference in India's internal matters.'' Pakistan says Kashmir's future should be determined by a plebiscite, as called for in United Nations resolutions. India says Kashmir is its sovereign territory and cannot be severed. The issue has simmered since 1947, when colonial India won independence from Britain and was divided into India and Pakistan on religious lines. Kashmir, then an independent princely state ruled by a Hindu king, had the option of joining either country. The king chose India. Pakistan objected, saying the people of Kashmir should have had a say. Chandra Shekhar said the hostilities were deflecting energy from the main task of improving the lot of the desperately poor South Asian countries. ``Poverty is the enemy. If we fight each other we won't be able to fight poverty,'' he said. He and Sharif set Dec. 18 as the date for their foreign secretaries to resume talks on confidence-building measures along their frontier.

DOC.HEAD: Sub Collides with Fishing Boat off Scotland, Several Missing
DOC.TEXT: A fishing boat believed to have four men aboard was missing Thursday after a British submarine collided with vessel off Scotland's Isle of Arran, the Royal Navy said. Naval helicopters, a frigate and a minesweeper searched for the fishing boat, Antares, which was reported overdue at its home port of Carradale, Kintyre. A navy spokesman said the boat normally carries a crew of four, but it was not known how many were on board. The spokesman said the sub surfaced after the 2 a.m. collision and sighted two fishing boats in no apparent difficulties. It submerged and left after trying unsuccessfully to make contact with the fishing boats, but reported the incident to the Coast Guard, the spokesman said, declining to be identified. The sub apparently struck the vessel's underwater gear but no further details were available. The spokesman said searchers near Arran in the Firth of Clyde off the west coast of Scotland later spotted some debris but it was not ``positively identified as coming from the Antares.''

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Walesa Far Ahead of Mazowiecki
With AM-Poland-Politics
DOC.TEXT: A poll published Thursday indicated Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa has a clear lead over his Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in next week's presidential elections. The sample of 1,000 respondents taken Monday and Tuesday showed Walesa is favored by 38 percent of voters, and Mazowiecki by 23 percent. Maverick candidate Stanislaw Tyminski, a wealthy emigre who has returned after 21 years in Canada and Peru, was third with 17 percent. If no candidate wins more than 50 percent in Sunday's vote, the top two finishers face a Dec. 9 runoff. Three minor candidates received a total of 13 percent, and nine percent were undecided, according to the survey carried out by the OBOP agency of state television. The margin of error is three percent.

DOC.HEAD: Protests, Violence Marks Final Enthronement Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito on Friday completed a centuries-old ceremony signifying his accession to the world's oldest hereditary throne while protests were held against the monarchy and the high cost of the rite. The Shinto ceremony, symbolizing communion with the sun goddess, has been performed by most of Japan's emperors since at least the 7th century, and in the past was believed to give monarchs their status as living god. But demonstrators across the country criticized the ritual as a violation of the Japanese constitution's separation of church and state and questioned the use of nearly $17 million in tax money on the ceremony. Other critics of the Daijosai, or Great Food Offering Ritual, also believe holding it indicates a desire within Japan's conservative government to bring back the emperor worship of prewar days. The rite, witnessed by only two female attendants, was held Thursday night and then repeated before dawn Friday. Anti-monarchy radicals marked the beginning of the ceremony by launching six mortar-like projectiles at an imperial villa in Kyoto, in western Japan, police said. Radicals were also believed to have set fires at three Shinto shrines and four train stations outside of the capital of Tokyo just after midnight. No injuries were reported. Separate peaceful protests were staged by scholars and labor unionists, and 1,000 Christians fasted to protest the funding of the rite. Akihito, 56, is the first Japanese emperor to be enthroned since his father, the late Emperor Hirohito, assumed the Chrysanthemum Throne 62 years ago. He is also the first to assume the throne under Japan's postwar constitution, which calls him not a god-king but a symbol of his people's sovereignty. Akihito's formal state enthronement ceremony Nov. 12 was viewed by foreign dignitaries representing 158 countries, but no foreigners were invited to the communion. During the rite, Akihito offered rice, wine and other foods from around the country to the sun goddess Amaterasu, from whom legend says the imperial line descended. The two women attendants are clad in white and red kimono and with their hair tied in pony tails nearly 6{ feet long. The ceremony is held in the torch-lit inner sanctuary of a specially built hall on the palace grounds. The rite is performed only once by each emperor. Inside the sanctuary, out of view of the 733 Japanese guests seated in large tents nearby, the offerings were made to an altar placed beside a stylized bed, from which the goddess is summoned. Scholars before World War II theorized that at one time the ceremony might have involved the emperor symbolically having sex with the sun goddess, representing a union with the divine. Palace officials, however, deny that theory and said the emperor would not touch the bed. The second ceremony was repeated after midnight in an identical hall yards from the first one. Akihito performs dozens of religious ceremonies at the palace each year, carrying on the priest-king role that has been handed down from ancient times. That role, however, has periodically come under fire since the end of World War II. Hirohito, who died in 1989 at age 87, renounced the concept of imperial divinity in 1946 at the urging of the U.S.-led occupation forces. The country's post-war constitution specifies that the emperor is a national symbol, and not a god-king.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Spend Thanksgiving Remembering Kennedy's Assassination
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people spent part of Thanksgiving day remembering President Kennedy with a visit to the downtown building where investigators say Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shots that killed him 27 years ago. By the end of the day, more than 700 people visite the Texas School Book Depository exhibit on Kennedy's assassination, said exhibit director Bob Hays. The exhibit is open every day of the year except Christmas. The exhibit opened on President's Day, 1989, on the sixth floor of the building where investigators say Oswald perched on boxes and ate his lunch on Nov. 22, 1963, waiting for the presidential motorcade to pass by. The exhibit features more than 400 photographs and a narrative detailing Kennedy's life and death. It mentions controversies over the accuracy of official reports on the assassination and speculation about whether Oswald had conspirators.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped British Girl Found Killed
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old British girl was found slain near a beach in southern Portugal on Thursday, four days after she disappeared from outside her family home in this coastal resort, police said. The body of Rachel Charles was discovered near a hotel close to where she was believed kidnapped Monday, 1\ miles from the family home, said a spokesman. Police said they had several suspects. They think the killer knew the girl. Rachel was last seen entering a red car with British or Dutch license plates after getting off a school bus in front of her home. A British consular official said Rachel's mother, Carol Charles, received a telephoned ransom demand for 300,000 pounds ($585,000) Wednesday. Rachel lived with her mother and stepfather, Ray Charles, who work at a local tourism company. She attended school at nearby Vilamoura.

DOC.HEAD: Wounded German Interior Minister Holds News Conference
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said Thursday he will remain bound to a wheelchair for some time after being wounded in an assassination attempt Oct. 12, but hoped to resume his duties soon. Schaeuble, 48, spoke to reporters at a rehabilitation clinic in southern Germany in his first public appearance since being shot twice during a campaign appearance. One bullet hit his jaw and the second struck his spinal cord, paralyzing his legs. Authorities said the gunman, Dieter Kaufmann, had a history of mental disorders and drug addiction. Schaeuble said he hoped to resume some duties around Germany's national elections on Dec. 2. ``It is certain that for the foreseeable future, I will have to live in a wheelchair,'' he said. Schaeuble played a major role in readying the treaty on German unification. He was one of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's closest aides and was seen as a possible successor to Kohl as leader of the conservative Christian Democratic Union. He said Thursday he viewed the assassination attempt as an ``accident.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: 4,000 Ethiopian Jews Expected in Israel by Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 4,000 Ethiopian Jews are expected in Israel by the end of next month following an agreement in Addis Ababa to let them emigrate, news reports said Thursday. The renewed emigration appears to be the culmination of a four-month hiatus triggered by tensions between the Ethiopian government and Israel, Israeli television said. Ethiopian leaders accused Israel of failing to honor agreements reached when the countries renewed diplomatic ties in October 1989, the report said. It said tensions between Jerusalem and Addis Ababa had been eased but didn't elaborate. Two official Israeli delegations have visited the Ethiopian capital to discuss the issue the past month. Uri Gordon, chairman of the Jewish Agency's Immigration Department, said 2,822 Jews have come to Israel from Ethiopia since January, the national Itim news agency reported. Another 1,000 are expected in the next five weeks, the television report said. According to the television report, about 20,000 Jews remain crowded in difficult conditions in the Ethiopian capital awaiting permits to emigrate. Television showed dozens of an immigrant group of 150 Ethiopians arriving at Ben Gurion Airport outside Tel Aviv before dawn Thursday. Most of the adults wore long white embroidered robes and turbans. ``For me today it is like the sunrise,'' newcomer Andshe Vorbaneh said. An Israeli Parliament member visiting Addis Ababa charged Thursday that Israeli Embassy officials had arbitrarily denied some Ethiopian Jews visas, claiming they provided inadequate proof of Jewishness. ``Some people who had the right to demand the Law of Return had the right taken away from them,'' Shimon Shetreet said on Israel radio. The 1950 law guarantees all Jews the right to immigrate to Israel. The Foreign Ministry denied Shetreet's charge, pointing out the ``very strict criteria for those who are entitled to enjoy the Law of Return and those that cannot.'' Jewish identity is passed maternally, and Israeli officials say spotty Ethiopian birth records make it difficult to prove Jewish backrounds.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Chief: Brazilian Miners Invading Amazon Reserves
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of gold prospectors expelled from Yanomami Indian lands have invaded other Amazon reserves and spread malaria among the tribes, an Indian chief said Thursday. The claims were made as representatives from 12 indigenous groups of the far-western Amazon state of Roraima came to the capital in search of medical aid. The Indian chiefs also want the government to demarcate their lands and expel the miners. Makuxi chief Jaci said Thursday that about 8,000 gold miners were spreading malaria among his 12,000-member tribe. The Makuxis, mostly farmers, inhabit a large reserve near the Venezuelan border. The Indian leader said 154 of 990 Makuxi in four villages had been infected the last three months. Five of those had died, including his own wife. In addition, he said 122 ranchers had also occupied large tracts of the Makuxi reserve, taking advantage of the lack of reserve markings. Last January, the government ordered the miners off the reserve of the Yanomamis, the world's largest primitive tribe. But since then the prospectors have poured into a region near the Guyana border in search of gold and diamonds, Jaci said. Neither the National Indian Foundation nor the Justice Ministry would meet with the Indian chiefs on Thursday, Jaci said. The government has said it lacks the money needed to demarcate the tribes' lands and remove the miners by force. ``All the medical attention is given to the Yanomamis. The government has forgotten the rest of us,'' Jaci complained. The Yanomamis are also being decimated by diseases from about 40,000 gold prospectors who have flooded into the mineral-rich region the last three years. Brazil's Indian Missionary Council, sponsored by the Roman Catholic Church, estimates that 1,500 of the remaining 9,000 Yanomamis have died in three years, most from malaria and sexual diseases brought by miners. Some have died in conflicts with the miners, the Council says. The Indians' medical situation has improved recently, according to government officials, because of an emergency health campaign that it says has cut the incidence of malaria in Indian villages from 90 percent to 18 percent. Federal police have also begun ``Operation Free Yanomami Jungle,'' to force the miners off the Indian lands. About 140 troops are dynamiting 120 clandestine landing strips cut in the jungle and used to supply mining sites by air. Brazil's Indians have steadily dwindled in number since 1987, when the clandestine rush to the Amazon began after government studies indicated a wealth of gold, diamonds, tin and bauxite there. Prospectors and landless peasants have leveled rain forests, chased off fish and game, polluted rivers with mercury used in gold panning, and spread diseases previously unknown to the tribes. There are about 215,000 native Indians left in Brazil, down from an estimated 5 million when the Portuguese landed here in 1500.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Socialists Approve Budget; Opposition in Challenge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE on budget approved, no-confidence vote set. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Socialist deputies carried Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov's austerity budget through Parliament early Friday, but main opposition parties boycotted the secret ballot and moved for a vote of no-confidence. Approval of the budget - 186 votes for, 10 against, seven abstentions and one invalid ballot - ended weeks of parliamentary squabbling. Lukanov had pinned his fate and that of his government on budget approval. The Union of Democratic Forces boycotted the vote and demanded a separate vote of no-confidence in the 400-seat Grand National Assembly. Socialist deputies agreed to meet the challenge, but only when Parliament reconvened later Friday. Lukanov's foes decided to shun the budget vote after losing, 197-160, on a vote to decide the issue by secret ballot instead of the regular show of hands. The Socialists, formerly the Communists, ousted hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov on Nov. 10, 1989, won free elections in June and named Lukanov premier. His popularity has waned because of political stalemate, rationing and shortages of food and consumer goods. His foes claim they would win new elections. The opposition rejects Lukanov's invitation to join a broad, Socialist-led coalition government, insisting instead on choosing the premier and holding key ministries. However, one prominent UDF leader, Rumen Vodenicharov, on Thursday assailed the opposition leadership for boycotting the vote and charged it with ``being blinded by the desire to get into power.'' He said he was quitting the coalition's parliamentary group and would continue in Parliament as an independent. He told deputies he supported the budget measures, which include privatization and price rises of 200 to 500 percent on some basic consumer goods, including some foods, to offset a budget deficit. Vodenicharov said the opposition promoted ``obstructive politics, that are only delaying the start of economic reform.'' Lukanov has faced increasing public pressure to resign, as disgruntled Bulgarians have taken to the streets protesting their economic straits. Up to 50,000 supporters and opponents of the governing Socialists had massed outside the Grand National Assembly to wait for the results of the parliamentary session Thursday. Opposition supporters formed a human chain around the building but were kept at bay by police, some in riot gear. Only a few hundred remained outside in the wintry weather by the time the result was announced. Inside, a brief scuffle broke out at the rostrum at one point and microphones were overturned in a dispute over whether the budget vote or a no-confidence vote should come first. Order was quickly restored. Lukanov's Socialist Party has a majority of 210 seats, against 144 seats for the opposition Union after Vodenicharov's defection. The Agrarians have 16 seats and the ethnic Turkish Movement for Rights and Freedoms hold 23. Small parties and independents hold the remainder. The Socialists have been unable to halt economic decline and improve food supplies, but rejected calls to hand power to the opposition. The resulting deadlock has fueled street protests and pressure on the Lukanov government to resign because of ``inaction.'' The opposition Podkrepa trade union called a general strike starting Monday if Lukanov did not step down Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Spy Chief Wants Securitate Files to Stay Shut
DOC.TEXT: The chief of Romania's new intelligence service told lawmakers Thursday the files of the late Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's Securitate secret police should stay closed indefinitely. Virgil Margureanu, boss of the newly created Romanian Intelligence Service, addressed Parliament before deputies debated a planned law regulating the service's operations. He said opening Securitate files to the public could cause instability and fan suspicion. Many government opponents insist the Securitate has not been disbanded and still taps phones, intercepts mail and employs other methods used under Ceausescu to control Romanian society. That belief is shared by many Romanians. Last month, Margureanu told reporters that authorities would reveal the names of former Securitate agents. He backed away from that position Thursday. He said keeping Securitate files sealed ``would be a natural solution for consolidating a climate of stability ... and eliminating the sources of suspicion.'' Margureanu said the Securitate had employed 14,259 military and 984 civilian personnel. Last month, he acknowledged that the new intelligence service had rehired some former Securitate agents. Margureanu appealed for swift passage of the law, saying it would help his agency deal with a ``fascist'' menace and hundreds of terrorist threats he claimed were received by Romanian politicians. Since the Communist dictatorship was ousted and Ceausescu was executed last December, many officials have warned of a resurgence of fascism by former members of the Legionnaires' movement that supported Nazi Germany. They are said to have been active outside the country during Romania's 45 years of Communist rule. Opposition figures say the government is trying to whip up a fear of renewed fascism to divert attention from the deteriorating economy and other issues. Margureanu insisted his service was not tapping phones or intercepting mail. Anti-government protests continued in Bucharest Thursday. About 2,000 protesters marched downtown shouting slogans against President Ion Iliescu and Premier Petre Roman, whose National Salvation Front took power in the revolution and won elections in May. In Sibiu, thousands ook part in an anti-government rally Thursday organized by the opposition National Peasant Party, the Democratic Union of Hungarians in Romania, and several unions. Tension rose in Romania after the government on Nov. 1 ordered price increases that doubled and tripled the cost of many items. Most essential foods, energy and rents remain subsidized for now.

DOC.HEAD: Press Crisis Forces New Closure
DOC.TEXT: The national newspaper Tempo announced Thursday it will close next week, making it the ninth major victim in Portugal's collapsing press market. On Wednesday, the Lisbon evening paper Diario de Lisboa said it will fold Nov. 30. They will bring to nine the number of major daily and weekly papers to shut down since the end of a press boom in the late 1980s, when a crop of new publications hit the stands. Investors had hoped for advertising revenue in one of Europe's fastest growing economies. But the market was unable to sustain the increasing number of papers in a country where almost 20 percent of the 10.3 million people are illiterate. The weekly Tempo was founded in 1975 as a conservative voice while much of the media swung to the left following a 1974 revolution that overthrew Portugal's 48-year rightist dictatorship. The paper's editorial line was often marked by a strong opposition to leftist movements in Portugal's former African colonies. The paper, which had a circulation of 71,000 in 1978, currently sells about 17,000 copies. The center-right government is hoping to boost the press industry by privatizing state-owned papers. Several papers have been sold and the last remaining state-owned paper, Diario de Noticias, is scheduled for privatization next year.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Drug Traffickers Offer Conditional Surrender
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Medellin cocaine cartel offered Thursday to turn themselves in if the government protects their security and promises not to send them to the United States. A statement from the cartel said from 200 to 300 of its members would be willing to congregate in a special, army-protected compound. Such a surrender ``implies the end of all activities related to drug trafficking or narcoterrorism,'' it said. It did not indicate if the surrender offer included Pablo Escobar, the Medellin cartel's leader. The statement was given to the presidency, which distributed it to news media. In response, Justice Minister Jaime Giraldo outlined legal guarantees drug traffickers would enjoy upon surrendering. In September, President Cesar Gaviria offered to bar extraditions and cut jail sentences of drug traffickers who gave up and confessed their crimes. The traffickers on Thursday apparently accepted - with conditions. They asked not to be required to confess, saying this would constitute self-incrimination, ``prohibited even in the United States.'' Giraldo said, ``A confession of all crimes committed is not required, just some of them.'' He said traffickers who surrender ``can be sure they will not be extradited.'' The traffickers said they would expect special army protection and oversight by world human rights organizations. The cartel has been blamed for killing about 550 Colombians since the government and drug traffickers declared war on each other after a political assassination in August 1989. Traffickers have kidnapped nine journalists. Drug bosses said the abductions were a response to human rights abuses by police in Medellin, the cartel's home city. The drug smugglers also apparently are trying to pressure authorities to grant them a pardon. On Thursday, the drug lords said they should not be treated like common criminals.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: In No Hurry to Sign Free Trade Agreement With Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to fix typo in lead, minor editing. Picks up 6th pvs, `If the...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he is in a hurry to sign a free-trade pact with Mexico. ``We have made a commitment to a free-trade agreement with Mexico. We want to do it as soon as possible,'' Bush told the Mexican government news agency Notimex in an interview made public Thursday. The interview, published in Spanish, was conducted in Washington, and released four days before Bush is scheduled to meet with Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in the northern state of Nuevo Leon. The free-trade agreement is expected to be one of the main topics of discussion at the two-day summit beginning Monday. Bush said he looks favorably on including Canada in talks for a three-way free-trade agreement, but only if that doesn't slow the process. ``If the effort to broaden the process is not viable because it produces unacceptable delays, we will proceed bilaterally with Mexico,'' Notimex quoted Bush as saying. Canadian finance and labor representatives have warned Mexico to proceed with caution in signing such an agreement. Canada and the United States signed a bilateral trade agreement in 1988; the pact began in part this year. Bush said he was grateful for Mexico's continued supply of petroleum exports, especially in the wake of the embargo on Middle Eastern oil imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Notimex reported. The president also expressed interest in U.S. investment in Mexico's nationalized oil industry. ``We recognize that petroleum frequently has been an area of special sensitivity for Mexico, particularly in its relations with the United States. However ... I am convinced that there are important areas in which we can work together and which can be mutually beneficial for increased investment and exploration of petroleum and natural gas,'' the agency quoted Bush as saying. The Mexican government nationalized the oil industry in 1939, ousting foreign corporations. Salinas' 2-year-old administration has returned many nationalized industries, including petrochemicals, to the private sector. But Salinas has maintained that primary petroleum production will remain in the hands of the state.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Albania Rejects Foreign Pressures for Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Albania, the last hard-line Communist country in Europe, said Thursday it wants to take part in European integration but it rejected the idea that foreign pressure could set the pace for reforms there. An editorial in Albania's official Zeri i Popullit newspaper also indicated that the Tirana leadership is still opposed to the type of radical changes that swept Communists from power in Eastern Europe. Albanian officials attended this week's 34-nation European summit in Paris as observers. According to excerpts of the editorial carried by the state-run news agency ATA, monitored in Vienna, democratization is under way in politics, the economy and human rights. But the report said it was ``not normal'' that Albania does not receive credit in Europe for the changes. The editorial quoted President Ramiz Alia, who is also the party leader, as saying some European leaders ``are using their consensus regarding Albania as a pressure to dictate different political recipes and conditions to our country.'' It did not mention specific European leaders, according to the ATA report, Alia reportedly told a recent party meeting that Albania will do nothing under foreign ``dictate'' and added, ``The Albanian people have never put on auction their freedom, independence and national sovereignty.'' Following the Eastern European revolutions, Albania has moved slowly to open up to the outside world, increasing contacts and trade with foreign governments and allowing visits by foreign news media. But the changes have not gone as far as multiparty elections. Albania ``will continue to march in the spirit of European developments and will render its modest contribution to the whole process'' of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the editorial said.

U.S. District Judge Kimba M. Wood's sentence was by far the stiffest in the insider trading probe that focused on Milken after speculator Ivan Boesky confessed to rampant lawbreaking in late 1986. DOC.HEAD: Japan's Four-Year Economic Boom Begins to Slow Down
Graphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A four-year boom that brought a new era of affluence to Japan appears to be subsiding as a labor shortage, higher interest rates and the Persian Gulf crisis take their toll on the economy. Demand for domestic goods and strong corporate investment will insulate the economy from the worst of the U.S. economic downturn and ensure that land prices fall gradually rather than plummet, said Russell Jones, an economist at UBS Phillips and Drew International Ltd. But growing corporate bankruptcies and lackluster mid-year corporate profits are signs that the economy is shifting into lower gear after four years of annual growth of 5 percent or more, analysts say. ``The economy's beginning to slow, but it's a slow slowdown. The deceleration is not that pronounced - it's not a collapse,'' Jones said. Most economists cite higher interest rates - introduced to cool inflation - as a key constraint, especially for smaller firms that borrow for investment. The Bank of Japan has raised the official rate it charges commercial banks five times since May 1989, from 2.5 percent to 6 percent. That has ended the source of cheap capital that helped fuel the boom that began in December 1986. Partly because of higher interest rates, corporate bankruptcies in Japan increased in October for the first time in 70 months, climbing 9.7 percent from the year before to 645 cases, Teikoku Data Bank reported. Hardest hit were real estate firms, weakened by flattening land prices, and small- and medium-size manufacturers suffering from a severe labor shortage, the private credit research agency said. At the same time, companies found their financial cushions of stock assets flattened by lower share prices. The Nikkei Stock Average, the Tokyo market's key indicator, has dropped more than 40 percent this year. The return on financial assets has plummeted, and cheap equity financing has become difficult, said Masahide Tsuru of the Long Term Credit Bank's economics division. ``The bankruptcies indicate the impact of the labor shortage and interest rates at the operating level. ... At the recurring level, declines in the equity and bond markets are compounding everything,'' said Peter Morgan, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Japan. A survey by Wako Research Institute of Economics showed that profits of major corporations for the six-month period ending in September climbed only 0.03 percent from the same period in 1989. During the previous six months, profits climbed 14.4 percent from a year earlier. The survey excluded banks and securities firms, whose profits have fallen sharply with the Nikkei's plunge. Manufacturers, meanwhile, are facing lower demand from importers in the United States, which is undergoing a more pronounced downturn. Japanese semiconductor manufacturers have already announced they will slash computer chip output because of lower demand from U.S. importers. Growth in consumer spending, which accounts for about 60 percent of gross national product, has begun to slow, partly because of the bearish financial markets. Higher interest rates also have made credit purchases of major items such as cars and homes much more costly, said Johsen Takahashi, director of the private think-tank Mitsubishi Research Institute. Consumption, which grew steadily by 2 percent to 3 percent until May, began to slow in July. It rose only 0.6 percent in September from a year earlier, marking the slowest growth this year, the Management and Coordination Agency said in a report released Wednesday. Not all the economic news is bad for Japan, though. Lower U.S. interest rates have tended to weaken the dollar, making the yen relatively stronger, noted Barclays de Zoete Wedd's Peter Morgan. That means Japanese products are more expensive abroad, but imports of fuel and other goods are cheaper. That's become increasingly important with surging oil prices caused by the Middle East crisis. Barring a major cut in oil supplies, economists expect Japan's economy to continue chugging along, although at a slower pace. Most expect economic growth to remain at a robust 5 percent to 6 percent in 1990 and to level off over the next several years to around 4 percent. ``This isn't going to be a recession. There won't be a huge fall in the standard of living,'' said Lawrence S. Prager, chief analyst and strategist at Nikko Securites Co. ``It's just a slowdown.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Seeks $10 Billion from Electricity Sale
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The government said Wednesday it hopes to raise $10.2 billion in the first stage of its electricity industry sell-off, its biggest and most complex privatization in the last 10 years. Twenty percent of the 2.16 billion shares being sold will be offered to foreign investors. The shares will sell for for 240 pence ($4.73) each, or a total 5.18 billion pounds, the government said. The offering caps Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's huge privatization program, which already has raised $65 billion, or 33 billion pounds, through the sales of Britain's telephone, gas and water utilities and such companies as British Airways PLC. The sales are intended to create efficient, competitive companies and encourage wider ownership of those companies. There has been some nervousness about how successful the recent privatizations will be, with a nervous stock market, the continuing Middle East crisis and the current struggle for leadership within Britain's governing Conservative Party. Investors also remember the sale of the government's one-third stake in British Petroleum Co. PLC, which flopped because it coincided with the October 1987 stock market crash. But Energy Secretary John Wakeham said 7.3 million people have registered an interest in buying the electric utility shares, second only to the record 7.5 million registrations for British Gas PLC. ``I don't see any signs of any serious effects on the stock market or sterling as a result of the election for leadership,'' Wakeham said, referring to Thatcher's failure this week to defeat Michael Heseltine for the leadership of the Conservative Party. Another vote will be held next week. The government also has calmed jitters about the offering by announcing it would scrap the sale if war broke out in the Persian Gulf. ``There is no major risk. I think in today's market conditions the offer will be a success,'' said Chris Rowland, an electricity analyst with the London investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. The government on Wednesday signaled its confidence by going ahead and selling 100 percent of each of the 12 regional electricity companies of England and Wales. It had been considering scaling the offer back to 60 percent if market conditions were poor. ``This is the first step in meeting the government's objective of privatizing the electricity industry within the lifetime of this parliament,'' Wakeham said. The government plans to sell its two electricity generating companies and the Scottish electricity industry next year. The shares are expected to fetch a 20 percent premium when trading starts Dec. 11. The application deadline is Dec. 5. Shareholders are to receive an average 8.4 percent dividend return in the first year, Wakeham said. The government has sought to enhance the sale with an installment payment plan of nearly two years, the longest ever, and with bonus shares and discounts on electricity bills, types of perks it has offered in the past. Rowland described the price as ``attractive,'' but opposition lawmaker Frank Dobson, the Labor party's spokesman on energy matters, attacked the price as overly cheap. He accused the government of selling 16 billion pounds ($32 billion) of assets for $5 billion pounds ($10 billion). The government said at least 34 percent of the shares will be reserved for the general public in Britain, and the remaining 46 percent will go to British institutional investors. If there is heavy British demand for the shares, the 20 percent offering to foreign investors will be scaled back, the government said.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Courtroom Channels Plan to Merge
DOC.TEXT: The backers of two proposed cable television channels devoted to covering the legal system have decided to cooperate on a single courtroom network, avoiding what could have been a costly competition. The Courtroom Television Network is expected to be launched next summer. Time Warner Inc., which hoped to launch its own courtroom network next year, and National Broadcasting Co. and the programming division of Cablevision Systems Corp., which were developing a similar service, said Wednesday they agreed to form a partnership to create a channel devoted exclusively to coverage of the courts and legal issues. Terms were not disclosed. The deal is subject to approval by their respective boards. The plan calls for Time Warner to manage the new service through its affiliate American Lawyer Media LP, which publishes 11 legal titles including the monthly American Lawyer magazine. American Lawyer president and chief executive, Steven Brill, will be chief executive of the joint cable venture. The Courtroom Television Network will provide continuous live and taped coverage of trials, legal reports and commentary from legal experts. Its backers say there is a big audience for television that focuses on legal issues. But planners of the competing services found many cable TV systems simply didn't have extra channel space for two legal networks and were slow in picking between them. A tight capital market, meanwhile, has made it more difficult for operators to raise money for expansion of channel capacity. ``The operators are, as a result, prudent and cautious in adding new services,'' said Sharon Patrick, president of Cablevision's Rainbow Programming Holdings Inc. ``But we feel that combining the distribution, the capital and the talent of the two of them creates the strongest new service in cable.'' Time Warner owns cable operations with an estimated 6.4 million household subscribers, while Cablevision Systems has about 1.6 million subscribers. Discussions are underway with other cable systems about taking the courtroom channel. Cablevision Systems had originally planned to have its courtroom cable network, called In Court, in operation this fall. It hired Arthur Miller, the Harvard law professor, as its chief legal analyst and a staff of about 15 to 20 other people, Ms. Patrick said. Time Warner has never disclosed a proposed launch date for its courtroom service, which was tentatively called The American Courtroom Network. It hired Fred Graham, formerly the Supreme Court reporter for the New York Times and CBS News, as its chief anchor. Graham will take that role on the proposed network and Miller, Floyd Abrams, F. Lee Bailey, David Boies, Robert Bork, Arthur Liman and Barry Slotnick will serves as commentators. The network will also draw on work from American Lawyer's more than 200 legal journalists. Larry Gerbrandt, who follows the cable industry for Paul Kagan Associates in Carmel, Calif., said the combination of the two proposed legal channels makes it more likely that a courtroom channel will succeed. ``This is not an environment where either Time Warner or Cablevision wants to sustain long-term losses. Combined, this network has a chance to launch much faster, be larger and be more profitable more quickly,'' he said. He noted that two cable comedy channels, for instance, were launched in the past year but neither has approached the 25 million subscribers he says are needed to attract advertisers and generate sufficient licensing fees to cover overhead costs. About 54 million U.S. households get cable TV. Time Warner's Comedy Channel, launched in November 1989, is on systems with 7.5 million subscribers while Viacom Inc.'s Ha! channel has 6.5 million. Talks about merging those services broke off earlier this year. ``The comedy wars have been plenty expensive,'' Gerbrandt said. He agreed there may be an appetite for a legal channel. ``It's America's ultimate ongoing theater,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Seventh-Largest Accounting Firm Files For Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Lawsuits seeking tens of millions of dollars in damages and challenging Laventhol & Horwath's audits have put the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm in bankruptcy court. Laventhol Wednesday filed under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws, which allows a company to continue operating while it reorganizes and pays creditors. But the Philadelphia-based accounting firm said its name was so tarnished by the filing that it cannot keep operating on its own. Instead, many of Laventhol's 318 partners plan to open independent offices in cities where the firm operated. These offices would attempt to retain Laventhol clients and funnel income to the parent company, allowing it to pay its debts, according to the filing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. In addition, Laventhol partners that find work at other firms would continue to service Laventhol accounts under the plan. Laventhol, which said earlier this week it would be forced to take the step, said the bankruptcy filing was prompted in part by the cost of settling or defending itself against more than 100 lawsuits seeking tens of millions of dollars in damages. The suits primarily were initiated by clients challenging Laventhol audits or by shareholders of client companies claiming Laventhol provided faulty financial information. Michael Crames, a New York-based lawyer for Laventhol, said the plan was novel and that it provides the best chance for creditors to be repaid. Laventhol said the court must suspend the lawsuits it faces in order for the plan to work. Laventhol received a temporary injunction Wednesday halting the suits and plans to seek a permanent bar at a Dec. 4 hearing before U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Cornelius Blackshear, Crames said. During the bankruptcy case, Laventhol will attempt to determine its total liaiblities, including claims made in lawsuits, he said. Crames said he could not estimate what those liabilities would be. In its bankruptcy filing, Laventhol said it owed $146 million to various creditors. Its two largest are Chase Manhattan Bank and Fidelity Bank, which are owed $85 million, Crames said. But its actual liabilities will be much higher, he said. Laventhol, which had 50 offices nationwide, said most of its annual income came in the tax season of January-April. These banks provided credit that helped Laventhol meet its cash needs the rest of the year. Laventhol also faces a lawsuit over its auditing of Jim Bakker's PTL ministry. That case is on trial in Charlotte, N.C. Since Laventhol is a partnership, not a corporation, its current and even retired partners could end up paying out of their own pockets to settle claims if Laventhol can't come up with enough money. ``Partners may find themselves on the hook'' for work that the firm did while they were employed there, Crames said. Laventhol said it thinned its payroll as it entered its credit crunch, leaving about 3,200 employees in addition to the partners and principals as of this month. It had domestic revenue of $350 million last year. Laventhol also said it sought to merge with several other major accounting firms but had no offers.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Factors Prove To Be Thatcher's Downfall
DOC.TEXT: Economic factors contributed to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's downfall, though reforming the economy was one of the hallmarks of more than 11 years of Thatcherism. During her tenure at 10 Downing St., Mrs. Thatcher relentlessly promoted capitalism to defeat socialism in Britain. She took over from the previous, Labor government a troubled economy that was suffering from 17 percent interest rates and moved deep into recession while inflation climbed to 18 percent. Mrs. Thatcher tamed militant labor unions, reformed taxes and cut many inefficiencies out of British industry. Her efforts helped produce an eight-year economic boom - the longest in Britain since World War II - during which interest rates fell to 7.5 percent, inflation got down to 3.3 percent and unemployment went from 11.3 percent to 5.5 percent. But her hostility toward European economic and monetary union, her unpopular per-capita community charge or ``poll-tax,'' and the downturn in the economy made her vulnerable to the attack on her leadership of the Conservative Party. To guard British sovereignty, she said she wouldn't abolish the pound to make way for a single European currency, or relinquish monetary control to a European central bank. But other Conservatives and many Britons worried about being left behind in the European economic revolution. The poll tax, which went into effect earlier this year, was unpopular enough to also divide her party and spark riots. The tax was intended to make local government authorities accountable for their spending, but it condemned for having no relationship to the taxpayer's ability to pay. The economic downturn has been accompanied by 14 percent interest rates, 10.9 percent inflation, and huge trade deficits. Unemployment, at 6 percent, has been climbing. The government had pushed interest rates higher, leaving them at 15 percent for a year, to fight the resurgent inflation by cooling demand. Demand had overheated because of loose monetary policy designed to improve the Conservatives' electoral prospects in 1987 and to avoid a recession following the stock market crash in October of that year. High interest rates have hurt industry and profits, and Britain is suffering record business failures. The rates also have squeezed Britain's new homeowners, who generally hold adjustable rate mortgages. The persistent bear market on the stock exchange, meanwhile, has hurt some 9 million Britons who have become new shareholders. Asked about Mrs. Thatcher's accomplishments, economist Kevin Darlington of the London investment firm UBS Phillips and Drew said, ``The true test will be whether the underlying economy is strong enough to cope with the current recession.'' Mrs. Thatcher said in the House of Commons Thursday that her government had improved the standard of living in Britain. This past week she said that one of her main achievements was creating a culture of enterprise that oversaw the restructuring of Britain's overmanned, inefficient industry into a leaner, more competitive one. ``The major accomplishment, I think, must be the enormous surge in British productivity, the change in management attitudes - she got rid of slack management - and the weakening of union power,'' said John Barnes, who teaches government at the London School of Economics. ``At least part of the 11 12 years in office she succeeded in beating inflation,'' Barnes said. The generation of small business was also a Thatcher accomplishment, he said. Through large-scale privatization that has been copied around the world, Mrs. Thatcher deregulated utilities, turned nationalized companies such as British Airways into world-class competitors, and more than tripled British share ownership. Britain's financial markets also were deregulated under the so-called Big Bang, which opened securities trading to banks and foreign traders in 1986. She tamed Britain's militant unions with legislation that required them to ballot workers before they go on strike, and union membership has declined substantially, to 8.4 million from 12 million in 1979. Mrs. Thatcher also promoted home ownership by selling public housing to its tenants. She cut and simplified taxes. Over the years she brought the basic income tax rate to 25 percent from 33 percent, and nearly halved the top rate to 40 percent from 83 percent. She put a tight grip on public spending, and tried to break a British dependence on welfare. Thus she turned the budget deficits into the surpluses. The prime minister also encouraged entrepreneurship, trying to turn Britain from a class-divided society into a meritocracy. Some 400,000 new businesses have been created since 1979, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed lower Thursday on European currency exchanges that were dominated by news that British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had resigned. Gold prices were higher. Currency dealers said the British pound fell briefly, but quickly rebounded after the announcement to close above Wednesday's rate. U.S. markets were closed for the Thanksgiving holiday. At the close in London, the pound stood at $1.970 dollars, up from Wednesday's close of $1.968. Dealers said the pound was strengthened by the feeling that whoever succeeds Mrs. Thatcher will unify the business-oriented Conservative Party in time to win the next general election, which must be called by mid 1992. Other late European dollar rates, compared with late Wednesday's rates, were: 1.4785 German marks, down from 1.4815; 1.2490 Swiss francs, down from 1.2505; 4.9890 French francs, down from 5.0000; 1.6670 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6717; 1,109.50 Italian lire, down from 1,112.75; and 1.1602 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1587. In earlier Tokyo trading, the dollar eased to 127.13 Japanese yen, down from 127.68. In London late Thursday the dollar traded higher at 127.25 yen. Gold closed in London at a bid of $380.00 a troy ounce, up from Wednesday's closing $378.25. The late bid price in Zurich was $380.50, up from $378.50. Traders said there was little movement in the gold price because of a lack of buying interest. Earlier in Hong Kong gold had closed at $380.44 bid, up from $372.13. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid of $4.13 a troy ounce, up from $4.11.

DOC.HEAD: British Stocks Higher After Thatcher Resignation
DOC.TEXT: The Stock Exchange closed slightly higher Thursday after a session that stayed erratic following news of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's resignation. The initial announcement pushed the main index up more than 34 points on optimism that Mrs. Thatcher's departure would improve the Conservative Party's electoral chances. But shares prices fell back after more than one new contender emerged. Traders said the market was still more assured that the Conservatives would be able to unite and win the next general election, which must be called by mid-1992. However, the overriding sentiment was that there was little point investing in the market when the leadership of the government remained undecided. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 1.6 points, or 0.08 percent, at 2,127.9. The session high of 2,160.7, a gain of 34.4 points, came immediately after the news of Mrs. Thatcher's resignation. The Financial Times 30-share index finished at 1,672.2, down 3.8 points. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 1.56 points to close at 1,124.29. Volume was 498.2 million shares, up slightly from 444.5 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher's Resignation Is Bittersweet News For British Business
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's resignation Thursday was bittersweet news for Britain's business community and financial markets. They were sorry to see Mrs. Thatcher go because her staunch free-market policies have transformed British industry during her 11{ years in power. But they were relieved that she stepped aside to improve the capitalist Conservative Party's chances of defeating the socialist Laborites in the next election, which must be called by mid-1992. They were dismayed that more than one new leadership contender stepped forward, raising doubts about the Conservative election changes, and fueling fears that the leadership battle would be prolonged. Some traders were cheered that Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major was one of two new candidates, believing the Treasury's top official could help turn Britain's ailing economy turn around. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd also said he would challenge Michael Hesletine, the former defense minister who won enough votes last Tuesday to force a second ballot next Tuesday and prompt Mrs. Thatcher to step down. Traders said Mrs. Thatcher's announcement caught the financial community, like most everyone else, off-guard, especially after her determined statement Wednesday that she would fight on. But Kevin Darlington, a British economist with the London investment firm UBS Phillips and Drew, said: ``There was not the kind of fallout in the stock market or sterling that might have been expected because the worst already has been anticipated.'' The pound and share prices soared when news of her resignation broke in the morning, then fell back after Hurd and Major emerged before the noon deadline for nominations. ``The market is going mad in relief,'' said Peter Furlong, senior British equities dealer at Daiwa Securities. One buoyant factor during the day was widespread speculation that the Conservative government would launch the new post-Thatcher regime with a quick, half-point cut in Britain's 14 percent interest rates. The strong pound would allow an interest rate cut without risking sterling's position in the European exchange rate mechanism, which links European currencies and limits exchange rate swings. ``The decision to cut base rates has almost certainly been taken already,'' said Steven Bell, senior economist at Morgan Grenfell and Co. The pound finished the day at $1.9695, after rising as high as $1.98. It closed at $1.9680 Wednesday. The British currency also finished at 2.9118 German marks after rocketing to 2.9315 marks. The Wednesday late rate was 2.9122 marks. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished 1.6 points, or 0.08 percent, higher at 2,127.9. The session high, which came right after the resignation news, was 2,160.7, a gain of 34.4 points. Andrew Ellott, a corporate dealer with Chase Manhattan Bank in London, said ``The market was optimistic about the next election when Thatcher resigned. ``Then we had two new people come into the election who in my view are Mrs. Thatcher's proteges. I think that will very much split the vote with Heseltine.'' Darlington said: ``There will be enormous uncertainty over the next week. It looks increasingly likely that it (the leadership battle) will go to a third ballot next Thursday. ``One would expect a kind of paralysis to take hold'' in the markets, he said. Some equities and foreign exchange traders predicted that the financial markets' bullish reaction would be short-lived because the markets longer-term wouldn't be able to ignore Britain's underlying economic troubles. One analyst said ``the economic facts are still the same: the economy isn't running smoothly, inflation is too high.'' Inflation is running at 10.9 percent, although the economy is shrinking. But the business community was quick to express its regrets at Mrs. Thatcher's departure. Sir Brian Corby, president of the Confederation of British Industry, said: ``British business today is unrecognizable in the quality of its management, the revival of its investment in the future and in its ability to compete in the toughest markets throughout the world. ``Much of the credit for that historic turnaround belongs to the prime minister,'' Corby said. British Midland Airways Chairman Michael Bishop said he was extremely sorry about the resignation. Mrs. Thatcher had been ``the catalyst'' which had helped his company expand, he said.

DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto RM1 of Nov. 16
Nautilus Muscling Back After Bankruptcy Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: New owners of the exercise equipment firm Nautilus are trying to muscle their way back from bankruptcy court with a pitch to older folks that they can benefit from pumping iron. ``We're going to go at the competition from a position of strength and with a lot of new products,'' said Nautilus President Dan Baldwin. Baldwin has returned to the company he helped founder Arthur Jones build from 1974 to 1986. Travis Ward of Dallas bought the company in 198 for $38 million and filed for bankruptcy protection in February after four years of management turnovers and increasing debt and overhead. Retail sales of nearly $60 million in 1985 plummeted and the work force of 600 that year dropped to 250 in 1990, Baldwin said. Baldwin, while not giving the exact amount, said sales of Nautilus exercise machines have tripled since August, when he and a group of well-financed investors bought the company in bankruptcy court for $15 million. The company is designing weight machines for the elderly that will be lighter and easier to get into and out of. And it is expanding its focus to people over 45 whose concern is shifting from their grown children to their own bodies. ``If we can just get the message across to these people. They need more exercise than anyone else,'' said Baldwin, gray-haired but trim at 57. ``Ronald Reagan is a good example of what weightlifting can do.'' Reagan used Nautilus equipment in the White House when he was rehabilitating from his gunshot wound. Baldwin, who can still yank bank an entire stack on the curl machine, personifies the push to beat the lull in the economy by expanding the market base to middle-aged and elderly people. The privately held firm is negotiating to buy a company that makes aerobic equipment such as treadmills, exercise bikes and rowing machines, or enter a joint venture with one, Baldwin said. Industry experts credit Nautilus' second wind to its name recognition and its reputation. They said the company helped pioneer the movement that brought physical fitness out of the locker room and into health clubs, hotels and office buildings. ``They are a symbol for the industry,'' Club Industry Magazine publisher Marc Onigman said. Nautilus is trying to capitalize on its brand name by licensing it for bottled water, sports apparel and a soft drink being test-marketed by Dr Pepper. To help sell the new ideas, Baldwin has hired one of the world's largest advertising agencies, Saatchi and Saatchi, and a Madison Avenue public relations firm. ``Most companies come out of Chapter 11 very conservative,'' John Saunders, the vice president for sales and marketing said. ``This company is stronger today and better capitalized and better managed than at any point in history.'' The new line of weight machines with unique shielding to cover moving parts was shown last week at a national trade show in Chicago. ``People were pleasantly surprised by the presence Nautilus had at the show,'' Onigman said. ``The message was clear: they're coming back with a vengeance.'' But Baldwin conceded that it has been more difficult than he anticipated to rehabilitate the company, which listed a debt of $38.6 million and assets of $27.3 million when it filed for reorganization in bankruptcy court. Baldwin declined to say what the company's debt and assets are now. A New York market research firm, FIND-SVP, puts industry sales at about $250 million this year. In 1988, the research firm estimated that Universal Gym was the industry leader with sales of $30 million and Nautilus was second at $20 million. Onigman said the fitness industry, leery of the recession, is watching closely to see if Nautilus can regain its former strength. ``There are a lot of disciples of Nautilus out there,'' he said. ``Nobody likes to see a hero fall, even people that compete with Nautilus.''

DOC.HEAD: Ski Industry Brings Out New Technology To Avoid Economic Ruts
DOC.TEXT: Barren slopes in Europe and slowing traffic at U.S. resorts have put a chill in ski equipment sales, and manufacturers face another potential rut in the soggy economy, industry officials say. ``I think everybody is concerned,'' said David Ingemie, president of United Ski Industries Association, a group representing resorts and manufacturers. ``In the past, the ski industry has been recession resistant, but you're never sure.'' Even before this year's season opened, ski makers saw an inside threat, as industry giant Salomon S.A. - a powerful force in bindings and boots - edged into the market with a new line of skis. Combined with the slower business, it helped fuel a stir in the ski industry, which is offering all sorts of bargains and high-tech equipment to bring more people into the port. Figures compiled by the ski association reflect the sluggish times facing the industry. In the 1989-90 season, U.S. resorts recorded 50 million skier visits, a 6 percent drop from the year before. Prior to then, skier traffic had been flat for a couple of years. Officials say the situation has been more bleak in Europe, which has been plagued by little snowfall. Also, the drop off at ski lift lines has had a ripple effect in the equipment industry. ``If fewer people are going out skiing, they will tend to purchase less equipment,'' said Marvin Kottke, a retired University of Connecticut economist who conducts annual studies of the ski industry. U.S. equipment sales increased last season by 2 percent to $675 million, but industry experts say that was explained by higher prices. The number of skis sold, for example, declined by 3 percent to 1.1 million pairs. This year, the equipment industry is bracing for another threat in the sagging U.S. economy. The economic troubles have hit particularly hard in New England, home to many major resorts. Still, ski area operators are optimistic, saying their biggest concern is not the economy but the weather. At the retail level, die-hard skiers will still buy new equipment, which can cost up to several hundred dollars, said Chris Leake, vice president of merchandising for Ski Market Ltd., which operates a chain of stores in the Northeast. ``But most people are saying, `I think I'll make my boots last another year. I'll make my skis work another season,''' he said. ``I think it would be crazy to think the lack of confidence in the economy has no impact on the ski business,'' said Stuart Rempel, a marketing and communications executive for Salomon's U.S. headquarters in Georgetown, which is about 30 miles from Boston. Nonetheless, Salomon, based in France, has introduced a ski this year that the company spent five years and $40 million to develop. Rempel said the ski has a unique design that gives skiers more control and more speed. The new line is targeted for top-level skiers, and the company is making no concessions to what might be a tight market. Each pair of its skis will cost a whopping $595. That high price could cause some problems, given the current economic slump, Leake said. ``Potentially, Salomon's timing is poor,'' he said, but added: ``They've made a major commitment. Salomon isn't making skis for one year.'' In fact, Salomon plans to introduce a lower level of recreational skis next year, Rempel said. ``Our intention is to be a major force in skis,'' he said. This strategy is not lost on other ski makers. Salomon already dominates the world market in bindings, with a 45 percent share, according to Rempel's estimates, and is vying for the top spot in boots. ``If I was a competitor, I'd be nervous,'' said Ingemie at the ski industries association. Rossignol S.A., a world leader in the ski market, has come out with its own new skis this year, which also incorporate significant technological improvements to make turning easier, said Jeanne-Marie Gand, a company spokeswoman. ``You can't sit back on your laurels,'' she said, adding that the French company next year will introduce another ``incredible'' line of skis. Still, she said companies are working harder to make skiing a ``viable activity'' for people facing tight budgets. Some resorts are offering special family rates and free skiing for beginners to attract more people. Rossignol is working with some resorts and retailers to offer customers free lift tickets if they buy a pair of skis. ``We see much more of that this year,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Calling, This Time in China
DOC.TEXT: Avon has come calling with a Chinese-style sales approach for its beauty supplies. Instead of knocking on doors in the American tradition, Avon salespeople in China will use the time-hallowed Chinese custom of working through personal contacts. The first selling job Avon faced in China was with Chinese officials, according to John Novosad, vice president for the Asia-Pacific region of Avon Products Inc. ``The first thing we heard was, `What's direct selling?''' Novosad said Wednesday in a telephone interview from his Hong Kong office. ``They had great difficulty understanding why we thought this was a good idea. But we convinced them.'' Avon, through a joint venture with the Guangzhou Cosmetics Factory, then began selling beauty products this month in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou, also known as Canton. The company has 25 sales supervisors, all Chinese, who have recruited about 800 people to sell the beauty supplies on a commission basis, Novosad said. ``We expected to have to spend a lot of time teaching these people about profit incentive and the selling methods,'' Novosad said. ``You're talking about a country that we all believe doesn't know about these things. Well, it wasn't that way. The first question we heard was, `How much commission do I get?''' Avon, which already sells its products in more than 100 countries, is selling skin-care supplies, perfumes, cosmetics and personal hygiene items in China. They will be made in China with imported ingredients. The company's traditional image in the United States is of an ``Avon lady'' ringing doorbells and spending leisurely afternoons with her customers. ``Here, we're telling the representatives to build networks, talk to their sisters, talk to those they work with and so on. There are no limits, so it can be done door-to-door if they feel comfortable, or it can be done by taking brochures to work. It depends on the ingenuity.'' Novosad said Avon will test the method in Guangzhou before trying other parts of China. Avon supervisors receive a base salary, but also get a 2 percent to 6 percent commission on the sales of the representatives they recruit, Novosad said. The salespeople will receive a 25 percent commission on their sales, he said. ``We think it will work here and let us develop a base for all of China. China, once it gets economically going, will be a fabulous market of tremendous proportions,'' Novosad said. ``We don't expect to make millions at first.'' Prices for the Avon products sold in Guangzhou average about $3. That's one-tenth the average monthly income of a Chinese worker, but Guangzhou workers are generally better off than those elsewhere in the country. Customers are most likely to be single young women, who tend to have relatively high disposable incomes.

DOC.HEAD: Ten-Month Strike Puts Damper on Holiday Season
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Kevin Paxton has worked at the Teledyne CAE plant for more than 10 years. He says he was a company man who took pride in his work as a tool and die maker. But when the 35-year-old father of two thinks of Teledyne these days, he feels mostly anger and bitterness over a 10-month strike that has cast a pall over the holiday season. ``You do a good job for the company and you want to continue on, but they seem like they just don't care. That hurts. I mean I feel like my legs have been kicked out from under me,'' Paxton said Wednesday. A local grocery store gave away more than 100 turkeys this week to the striking employees to help them through Thanksgiving. Local 12, which also represents workers at the Toledo Jeep plants, has started a program called ``Adopt a Teledyne Family.'' Union members are being encouraged to give presents and other help to Teledyne families with children. Paxton said most of the 130 members of United Auto Workers Local 12 who went on strike in February feel that the walkout has gone on for too long. Teledyne hourly employees walked off the job after working eight months without a contract at the manufacturer of engines that power military missiles. A federal mediator is involved, but no new talks have been scheduled and the company has hired some replacement workers. A telephone message that a reporter left at the company's offices was not immediately returned. Workers at four other Teledyne plants in the United States also are on strike. David Bosworth, president of the union's Teledyne unit, said the union wants the company to continue paying health insurance to employees after they retire. In addition, Teledyne wants to cap cost of living increases for workers, who earn $13.50 an hour. It also is seeking job description changes that would allow some positions to be combined. Union members receive $100 a week in strike pay. Some members have wives who work; others have had to dip into their savings to support their families. ``I know of families that are hurting real bad. Members of this unit never expected to be on strike this long. I thought we'd have it over by now,'' Bosworth said. The mood was somber at a meeting Wednesday, where workers listened to the latest news about the strike and picked up food donated by other unions. ``I wish I had some good news, but I don't have any,'' Bosworth told more than 100 workers.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Europe, Japan Agree on Advanced Manufacturing Technology Project
DOC.TEXT: Japan, the United States and Europe have laid the groundwork for a joint development of ``intelligent'' future manufacturing technologies, negotiators said. ``This is the first time that this many countries have been represented ... in discussions about advanced manufacturing and how they can collaborate,'' a U.S. negotiator said. ``We're very pleased with the amount of progress we made.'' As proposed by Japan, the project would develop and set standards for future technologies such as computer-controlled flexible factories that could shift products with a simple change in software programs. A lack of standards in such technologies would make competition among suppliers difficult and complicate procurement for manufacturers, especially at overseas plants. The three sides agreed in talks this week in Tokyo on basic principles for the project, called the Intelligent Manufacturing System, but did not set any concrete plans, the officials said. U.S. officials said they now will explain the outcome of the talks to American industry and seek its consensus on how to proceed. ``If it is the feeling of industry to go ahead, the next step would be to actually negotiate an agreement for the first phase'' of the program, said a member of the U.S. delegation, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Japan originated the project, and offered to fund about 60 percent of its cost, partly in response to charges that it has used foreign technology but contributed too little to world scientific knowledge. More than 80 Japanese companies and a number of American firms have expressed interest in the program. But at a meeting in May, U.S. and European officials balked at adopting Japan's plan and demanded that preparation and control of the project be shared. Some U.S. business and government officials also accused Japan of planning to use the project to acquire U.S. technology and dominate future global manufacturing. ``The degree of skepticism has been reduced as a result of the dialogue,'' the U.S. official said. He said most U.S. proposals were accepted by Japan and the European Community during the two-day discussions, which ended Tuesday. ``The United States, Europe and Japan each have different strengths. If we select themes that will be of benefit to each of the participants, the result can be satisfactory to all,'' said Katsujiro Kida, director of the Industrial Machinery Division of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry. ``By advancing manufacturing technology, this will create a body of knowledge that will profit all humankind,'' he said. The U.S. official said it was unfortunate that American industry waited until Japan took the initiative in calling for research in manufacturing technologies, ``but we should take advantage of this opportunity.'' U.S. negotiators said they see the project as a broad umbrella under which many groups of researchers can work on a variety of projects. Although research topics have not been selected, Japanese officials envision standardized technologies that would allow factory computers and robots to communicate much more extensively. Factory machines would be linked directly with sales offices, parts suppliers and accounting departments. An order entered in an auto dealer's computer, for example, could automatically instruct computers at parts suppliers and factories to adjust assembly line robots at the appropriate time to produce a customized car, and enter the transaction in the firms' books.
